Let me put it like this... If you were looking for a game, look elsewhere. This is the taste of a different universe. An artistic masterpiece so ideal you'd die grateful to have witnessed it. And practically nothing can match it, which is why it is one of the best rated games of all time.

The story, the design, the action - it was made with love, with passion, with a longing for a life we will never live, a person we will never be, and seeing things we never will. But it shows us what could be, and a place of comfort to escape to when the real world is just too overbearing.

I recommend you play some games. And then play this. Because experiencing this will make everything else disappointing. Seriously. I went out of my way to play this again, just to soak in how good it was even if I may never get to relive the exact feeling I had then. And in doing so I found so much that I had missed during my first playthrough. I bought and played through the other games, watched so many in-depth videos on The Witcher series, and will probably get the books at some point. Which I never thought I'd do.

Look I was early to Baldur's Gate 3. And even that isn't quite on the level of The Witcher. There's just a surreal "vibe" to the story, and everything is so well done in it.
"I see you're a man well travelled, so tell me something, should I beat me wench once a week or oftener?"
Best game in videos gaming history. The music, gameplay, story, emotion everything is on point.

Not playble - random crashes (4070ti super + Ryzen 7900 + 96GB)
Setting:
New computer = AMD 7900 + rtx4070ti super + 96GB, Windows 10
New Nvidia driver for the new rtx 40 super series
Purchased witcher 3 to test my setting, fresh installation.


Results:
Random crashes between 5min to 2h --- you could hear music but computer no response at all, have to restart your pc.

Options tested: None / or their combinations work.
1. DLSS on/off
2. RT on/off
3. Hair on/off
4. frame rates 60/unlimited
5. DX 11/12
Others:
* Dynamic resolution
* resolution 1080/1440, full screen etc

Initially I thought my pc has some problem, until I found no problem with Furmark or other games.

I think it is an interesting game to play - I think I have more than 30 crashes with a total game/test time of 20 hours.

Having had five major playthroughs of The Witcher 3 over the years, I cannot recommend this game enough for fans of open-world, "fantasy-realism" RPGs. The writing, voice acting and story quality are excellent and full of humour, the combat is fluid and satisfying and there is a strong level of excitement created by unlocking new gear and visiting new locations. The graphics have also always been top tier, kept up to date with Patch 4.0 and the inclusion of ray tracing and HDR. 

The Blood and Wine DLC is definitely the best DLC pack I have played for any game, ever. It offers more of the best aspects of the base game, with its own bright atmosphere and locations which have been lovingly crafted with great ambition.

Vast and intricate world with so much to explore and do. The story line is great and the game play is as challenging as you'd like it to be. There is a reason it won game of the year. I've played it through a few times now and I've enjoyed it each time. If you haven't checked it out then I highly recommend you do so.

Good game. The world is immersive, looks and feels alive and the art is superb. The lore is masterful and the scope is huge. 

The story is well written for the most part, however there are arguably some dire pacing issues at the earlier part of the game. Took me multiple tries to get into the game and continue past the Griffin fight..

Moreover, some of the characters are complex and have a lot of depth.. but most are one dimensional and annoying. 

Now moving to gameplay, I think the combat system is pretty solid - however there's a lack of variety with the Skills tree. It's kind of a letdown that even after finishing the Main story, I don't feel a significant change in my combat playstyle and how skills progress.. 

Perhaps they were aiming to make the Signs complimentary mechanics and not the main focus, but I don't think it's an excuse (in contrast, the Skills progression in Skyrim felt much more rewarding for me). 

And.. about the side content, some of it is high quality and at times as good as the Main Quests, and some are very generic and feel like a chore from start to finish, and get repetitive.

Anyway, Gwent is amazing - 10/10 IGN.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

The game is good. It took me two attempts to actually get into the game. First time was like a lot of people after watching the series, I got motivated to try the game. Gave it a couple hours but couldn't really get into it because of how slow the pace of the game is. Second time I knew this going in so it was easier. Voice actors are pretty good for the most part, to be honest geralt is probably the worst voice actor in the game. At times it is really bad. It plays pretty slow, but very very similar to assassins creed in game play minus the parkour aspect. Surprisingly there are still game breaking bugs that I've run into. I've hopped on the horse and then couldn't move except for swinging a sword. Try jumping over stuff on the horse and it freezes and contorts in mid air. Some quests get glitched and will not move forward. Usually have to load a previous save a couple times or run back and forth multiple times trying to trigger something. I'm also not a fan of the way the quests are given. I don't like that they flood you with all these quests, and if you don't know what you're doing you can fail a whole lot of them if you advance too far in other quests. This process of doing it makes absolutely no sense to me. NPC's spawning under the map with just the top of the head sticking out. All in all though this game will keep you busy for a long while if you can get into it. 101 hours later and I'm still in the second territory, velen/novigrad.

As a dedicated fan of the Witcher franchise, immersing myself in the rich, expansive world of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt has been an unforgettable journey that has spanned over 250 hours of pure gaming bliss. CD Projekt Red has truly outdone themselves with this masterpiece, crafting an experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming and leaves an indelible mark on the RPG genre.

The narrative of The Witcher 3 is nothing short of a magnum opus. It weaves a complex tapestry of political intrigue, personal struggles, and moral ambiguity, all set against the backdrop of a stunningly realized open world. Geralt of Rivia's quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, unfolds in a non-linear fashion, offering players a narrative depth rarely seen in gaming. Every choice you make, every ally you forge or betray, resonates throughout the story, shaping the world around you in ways both subtle and profound.

The attention to detail in the game's design is nothing short of awe-inspiring. From the bustling city of Novigrad to the war-torn landscapes of Velen and the hauntingly beautiful Skellige Isles, each locale feels alive and brimming with stories waiting to be discovered. The environmental storytelling is top-notch, with every nook and cranny holding secrets, lore, and challenges for those willing to explore.

The character development is a testament to CD Projekt Red's dedication to their craft. Geralt's stoic demeanor hides a depth of emotion, and the supporting cast is filled with memorable and nuanced characters. Whether it's the sharp-tongued Yennefer, the roguish bard Dandelion, or the enigmatic sorceress Triss Merigold, each character feels like a living, breathing entity with their own motives and desires.

Combat in The Witcher 3 is a finely tuned dance of steel and magic. The variety of weapons, armor, and spells allows for a customizable playstyle, and the monster-slaying contracts provide a challenging and rewarding experience. The progression system is robust, ensuring that every level gained feels meaningful and empowering.

What truly sets The Witcher 3 apart, however, is the sheer amount of love and passion poured into every aspect of the game. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, the meticulously crafted quests, the jaw-dropping visuals ‚Äì it's clear that CD Projekt Red aimed for perfection and achieved it.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's an experience that will linger in your thoughts long after the credits roll. With its compelling narrative, breathtaking world, and unparalleled attention to detail, this game stands as a shining example of what the RPG genre can achieve. For any fan of the Witcher series or RPG enthusiasts in general, The Witcher 3 is an absolute must-play, and I can confidently say that my 250 hours spent in this enchanting world have been some of the most rewarding in my gaming history.

I wish I could get my money back for this game. It is MASSIVELY overhyped. I've attempted it 3 times now, once on switch and twice on PC. Using a 4090 to crank the graphics settings, I'm still unimpressed with how this game looks - even in 4K. That aside, the world feels so sterile, its incredibly difficult to interact with anything. The game doesn't reward exploration and just sort of expects you to follow a pre-determined path. The mechanics and menus are cumbersome. Why do I have to open 3 menus just to heal my character? Combat is repetitive and just gives me no incentive to keep trying at a boss because I'm not having fun. Even basic traversal feels like a chore and riding your horse is even worse. I'm not even impressed with the voice acting, I'm actually sick of Geralt's little quips especially when talking to Roach. 

All around a sub-par experience, I don't understand why its still so highly regarded. Don't waste your money.

Greetings, fellow travelers, Geralt of Rivia here. Yes, *the* Witcher, silver-haired monster hunter extraordinaire, and unwitting star of "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt." Sit down, pour yourself a drink‚Äîpreferably something strong‚Äîand let me regale you with the tale of my latest, grand adventure. Mind you, it's not every day I write video game reviews, but when I do, I prefer to add a touch of... let's call it, rugged charm.

First off, let's talk about the sheer size of my playground. The lands of Velen, Novigrad, and Skellige are so vast, you'd think you were on a continental tour rather than a quest to find Ciri. I've spent more time on horseback traversing these realms than I have in baths‚Äîand let me tell you, I do enjoy a good soak. Roach, my trusty steed, has seen more landscapes than a well-traveled bard. And don't get me started on the number of times she's spontaneously decided to mount a fence or a rooftop. A mind of her own, that one.

Combat, ah, the bread and butter of witchering. It's like a dance, indeed, if dancing involved slicing drowners in half and setting fire to vampire nests. My moves are a blend of poetry and violence‚Äîa pirouette here, a decapitation there. And yes, I do occasionally talk to myself during battles. Keeps the morale up, you see.

Magic, or as we in the business call it, "signs," are a handy toolkit. Ever tried to negotiate with a bandit only to find words failing you? A blast of Aard tends to send the right message. And Igni? Nothing like a bit of fire to brighten up a nekker's day. It's all in a day's work.

Now, the heart of this tale‚Äîfinding my surrogate daughter, Ciri. Between you and me, it's not just a simple fetch quest. It's an epic saga involving time travel, other dimensions, and a Wild Hunt that's as persistent as a debt collector. Along the way, I've had the pleasure of rekindling old flames, playing politics, and yes, even partaking in a bit of family counseling with vampires.

The characters I've met? Imagine the most colorful carnival you've ever attended. From sorceresses with more secrets than I have scars, to a bard who's more interested in his next ballad than his next meal. And let's not forget the Bloody Baron‚Äîa man with a story so touching, I almost forgot to charge him for my services. Almost.

Side quests are a Witcher's delight. Ever had to judge a beauty contest for trolls? I have. Or search for a pan with as much zeal as for a lost princess? Done that too. The variety is astounding. It's like the locals see me coming and think, "Here's a man who looks like he'd love to chase after my runaway goat."

In closing, "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" isn't just another entry in my ledger. It's a testament to my endless journey‚Äîa mix of heroics, heartbreak, and the occasional game of Gwent (a card game that's dangerously addictive, I warn you). So, if you ever wonder what it's like to walk a mile in my boots, to face down beasts and bandits with naught but your wits and your sword, give it a try. Just remember, it's not all monsters and magic; there's a lot of horse-chasing, too.

Till our paths cross again,
Geralt of Rivia

One of the best games of all time.
Graphically stunning; an easy to use and rewarding crafting system; adrenaline-filled, gory, and satisfying combat-- every combat sequence is a unique and thrilling experience, where you will use both magic and swords (Witchers always hold two swords: a steel sword for humans, and a silver sword for monsters) to defeat your enemies. You'll be confronted with some of the most intense choice based story sequences in all of gaming, many of which will cause you to question your own morality. These often tough choices have a lasting impact on the characters and world around you, and ultimately affect how the story unfolds. All of this is perfectly blended with a rich, fantastical open-world, a dazzling musical score, and a seemingly flawless plot which make this a strong contender for the greatest game of all time.
I am currently on my second run-- the first time I played it on Xbox One-- and it's great to see how different the story can be based on the choices you make throughout the game.
Addictive, masterful storytelling combined with fluid, visceral combat make this game one hell of an experience. It's a thrill-ride you won't forget any time soon; an absolute must-play.

Hands down the BEST game I have ever played. I highly recommend this to everyone. It's got everything a single player game could ever need. Incredible stories, side quests, exciting combat, the ability to craft and upgrade gear, and good graphics. You have the freedom to make your own decisions and shape the story however you want. I'm a huge fan of the books as well, and this feels like an excellent close to Geralt's story. This game truly makes you feel like you are completely immersed in the world, like you ARE Geralt of Rivia. The two DLCs are the best DLCs you will ever play. They both have amazing storylines, and especially the Blood and Wine DLC is like a whole new game, in a whole new area! An absolute 10/10 game. A warning though, once you finish this game, no other game will feel the same!!

The best game I've ever played is truly a work of art. The story is a solid 10 out of 10, and the replayability is off the charts. You can explore numerous fun builds, each with its own unique appeal. The side quests are incredible, with over 270 to keep you engaged. The game even offers a very challenging difficulty setting and a new game plus option, allowing you to replay with all the items from your first run, plus some exciting new additions.
The DLCs, especially Blood and Wine, feel like an entirely new game, introducing a lot of fresh content beyond just quests. The vast and immersive map ensures you'll never run out of things to discover in this lively, big and dynamic world. It's unlikely you'll uncover everything in your first 2-3 runs due to the sheer amount of events happening. I recommend starting on a high difficulty, delving into plenty of side quests, and losing yourself in the vast landscape on your trusty steed, Roach. The world will continually surprise you with unexpected delights.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's an immersive journey into a meticulously crafted world filled with breathtaking landscapes, captivating characters, and epic adventures. From the moment you step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, you are whisked away on a fantastical quest that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

One of the most remarkable aspects of The Witcher 3 is its sprawling open world, teeming with life and detail. Whether you're traversing the rugged terrain of Skellige's islands or navigating the winding streets of Novigrad, each location feels alive with its own history, culture, and challenges to overcome.

But what truly sets The Witcher 3 apart is its narrative depth and character development. The game's storytelling is nothing short of exceptional, weaving together intricate plotlines, moral dilemmas, and unexpected twists that keep you guessing until the very end. Every decision you make, no matter how seemingly insignificant, has far-reaching consequences that shape the world around you and the fate of its inhabitants.

Of course, no discussion of The Witcher 3 would be complete without mentioning its stellar cast of characters. From the enigmatic sorceress Yennefer to the loyal bard Dandelion, each character is brought to life with remarkable depth and complexity, making you care deeply about their fates and motivations.

But perhaps the crowning achievement of The Witcher 3 is its gameplay. Combat is fluid and dynamic, allowing you to seamlessly switch between swordplay, magic, and alchemy as you face off against a diverse array of foes. And with a wealth of side quests, treasure hunts, and monster contracts to undertake, there's never a shortage of things to do or discover in the world of The Witcher.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a true masterpiece of modern gaming. With its stunning visuals, gripping storylines, and immersive gameplay, it sets a new standard for open-world RPGs and cements its place as one of the greatest games of all time. Whether you're a seasoned adventurer or a newcomer to the genre, The Witcher 3 is an experience that should not be missed.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a monumental achievement in gaming, a testament to the power of immersive storytelling and captivating world-building. As a fan of the books and a dedicated gamer, stepping into Geralt of Rivia's shoes felt like coming home to a rich and vibrant universe that I had grown to love.

From the moment I set foot in the sprawling landscapes of Temeria and beyond, I was enraptured by the game's stunning visuals and attention to detail. Every corner of the world felt alive with its own stories, characters, and secrets waiting to be uncovered. Whether traversing the windswept plains of Velen or navigating the winding streets of Novigrad, The Witcher 3's world felt vast, diverse, and utterly immersive.

What truly sets The Witcher 3 apart, however, is its masterful storytelling. Drawing from the rich lore of Andrzej Sapkowski's novels, the game weaves a complex tapestry of politics, betrayal, and moral ambiguity that kept me engrossed from start to finish. The characters are beautifully realized, with their own motivations, flaws, and shades of gray that make them feel like real people struggling to survive in a harsh and unforgiving world.

As someone who has read the books, I was delighted to see familiar faces and places brought to life with such care and attention to detail. From Geralt's iconic silver sword to the haunting melodies of the game's soundtrack, every aspect of The Witcher 3 felt like a loving tribute to the source material.

But beyond its rich storytelling and immersive world, The Witcher 3 also delivers on the gameplay front. The combat is fluid and satisfying, with a wide variety of weapons, spells, and abilities to master. The quests are diverse and engaging, ranging from epic battles against monstrous creatures to intimate moments of moral decision-making that have lasting consequences.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is more than just a game‚Äîit's an epic journey that transcends the medium. Its rich narrative, captivating world, and unforgettable characters have left an indelible mark on me as both a player and a fan of fantasy literature. It's not just one of my favorite games; it's a masterpiece that I will cherish for years to come.

Witcher 3 has been my favorite game for a very long time. I've played this game countless times back in 2015-2016. Recently with the release of Baldur's Gate 3, I said that it, as in BG3, has become my new favorite game and rightfully so. I got Witcher 3 on Steam now mostly to get my 100% achievements for a great game in order, but while I played this game for like the millionth time, I did not feel bored, it did not feel daunting. I was playing looking at the environment, graphics, design and I couldn't believe this game was released in 2015. I thought it would feel like a chore playing this and that most of my good memories with the game were pure nostalgia but after finally completing it, I can say it is not, in fact, nostalgia, but actually an insanely well done game that held up for, what is now, 9 years.

This game is definitely very good and worth playing. However it has got some quirks...

pros:
+ gigantic world
+ shit load of quests and points of interest
+ beautiful graphics
+ the gwent card game is very well implemented solution to the boring pure luck based dice poker. 
+ Heart of Stone DLC does have quite interesting story
+ some quests are also well done and give og Witcher 1 vibes (Djikstra's treasure, finding the murderer who hurt Priscilla)
+ huge variety of enemies
+ you can do a skill reset as much as you wish (almost)
+ lots of references to books or previous witcher games
+ its the complete opposite of the trash netflix series

cons:
- extremely uninteresting skills in the skill tree
- the blood and wine mutations do not really bring much improvements to the combat, it just pretty much enhances your stats.
- leveling up takes soooooooo much time and offers no real excitement of getting a new skill.
- the combat system is very primitive, you can literally beat anything (even monsters 20 levels higher than you) by just spamming left mouse button and occasionally reapplying quen or dodging.
- there's so huge potential with the bestiary, learning about the monsters weaknesses and using them against your enemies. This thing is purely useless, again you can just spam anything with light attack for easy win. I literally play this game using only one hand.
- given the fact that after 2 witcher games the combat system has only gotten worse, this negative rating is fully justified - Witcher 3 has the least exciting and boring combat system.

Even after the next gen update, the combat still sucks ass. I would really love to see something that takes more than 2 braincells to beat the enemies.

now after the combat system has received enough hate let's move onto the story...

- story is marvel/fairy tale tier, that means it's very primitive and characters are black'n'white aka the good guys and the bad guys. The story ends by the good guys beating the bad guys. There's nothing else to the whole story of The Witcher 3. The worst and least interesting story of all the witcher games yet.

- wayyyyyy less sex scenes
- no sex cards in the journal character entries
- no uma sex scene
- no more arm wrestling
- no more dice poker
- very limited challenge in the gwent minigame
- gwent AI is sometimes insanely stupid
- the horse race minigame is more of a "body block your opponents when the horses stamina is low" than a race game.
- Geralt has way stronger feeling for moral values than he should have
- the whole game is too family friendly
- no equipment imported from The witcher 2 save
- if you want to get all the achievements in the game - they are grindy af and not really challenging.
- no Iorveth appearance
- no Yarpen Zigrin
- would expect next gen update to add a new dlc
- the existence of another random game launcher and the requirement of having it installed to play this game is an absurd tragedy. Fortunatelly, you are not forced to create another stupid throwaway account for this random launcher app.

Should you give it a try?
absolutely - though this game sucks for a witcher game it certainly is not a trash game and can offer hundreds of hours of fun.

Also I would love to say that the hour count of mine is mostly idled but it is not really...

Hmm: A Majestic Tale of Witchers, War, and Wonder

Introduction:
Embark on a journey of epic proportions in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, a game that stands as a magnum opus in the realm of open-world RPGs. From its captivating storyline to its breathtaking landscapes, The Witcher 3 sets a new standard for immersive gaming experiences. Join Geralt of Rivia, the legendary monster hunter, as he navigates a world torn apart by war, politics, and ancient prophecies. In this review, we'll delve into the depths of The Witcher 3 and uncover why it remains an unforgettable masterpiece years after its release.

Dynamic Storytelling and Rich Characters:
At its core, The Witcher 3 is a tale of love, loss, and the pursuit of destiny. Players step into the boots of Geralt, a hardened yet compassionate Witcher, as he embarks on a quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, and save her from the clutches of the mysterious Wild Hunt. Along the way, Geralt encounters a cast of unforgettable characters, each with their own hopes, fears, and motivations. From the enigmatic sorceress Yennefer to the charming bard Dandelion, every character feels fleshed out and multidimensional, contributing to the game's rich tapestry of storytelling.

Expansive Open World:
The world of The Witcher 3 is a sprawling expanse of forests, mountains, and bustling cities, teeming with life and detail. From the war-torn landscapes of Velen to the sun-kissed shores of Skellige, each region offers its own unique atmosphere and challenges to overcome. Whether you're tracking down a monstrous griffin, exploring ancient ruins, or embarking on a quest to aid the local populace, there's always something new and exciting to discover in the world of The Witcher 3. The sense of immersion is unparalleled, with dynamic weather systems, realistic NPC behavior, and breathtaking vistas that make every moment feel alive and vibrant.

Deep and Engaging Gameplay:
The Witcher 3 offers a rich and varied gameplay experience that seamlessly blends action, exploration, and role-playing elements. Combat is fluid and satisfying, with Geralt wielding a combination of swordplay, magic, and alchemy to overcome his foes. The game's branching questlines and multiple endings provide ample opportunity for replayability, as players navigate moral dilemmas and make decisions that shape the fate of the world around them. Beyond the main storyline, there are countless side quests and activities to enjoy, from monster contracts and treasure hunts to horse racing and Gwent, a card game played throughout the world. The depth of the gameplay ensures that there's always something new and exciting to sink your teeth into.

Stunning Visuals and Immersive Sound Design:
Visually, The Witcher 3 is a feast for the eyes, with stunning graphics and breathtaking art direction that bring its world to life in stunning detail. From the rugged landscapes of the Skellige Isles to the bustling streets of Novigrad, each environment is rendered with meticulous care and attention to detail. Character models are equally impressive, with lifelike animations and expressions that add depth and personality to the game's inhabitants. The game's soundtrack, composed by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz, is a masterpiece of atmospheric music, with haunting melodies and epic orchestral scores that perfectly complement the game's tone and setting.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterclass in storytelling, world-building, and gameplay design that sets a new benchmark for open-world RPGs. With its captivating narrative, expansive open world, deep and engaging gameplay, and stunning visuals and sound design, it's a game that offers an unforgettable experience from start to finish. Whether you're a fan of the Witcher series or a newcomer to Geralt's world, The Witcher 3 is a must-play title that deserves a place in every gamer's collection.

Definitely a 10/10. Highly recommended!

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a towering achievement in the realm of fantasy gaming, weaving together an intricate tapestry of compelling narratives, rich characters, and immersive environments that captivate players from start to finish. As an avid gamer and enthusiast of the fantasy genre, delving into the vast world of The Witcher 3 was nothing short of a transformative experience.

At the heart of The Witcher 3 lies its unparalleled storytelling. The narrative unfolds with the grace of a finely crafted novel, drawing players into a world teeming with political intrigue, moral ambiguity, and existential themes. Set against the backdrop of war-torn kingdoms and shadowy conspiracies, players assume the role of Geralt of Rivia, a seasoned monster hunter known as a Witcher. Geralt's journey is deeply personal yet intertwined with the fate of the world, as he embarks on a quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, and confront the malevolent force known as the Wild Hunt.

One of the game's greatest strengths lies in its characters, each impeccably crafted with layers of complexity and nuance. From the stoic Geralt to the enigmatic sorceress Yennefer, and the fiercely independent Ciri, every character feels like a fully realized individual with their own motivations and struggles. The relationships forged throughout the game are equally captivating, as players navigate intricate webs of alliances and betrayals that shape the course of their journey.

Quest design in The Witcher 3 is a testament to CD Projekt Red's commitment to excellence. From the epic main storyline to the countless side quests and contracts scattered throughout the world, every mission feels meaningful and engaging. Whether tracking down a mythical beast or unraveling a town's dark secrets, each quest is meticulously crafted with its own unique narrative arc and moral dilemmas, ensuring that no two experiences are alike.

The game's atmosphere is nothing short of breathtaking, with sprawling landscapes, bustling cities, and foreboding forests brought to life with stunning detail and atmospheric lighting. From the windswept cliffs of Skellige to the war-torn streets of Novigrad, every location feels alive with its own distinct culture and history.

Moreover, The Witcher 3's downloadable content expansions, particularly "Hearts of Stone" and "Blood and Wine," elevate the game to even greater heights. "Hearts of Stone" delves into Geralt's past and introduces players to a cast of intriguing new characters, while "Blood and Wine" transports players to the vibrant land of Toussaint, a realm of chivalry and wine, filled with new quests, creatures, and adventures. Both expansions offer hours of additional content that seamlessly integrate with the main game, further enriching an already expansive experience.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a tour de force of fantasy gaming that sets a new standard for storytelling, character development, and world-building. With its gripping plot, memorable characters, and vast open world teeming with adventures, it's a game that will undoubtedly stand the test of time and continue to enchant players for years to come. Whether you're a seasoned Witcher fan or a newcomer to the series, this is an experience that should not be missed.

The Witcher 3 simply remains the best open-world action RPG. It ticks all the boxes a title from this genre should and it does it all borderline perfectly.
The stories, characters, dialogues, choices you can make and world-building are hands down the best I have seen in any game. Main characters and plot are very well written and the latter has pretty good pacing all in all. The world always feels alive and is fun to explore with plenty of outstanding optional quests which have interesting stories and fleshed out characters tied to them, or just randomly tucked in useful items and materials guarded by various enemies. Even though the core gameplay loops are bound to become repetitive in a game of this size, the quality and amount of various narratives make up for it, since the side quests here are easily the most elaborate you can find. There are different ways for just about anything to unfold and a vast majority of your decisions are quite impactful, choices often being morally grey or without easily predictable outcome and consequences, making the role-playing part more engaging. Darker, difficult moments and more light-hearted parts are well balanced. Same goes for happy, neutral and sad conclusions, resulting in a very immersive experience.
Combat is not spectacular compared to purely action games, but it's fairly decent - responsive, a good number of different moves and abilities, slick animations, several difficulties... There's a high variety of enemies, both regular and "boss" ones, all with detailed lore and different strengths and weaknesses. Ability / talent development and gearing / crafting options for Geralt are alright. The builds won't completely change your playstyle, but there's enough to allow for some experimentation.
All the systems are well done and nothing feels out of place or poorly implemented. If you get bored of combat, exploration, talking, occasional horse-racing, puzzles and riddles - you can always play some Gwent, which is insanely fun for a mini-game!
The visuals are great for its time and still hold up, especially after the awesome next-gen upgrade which brings numerous graphical and QoL improvements. Soundtrack is pleasant, UI is functional... I honestly don't think I have a single complaint.
The two expansions are excellent as well, especially Blood and Wine which might be even better than the already amazing base game.
To conclude: Witcher 3 is surely one of, if not *the* best game I have ever played.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is hands down one of the best RPGs I've ever played. I‚Äôve played the whole game on my other account but now i‚Äôm gonna play it on this account also, Seriously, this game is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. From the moment you start playing, you're sucked into this incredibly detailed world filled with monsters, magic, and political intrigue.

The storyline is just...wow. It's so rich and immersive, with twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. And the characters? They feel so real, with their own personalities, motivations, and flaws. You really get invested in their journeys, which makes every decision you make feel weighty and important.

And let's talk about the world itself. It's massive, but it never feels empty or boring. There's always something to do, whether it's hunting down monsters, exploring hidden caves, or just chilling in a tavern playing Gwent. And speaking of Gwent, don't even get me started on how addictive that card game is!

Combat is another highlight. It's challenging, but in a good way. You have to be strategic with your swordplay, magic, and potions to take down tougher enemies, and it feels incredibly satisfying when you pull off a tough fight.

Honestly, I could go on and on about how amazing this game is, but I'll just say this: if you haven't played The Witcher 3 yet, do yourself a favor and pick it up. You won't regret it.

Update: BG3 bangs, best game. 

Really recommend to play 2 other games or/and read the books. Books first then games , for the best experience.Otherwise you won't experience the same emotions seeing  characters the way the game presents them compared to how you imagined them inside your head while reading the book. But if you do otherwise you will have a clearer view of what is going on in the book as you won't have to imagine anything (experienced both). 

Positives:
-Amazing soundtrack
-Strong main and side storyline(s) 
-Variety of consequences for the actions meaning every player has a unique experience of their own
-Challenging the entire time (unless played on lower than Blood and Broken Bones and without enemy upscaling)
-High character customization (mostly armour and swords tho)
-Great athmosphere of  the medieval age 
-Dialogues refer to Geralts adventures described in books often , making it sweeter for the players that read the books
-Gwent , a great minigame that makes usual collectibles  into a wonderful entertainment 
-Over 400 quests
-Great replay-ability 
-Cheap for a AAA project
-Did i mention the soundtrack?
-Great voicover for dialogues 
-A world that engages the player to explore it
-Fooking nordlings
-Lots of charecters from previous games
-Your actions actually determine the lives of people and communities surrounding you
-For ¬£30 you get ¬£100 worth of content .
-Time demanding



Negatives:
-Combat , not very rewarding for using a variety of techniques . Most of the players will just spam Alt+M1 as it is the most effective way.
-Roach is kinda buggy , which makes you laugh at first but starts to annoy later
-Controls don't respond correctly in combat , leading to death/taking damage(happened 5 times in  100 hrs)
-The game is too damn good , so if you fall in love with it playing becomes painful . Meaning that you won't wish the adventure to end.
-Limit of 12 slots for perks , meaning that you will never experience geralt with every single perk in the game (though Hearts of Stone makes the situation better , adding mutarions)
-Time demanding.




Overall , if you are not a book fan or just not into medieval RPG's as much as Witchers community you will get a clearer view what a banger Cyberpunk 2077 will be.

This game is a masterpiece. Definitely an instant classic where you get to play as the legendary Witcher himself Jerry, finish the fight against a group of murderous furry cat people called the Wild Hunt, while protecting your surrogate daughter who's destiny it is to save the world from the deathly, pale void called the White Frost.

Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who wants to play a great game from the 8th generation of gaming (2013 - 2020). This game has maps you can get lost in for hours on end; I know I did for Toussaint; great romance options such as Yennefer or Shani, and no Triss and Syanna are the kind of chicks you'd stay away from in real life lest you wanna false accusation taken your way. Other than that, the supporting cast of characters such as Ciri, the an-Craite clan, and the Bloody Baron, as well as DLC characters like Olgierd and Regis that are compelling and carry each story and quest that they are in to make such a great narrative.

In conclusion, buy this game if you're a fan regardless of sale or not (I'd wait for a sale personally).

The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece, a game where my every decision feels like I'm shaping the destiny of an entire universe... until I try to romance someone. Geralt, my silver fox, turns into a medieval Casanova, and I end up with the romantic finesse of a potato.

I tried wooing Yennefer, but it was more awkward than a bard with stage fright. My attempts at romance were so cringe-worthy that even the in-game monsters were rolling their eyes. Geralt may be a monster hunter, but he's no match for the real beast: my attempts at love.

And let's talk about Gwent - I'm more likely to summon a deck of Uno cards in real life than master this card game. My Geralt might be a legendary Witcher, but he's also the guy who accidentally punches a merchant while trying to buy bread.

The Witcher 3, where my choices shape the world, but my attempts at love are straight out of a tragic comedy. 10/10 for making me feel like a powerful hero while also proving that my social skills in the game are as rusty as Geralt's swords.

Title: The Witcher 3: A Masterpiece of Epic Proportions

Introduction:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a testament to the heights video game storytelling can reach. From its breathtaking visuals to its immersive world and intricate storyline, every facet of this game exudes excellence. With all DLCs and expansions, The Witcher 3 delivers an unforgettable experience that will linger in the minds of players long after the final credits roll.

Main Game: The Wild Hunt
In The Witcher 3's main storyline, players step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, a seasoned monster hunter, as he embarks on a quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, pursued by the otherworldly Wild Hunt. The narrative unfolds in a vast open world, filled with political intrigue, moral ambiguity, and unforgettable characters. From the war-torn landscapes of Velen to the bustling streets of Novigrad and the majestic vistas of Skellige, every corner of the world is meticulously crafted and teeming with life.

The main storyline is a rollercoaster of emotions, blending personal stakes with grand political machinations. Players will find themselves drawn into a web of alliances, betrayals, and unexpected twists as they unravel the mystery of Ciri's heritage and the true nature of the Wild Hunt. Along the way, the game presents players with meaningful choices that shape the world and characters around them, making every decision feel weighty and impactful.

The visual fidelity of The Witcher 3 is nothing short of breathtaking. From the haunting beauty of the haunted swamps to the awe-inspiring architecture of ancient ruins, every environment is rendered with painstaking detail. Character models are equally impressive, with lifelike animations and expressive faces that bring the inhabitants of the world to life. Whether exploring the bustling streets of Novigrad or navigating treacherous forests, the game's visuals never fail to impress.

Expansions:
Hearts of Stone
Hearts of Stone takes players on a dark and twisted journey into the heart of Temeria, where they encounter Gaunter O'Dimm, a mysterious and enigmatic character with a penchant for making Faustian bargains. The expansion introduces a new cast of memorable characters, including the tragic figure of Olgierd von Everec, whose tale of love and loss serves as the emotional core of the storyline.

With its intricate plotlines and morally ambiguous choices, Hearts of Stone offers a refreshing change of pace from the main game. Players will find themselves drawn into a world of deceit and betrayal, where nothing is as it seems and even the most noble intentions can lead to unforeseen consequences.

Blood and Wine
Blood and Wine transports players to the sun-drenched kingdom of Toussaint, a land of chivalry and honor, where they become embroiled in a mystery involving a series of gruesome murders. As Geralt delves deeper into the investigation, he uncovers a dark secret lurking beneath the surface of this seemingly idyllic paradise.

With its vibrant colors and picturesque landscapes, Blood and Wine offers a stark contrast to the grim and war-torn world of the main game. But beneath its facade of beauty lies a story of corruption and decay, as players navigate the treacherous politics of Toussaint and uncover the true nature of the monsters that haunt its streets.

Conclusion:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, along with its DLCs and expansions, stands as a crowning achievement in the world of video game storytelling. With its richly detailed world, compelling characters, and intricate plotlines, it offers an experience that is as emotionally resonant as it is intellectually stimulating. Whether you're a fan of epic fantasy or simply appreciate a well-crafted narrative, The Witcher 3 is a must-play experience that will leave you breathless from start to finish.

Years ago i left my old laptop and bought a proper Gaming PC, naturally I began searching for new games to try out, games that i could never play in my old yet trusty laptop.
I was quite intrigued by the Witcher 3, something caught my interest in the trailers, so i started playing, and oh boy... was I surprised.

Fast forward to today and I played countless hours of the Witcher games, bought all of Sapkowski¬¥s stories, fell in love with Gwent and just recently read Rafal Jaki¬¥s take on a Ronin Witcher... I¬¥m even writing this review with a wolf medallion around my neck...

That had never happened, I watched, read and played a lot of media, not one came close to The Witcher, and for that, this game will always be my favourite.

I almost feel obligated to thank Sapkowski for creating this world, and CDPR for respecting the source material and developing it, you¬¥ve all created a fascinating universe.

Geralt of Rivia... That¬¥s a name I won¬¥t easily forget...

There is nothing that can be said about this game that hasn't been said already, but 1000 hours down, here goes!

From beginning to end, an absolute masterpiece. I myself went into this blind, with no idea about the books and got utterly entranced by the level of world building CDPR achieved in this adaptation. The characters and the flow of the story are so finely crafted, its hard to stop and return later.

The game can best be experienced in two parts - the side quests and all explorable areas, and then the main quest because if there is a way to do side quests right, this game does it. None are mere 'fetch' quests and there is no backtracking to return to the contract giver unless for a very valid in-story reason. Be aware that completing all of the side quests will make your character pretty OP for the main story, but that takes nothing away from the immersion. Even better that many times, the side quests have some hidden connecting thread that becomes apparent only when you have progressed enough.

Each of the monsters you face, has certain tactics and weaknesses and if you find yourself underpowered, you can go down the rabbit hole of potions and oils, though you can also entirely avoid that and focus on getting hold of the best possible weapon and armor sets. If you don't like grinding for coin, then make sure to loot every body of every victim, since you can become rich just by selling weapons and armor. To be clear, there is absolutely nothing in the game that requires you to repeat the same thing twice. There are however optimal and sub optimal choices to getting resources quickly, but with just enough leeway granted that it never feels like a hassle.

Witcher 'signs' bring an entirely new dimension to combat, and 'abilities' and 'mutations' even more so. If you find parrying difficult, you can upgrade your 'Igni' sign to begin with a burst of fire that burns the enemy or the "Aard' sign to stagger them, then rush in to deal a couple of swift sword blows and retreat, waiting for the 'bleeding ability' to further wear down defenses until you begin the final set of swift attacks with a strong finisher. There are an incredible number of combinations and variations to playstyle. You can watch a trailer for the game called 'A Night to Remember' for a flavor of this.

But gameplay aside, what sets the experience of playing this game apart from others, is the character development and balanced story progression. There are zero unnecessary dialogues, and you would find yourself amazed by the ease by which is built a world where you are at the same time an outcast shunned by the populace, but also a potently powerful creature and where you try to tread the thin line between taking one side or the other - when there are no easy choices to make. What starts off as a deeply personal mission (finding your daughter) ends up as an intricate dance across kingdoms, across worlds and across webs of intrigue that are brilliantly crafted around your character. Furthermore, the voice acting is incredible, and that includes even random NPCs. Even on subsequent playthroughs, you would likely not be skipping through the cutscenes.

Choices absolutely will matter and affect not only your experience of the quests and side quests, but also the main ending. This gives you a huge reason to replay the game several times. One of the best ways this is implemented is in recruiting allies for an epic midgame battle, which plays out differently scene by scene based on who is on your side.

So take the plunge and make the time for this game. You would keep memories of it, for years later, and one thing is guaranteed - there would be characters you actually miss with all your heart once the game is over.

About 10 hours into the game I have no compelling or interesting supporting characters to interact with.  RPGs of this nature are strongly determined by who you interact with in a game world, not who you get to play as.  However "The Witcher" flips the script where you get to play as the James Bond of the game world.  RPGs shouldn't force you to play as a well defined main character and try and convince you how cool this character is, they should allow you to create your own persona by putting you in a game world and surrounding you with well developed characters that can interact and reflect back your decisions to you in a dynamic and fun way.   The Witcher doesn't do this at all.

Look at BG3, the popularity of the game is surrounding the supporting characters where the main character you play as is a blank slate.  That's how these games are supposed to be.  That's what makes it "role playing" and what makes your decisions matter.  

I think this game is as popular as it is, is that there are a lot of people that think that playing as "James Bond" is cool, and it was also the last major game of this kind before the greed of the AAA industry created a bunch of even much worse games that perhaps hit its nadir with Diablo IV.  We can only hope.

Masterpiece, not only because of all the technical aspects -that are brilliant-, the world building is perfect. The setting, based on the books, is rich and varied, but always rooted in reality; it not a high fantasy realm but a medieval-like eastern European grey place, one of those where shiny places really shine, dark places are really dark and everything has an emotional connection with the lore, the story and the plot. There is no other open-world game that unites such fantastic visuals and world design with the game mechanics. However, the strongest point of the game is that it has some of the best writing in game history -some of the most emotionally involving stories you'll experience in a videogame. I totally recommend this long, complex, bast and beautiful game.

As much as I love Cyberpunk 2077, this one isn't for me. The world is full of stuff but sadly I don't feel engaged. 

But don't get me wrong. This is a very well made game with a lot of heart and soul and from all three Witcher games definitly the best.

This game is quite long and may require a lot of time to complete The beginning of the game may feel slow and uneventful but it is essential to pay attention to the dialogues and storyline to understand the events that unfold later Skipping the dialogues may result in missing important plot points and making the game less enjoyable

The combat in the game can become monotonous as it mostly involves pressing the square button However the game includes a card game called Gwent which is a game within the game and is a lot of fun Gwent is a strategic card game that requires players to build their decks and each card has a unique ability that can be used to outsmart the opponent.

In my opinion Gwent is the highlight of the game and more enjoyable than the game itself It is a great way to take a break from the main story and challenge your mind with a different type of gameplay So, if you're looking for something to break the monotony of the game and have some fun give Gwent a try!

Probably the best game to be made last generation without a doubt. Incredible story and characters. Nothing will immerse you like this game with its hundreds of hours of content and missions. The Witcher 3:  Wildly Overrated

It's a decent open-world RPG.  I played a lot of this game closer to when it came out on PS4, and the PC version is better to the point of feeling like a remaster at times.  Even so, it crashes a lot, bugs out a lot, and the combat is a lot less polished than you'd want from such a combat-heavy game.  By "it crashes a lot,"  I mean it crashes much more frequently than any other game I have ever played on PC.

If you're just looking to dust off a game that you played years ago on console, you know what you're getting into, and I think this will scratch that itch and then some.  If you're looking for a genre-defining open-world fantasy RPG, [i]I guess[/i] this is probably that, but I don't know if that's actually a good thing.

One thing that I can say for sure is that it's a million times better than Cyberpunk.

I have tried to give this game a chance several times on multiple platforms. I always come to the same conclusion. It is simply the most overrated game of all time. Combat is uninspired. They just threw every mechanic possible into it for a game of this style and didnt polish a single one of them. This game is supposed to look amazing not only for 2015 but even now but its not AMAZING. Its simply was just pretty good for its time. Not saying its bad just not exceptional for the time like people say. Another thing that I have seen praise for are the facial animations. Once again im rating this as if it is 2015. They are just good nothing special they look like any other game at the time. The story pulled me in at the start but sadly did not refresh this feeling quick enough for me as it was the only thing keeping me on the game. What reason would I have to play a game where the combat is generic and not interesting and the story isn't captivating consistently enough? that's right none at all.

The Witcher 3 is a game that I originally picked up to "scratch my itch" of Dragon Age. However, after diving into the lore of the video game and seeing the masterpiece that CDPR created here, I found myself reading the novels, watching the show (God bless...), and watching more YouTube videos than you can count. The Witcher 3 is not a game. It is an artistic masterpiece that, as consumers, we are blessed to be able to interact with. It's like watching a book unfold before your very eyes. Fortunately, through my first playthrough, I received the "good ending." Without spoiling anything, I'd just like to commend CDPR for their storytelling here. There were highs and lows throughout, amazing subplots, and even the secondary missions and Witcher Contracts feel fulfilling and tell a story. I've finally completed the base-game, and so I felt it was time to write a review. 

There will never be a game quite like this. Many will try to replicate it, but nothing will ever come close. You're going to read plenty of reviews that say "my first time in Ard Skellige was breathtaking," or "I'lll never forget the sheer beauty of Toissant," and you're going to think the reviewers are just blowing smoke. I'm here to tell you that they are not. Especially with the current state of the game (4.04), this is a masterpiece--graphically, audibly, and gameplay-wise. I urge you to pick this game up. Don't wait for a sale, and don't try something else. I promise you this is THE GAME. The beginning is a little slow, and you'll come across a plot line with a guy named "The Bloody Baron" that seems to drag a little bit, but please trust me when I tell you it is all worth it. Dive into the lore, read all the notes you come across, and check things out as you play. Take your time. Go explore areas you haven't seen yet. Learn about the characters. Check the bestiary and character catalog. There is so much thought and love put into this game. I'm forever grateful for what CDPR has done for The Witcher franchise with this game. 

Play this game. I promise after the time it takes to complete the story and countless hours you'll spend diving into the lore, The Witcher 3 will create an itch only scratchable by this game. Trust me: you'll eventually find yourself writing a novel in the review section for it.

Sometimes you wish you could re-experience the first time you played a game.

I definitely recommend it and please buy the DLCs, they are just perfect.

The Wolven Storm

These scars long have yearned for your tender caress
To bind our fortunes, damn what the stars own
Rend my heart open, then your love profess
A winding, weaving fate to which we both atone

You flee my dream come the morning
Your scent - berries tart, lilac sweet
To dream of raven locks entwisted, stormy
Of violet eyes, glistening as you weep

The wolf I will follow into the storm
To find your heart, its passion displaced
By ire ever growing, hardening into stone
Amidst the cold to hold you in a heated embrace

You flee my dream come the morning
Your scent - berries tart, lilac sweet
To dream of raven locks entwisted, stormy
Of violet eyes, glistening as you weep

I know not if fate would have us live as one
Or if by love's blind chance we've been bound
The wish I whispered, when it all began
Did it forge a love you might never have found?

Best game out there. If you are looking for something like fallout then this will scratch that itch with a different style entirely. Very well done story. Have been playing this game since it came out and its still my favorite.

Let me just start by saying that Witcher 3 is an amazing game and both DLCs are even better. Main story and side quests are immersive. Witcher contracts are always fun, no matter how many times I do them. World is massive (for its year) and feels alive. Music fits the climate very well. The only problem this game has is the combat.

If you are playing on the normal difficulty combat will be reduced to left click spam + Igni/Quen. With the exception of a few boss encounters all fights can be completed with eyes closed. No need to use oils, potions, dodges etc. This problem is fixed if you play on the highest difficulty (for like 10h, because after that you learn how to play game properly). Then all the previously pointless mechanics start to matter. However even then combat has problems. It's simple (fast/heavy attack, 5 signs, bombs, parry, dodge, roll) and is wonky at times. Heavy attacks feel useless compared to fast attacks. Hit-boxes are weird at times and you can get hit by an attack that clearly didn't even touch you. That being said combat is still enjoyable provided you chose a difficulty that actually requires you to do anything.

To sum up, the game is amazing, but I wish all the difficulties were scaled up so "Story and Swords!" would require you to actually use all the game mechanics and I would like "Death March!" to be challenging for longer than 10h, because in all honestly the hardest fight was a random pack of wolves.

Ok game on death march difficulty with controller.

Pros:

+ Good graphics
+ Riding around on you horse in the big world feels great a few hours
+ Good voice acting
+ Some tough fights that are really fun if you play on death march and are a bit underleveled

Cons:

- No mechanical depth to combat, most systems can be ignored, just dodge and hit them on the head
- Crafting system is absurd (for example you combine leather straps into a full piece of leather, should be other way around...)
- GUI is primarily for console so it feels like Skyrim, playing a bad port of a console game
- Leveled loot is boring. You switch gear almost every level which means you never get attached to your gear (also absurd that a better sword should be harder to use...)
- The game world itself is boring, if want to take a walk in the fields i can just go out my RL door.
- Everything tries to be so gritty. Instead it feels like a parody.

[h1]  [b] "Evil Is Evil. Lesser, Greater, Middling, Makes No Difference. The Degree Is Arbitrary, The Definitions Blurred. If I'm To Choose Between One Evil And Another, I'd Rather Not Choose At All."[/b] [/h1]
[b] This quote is the perfect synopsis for the moral ambiguity and atmosphere of Geralt's life and world. [/b]
Naturally, as every review is subjective this review will be void of almost all objectivity as this is not a mere game and it should not be reviewed as such due to the virtuosity of the devs.
CDPR has succeeded in not only creating the best video game of all time serving as a role model that has changed future games from other developers for the better, but also making it transcend into a living piece of art and milestone in several categories.
There is no greater value for your money on steam.
The choices matter branches are so vast that people are discovering new scenarios till this day! [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_UwerUx8bGApFn_oIAuilw] Refer to xLetalis on Youtube [/url]. CDPR should award this Youtuber with a Kaer Morhen PhD.
This acknowledgement needs to be superseded by compliments to the author Andrzej Sapkowski as there would be no Geralt, Yen, Ciri, Triss, Vesemir or drowners in Velen to kill without him.
[h1] Being a Witcher is like feeling unwelcome and antagonized wherever you go... [/h1]
This feeling is mostly omnipresent except for that heartwarming moment in the tavern with Zoltan listening to Priscilla sing the Wolven Storm accompanied by her lute.

[h1]  May a chant encapsulate a person? It can certainly try to conjure up several mirrors...Lilac and Goose(bump)berries it is...  [/h1]

[h1]  CD Projekt Red's Magnum Opus[/h1]
This is the best video game ever made...
... in fact this is not a game, its an artistic masterpiece so beautifully vile, sinister, and morally grey as life is. 
The malevolence one encounters in the Witcher III  is dreadful and monstrous, whereas the love and empathy one can  come across on Geralt's journeys can be truly heart-warming and invigorating.
This is all up to you and your choices.

[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
"Feel any better?"
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
"I told you, I'm fine"
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Dont need to play tough for me. That was a hard fight. Maybe not as hard as the last time we fought a djinn, but still...
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
Hhm! No comparison, I'm afraid. Half of Rinde suffered then. Now I'm merely a bit tired...
Thank you for coming, Geralt. I'd have had a much harder time of it on my own.
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Well, I never could say no to you.
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
Mhm...perhaps that will change now.
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Feel anything? That anything's...different?
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
Hmm...I expected...I don't know what I expected actually. A bit of vertigo, perhaps.
I thought...youd'd become a stranger to me...That I'd look at you and not feel a thing...
But it's not like that at all. Nothing's changed.
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Djinn might have cheated us after all.
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
Why?
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Cause I don't feel that anything's changed either.
I love you, Yen.
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
And I love you.
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Ow! What was that?
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
It can't all be sweetness and light.
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
Strange...Done that so many times, but...it felt like our first kiss to me.
[h1] [b] Yen [/b] [/h1]
It was, in a way. Besides...once you say "I love you", a kiss has to taste differently.
[h1] [b] Geralt [/b] [/h1]
What's next? Got any plans?
[h1] [b] Yen [/b][/h1]
That depends on what you mean...We must find Ciri, and then defeat the hunt...But I doubt the world will end if we sit here a while.

[h1] [b] Geralt [/b][/h1]

CONS:

I just got back years after completing Blood And Wine, and this game is still a masterpiece, a must-have experience for anyone who loves the genre.

After over 40 hours (for some reason my total time isn't recording on the game I'm playing) I quit and uninstalled. I did side quests, Witcher quests, gave that up after I got through all the ones in Temeria, focused on the story only, then quit after we had to put on a play.

The game is just... find this person. Find this person, then find this person, find this person and help them find a different person before they help you find the person you're looking for, find this person but you can't find them until you find a different person, but you can't find them until you find yet a different person, and then once you find all the persons you're looking for, you gotta find a different person. When I told Priscilla we needed to find Dudu, she said we had to put on a play to find him. And I had to find Irina, and then from Irina I had to find people to spread the word of the play and then find other people to ush. Ushers, they call 'em.

It basically felt like Fetch Quest: The Game.

I keep coming back to this game because the world is so vibrant and alive, the characters are incredibly well written, the stories are deep, and the music is haunting. The voice acting is superb. It's one of those games that I got the bad ending on the first go around, and immediately had to start over because I was so heartbroken. 11/10 this one is art, boys.

The best part of this game is story. I play many great rich-story games, but none of them can beat Witcher 3. Drama, romance, funny mystrery, thriller, horror, many feelings combine together. Long speaking dialogues and cutscenes.The books and documents in this game are also full of story in it. Every quest even minor ones are filled with great stories, distinguish itself from each others. The choices you choose, the ways you speak or act effect the story line in game a lot. Scenery and music are also wonderful, could make you cry. 

The combat is very good, fun, enjoyable but can't say it's the best one. There are many games I've played better than Witcher 3. I know horse's bugs in this game are hilarious and could be famous meme. No offense but horse riding is suck! The horse get stuck on every thing even the thin air you can't see. Riding is awful give you disadvantage in combats.

This game is NOT SUITABLE for gamers who like GRINDING, killing monsters/enemies, doing same things over and over. Because you level and make money from quests and contracts which have different stories, missions, and things to do. You cannot expect what's gonna happen next. 

The DLCs are pretty big, long and great stories. I feel like I play another big game of Witcher, so I recommend you buy the GOTY edition that including the base game and all DLCs. Worth every cent, penny, baht or whatever your currency is.
 
You can mod in this game, yet I don't reccommend in you first playthrough. You should experience the original of the game before trying anything else. However, it's single player. It's your choices.

After so many hours, so many adventures, so many life lessons.. I wish I had words to describe this game, but I simply don't.
It is definately the best game I've ever played in my life, it's like a work of art that I'm glad I had the chance to experience.
Every place you go feels so alive, the characters are so well written that most of the time I would get completely immersed into the conversations with them.
When you look back at it after doing everything, every single quest, all the expansions, all the places.. You feel something like a good memory from the past, a feeling of nostalgia..
When people say this game is big, it's kinda hard to understand what it means, for some, it's the map, or the number of quests, or even the size of the campaign, but I believe this game is big on what it tried to achieve, on the greatness of the story that it told, the powerful effects of your choices, the felling you have when you discover a new monster and quickly have to adapt to overcome it, the experience you have when picking up a trail, or sailing through the cold oceans of skellige alone..

So many memories, that with words it's simply too hard to explain, memories that I will always hold dear to my heart.

Best game I've ever played honestly. Although I am a little biased since this game holds a lot of nostalgia for me, I can say objectively that this game is top-notch and it's talked about 10 years after its release for a reason.

An amazing story and detailed characters paired with fantastic graphics and audio is what makes this game so immersive and it just keeps pulling you in. As it goes with RPGs like this, some parts are a tad bit slow but it is 100% worth it. It's got an okay replay value since there's a lot of different choices and paths to take, also there's a lot of mods made by community! Aside from main story and a lot of interesting side quests/contracts/exploration there's also a card mini-game Gwent which is a lot of fun when you actually learn how it works, so I recommend doing that throughout the game!

Combat isn't really a strong part of this game although I've enjoyed it. After getting the hang of it, it gets really repetitive and easy (apart from certain bosses) even on the hardest difficulty. Luckily, you can try out a lot of different builds which focus more on different aspects of combat so thats a plus. Also Roach is buggy af but we love her for that!

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is nothing short of a masterpiece, setting a new standard for open-world RPGs. From the moment I stepped into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, I was captivated by the rich, immersive world, the intricate storytelling, and the sheer depth of character development.

Visually stunning, the game's landscapes are breathtaking, from the bustling cities to the hauntingly beautiful Skellige Isles. Every corner of the world is meticulously crafted, creating an atmosphere that draws players into a living, breathing fantasy realm.

The narrative is the true gem of The Witcher 3, weaving a complex and emotionally charged tale. The choices you make have genuine consequences, affecting not only the main storyline but also the fates of the characters you encounter. The moral ambiguity of decision-making adds a layer of realism, forcing players to grapple with the consequences of their actions.

The character development is unparalleled. Geralt is not just a monster slayer; he's a multifaceted individual with a moral compass and personal struggles. The supporting cast is equally well-realized, with each character having their own motivations, flaws, and stories. The dialogue choices feel meaningful, contributing to the immersive storytelling experience.

Combat in The Witcher 3 is a satisfying blend of strategy and skill. The variety of weapons, spells, and potions at Geralt's disposal allows for diverse playstyles. The monsters you face are not just adversaries but living entities with unique behaviors, weaknesses, and lore, making every encounter a thrilling challenge.

Beyond the main quest, the game is filled with side quests that are more than mere distractions; they're mini-epics in their own right. The depth of the world-building is evident in every quest, big or small, creating an expansive and cohesive game world.

While no game is flawless, any shortcomings in The Witcher 3 are overshadowed by its overwhelming strengths. The occasional graphical glitches or minor bugs are forgivable in the grand scope of this gaming masterpiece.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a triumph of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay mechanics. CD Projekt has crafted a game that not only sets the bar for the RPG genre but also stands as a testament to the power of interactive storytelling in the world of gaming. It's not just a game; it's an unforgettable journey that lingers in the mind long after the final credits roll.

Arguably the best game of all time. First play through was mind blowing, thrilling, and emotional. Second play through years later reminded me what makes The Witcher 3 so special. True freedom to explore a vibrant world in your own style and pace. Decisions have true impact and are game-changing. Even better, the game designers did not wave red flags, like most designers do. The smallest of choices can lead to the greatest of consequences, As in life, there is nobody there to make those forks in destiny clear. 

Graphics still hold up, especially with the free next gen update. The graphics aren't appealing just because of fancy atmospheric affects (though you get a bit of the that). It's because of the beauty and detailed cultures in all of the game's locations. Which is to say... this game is was crafted with lots of passion and creativity. It ticks all of the boxes: incredible visuals, strong story, immersive dialogue, quality voice-overs, and great music.

I only wish I could wipe my memory of it and play as though the first time again. What an incredible game.

Years ago, I vowed to stick to familiar gaming franchises, but thankfully, friends persuaded me to venture into new territory with The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. Having missed out on its predecessors initially, I later delved into The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings and eagerly anticipate the remake of the original. 

The Witcher 3 delivers an immersive open-world experience, enriched by a cast of compelling characters reminiscent of the beloved crew from the Mass Effect trilogy. Its standout feature lies in the meticulously crafted side missions and expansions, such as Heart of Stone and Blood & Wine, which captivated me unlike any other game. Each side quest offered a unique blend of excitement and depth, further enhancing the already rich narrative. 

The game‚Äôs dynamic storytelling, influenced by player decisions, sparked lively discussions among friends as we compared our divergent journeys through its world.

I spent almost 80 hours playing this game and the funny thing is I didn't end up finishing it. 

This review comes from a really wild angle of the entire series as a whole. I tried reading the books, I tried watching the TV show and I tried playing the games. I even bought a poster, a mug and set my backgrounds to as many Witcher themed art as I could find. 

There was a time I really loved this game, I didn't even want to play multiplayer games at one point, I would even schedule it in my calendar and plan what I would do next in the game. I would even light my room a certain way and my desk when playing. 

But then it updated into some new update which made the game different in the bad way, the Netflix show got bad, the books storytelling and endless lore got confusing, the DLC was prolonging the game into infinity and I just fell out of love with it. 

Suddenly I was apart of a lot of Witcher fans who were like "What happened to this franchise?" it kind of spread thin and started to become milked for what it's not...another Lord of the Rings. Not only that the update made the game unplayable and I ended up losing a lot of progress that I didn't feel like redoing. 

My Recommendation: Play the game with out the DLC and play it on a quality that your PC can handle. Don't dilly dally in the game and just keep it moving at a quicker pace. Don't try and 100% the game because it will become a tad repetitive and you'll lose the great story that is within the game. Don't fall into what the Witcher brand is wildly changing into.

One day I will re download this game and finish it, but right now I understand it's a masterpiece, I just got caught up the hype of it all and it ruined it a bit for me. If that's what you are afraid of... don't download the DLC and just play the straight forward story line and stay away from the new wave of the Witcher series. That's what made it what it is known for not what it isn't anymore.

I've played 353 hours of this game, yet I am giving it a negative review.

The combat, which the game wants to revolve around for some reason, is down horrendous. Deathmarch, which I alway play on because I'm stupid, is essentially just enemies with more hp and dmg, nothing creative. A boss fight at this difficulty takes a little bit of time, the whole time you are not having fun, you are just waiting to dodge and to hit, that's it. 

Also how can the game still have so many bugs and issues? It's been a decade. I just played the wraith fight from Heart and Stone and you Projekt Red still haven't made it so Geralt targets the paintings, essentially just giving you a RNG factor to how long the boss fight lasts. I know guys who have spent entire SEASONS in that room with that wraith. I hate how this game thinks longer boss fights is more fun, NOBODY is playing your game for the combat, buddy, YOU ARE NOT THAT GAME. 

In all honesty though, the game plus all the DLCs are worth around maybe 6-7 dollars, but the game is expecting way too much thinking it's worth more than 10 dollars. YOU ARE NOT THAT GAME!

Gripping story, interesting characters, satisfying game play. Gorgeous music and environments.

This game is nothing short of a masterpiece! The world you step into is vast, highly detailed and simply breathtaking. Every little nook and cranny have their part to play to make this a truly immersive experience. The attention to detail in the games design, from bustling cities to the tranquil countryside, is a feast for the eyes. Almost every house is fleshed out and not some empty or locked up set piece. Character models are intricately designed, and the monsters you encounter are both terrifying and awe-inspiring. The graphics, even years after the games release, continue to stand the test of time.

The storytelling in The Witcher 3 and its DLC's are among the best narratives out there. Filled with complex characters, choices that makes you question morality and each dialogue or action have their consequences that shapes your tale. Every corner of the map is teeming with quests, mysteries, and hidden treasures. The side quests are not distractions but are tied to the main story, offering players a chance to explore the depths of the world and its lore. Whether you're hunting mythical creatures or solving mysteries, every quest feels meaningful and contributes to the overall story of the game.

The combat system is both challenging, fun and really satisfying. Movements and fighting feels so fluid with a big variety of combat styles to suit everyone, from sword fighting, spells, ranged and potions allowing players to really strategize. It's a perfect balance between accessibility for newcomers and complexity for seasoned players.

The sound design and music is something truly special and deserve a big praise! The music is especially haunting combined with the atmospheric sounds and have a huge emotional impact on every moment.
