Love: AMAZING open world, epic quests, monster hunting and monster lore, insane graphics, fully voice acted, great in game animations, fun combat

Hate: A dense story that's difficult for newcomers to follow without referencing Google/YouTube, cheesy acting, random sex scenes (the whole game is sexually charged for no reason), and a protagonist / love interests that I personally have never been invested in.

Side note. I hope Witcher 4 allows for character creation because I love the Witcher universe but have no attachment to Geralt.

In an industry often besieged by formulaic sequels and uninspired narratives, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a towering testament to the power of immersive storytelling in the gaming world. CD Projekt Red's magnum opus isn't merely another entry in a popular franchise; it's an expansive, deeply engrossing journey that defies the constraints of its genre, weaving a complex narrative tapestry that resonates long after the final credits roll.
At the heart of The Witcher 3 lies a narrative so intricately woven that it transcends the boundaries of video game storytelling. This isn't your typical hero's journey; it's a deeply human exploration of complex moral dilemmas, political intrigue, and the blurred lines between good and evil. The game's masterful storytelling allows players to navigate morally ambiguous choices, presenting a nuanced world where every decision has far-reaching consequences, making it one of the most captivating and intellectually stimulating narratives in modern gaming.
The game's meticulously crafted open world of Temeria is a visual and atmospheric marvel. From the sun-drenched fields of Velen to the hauntingly beautiful Skellige Isles, each locale is painstakingly detailed, brimming with life, and steeped in rich lore. The depth of the world-building is nothing short of remarkable, immersing players in a living, breathing realm where every corner tells a story and every character carries a weight that goes beyond their scripted lines.
Moreover, the expansion packs, "Hearts of Stone" and "Blood and Wine," aren't mere cash-grabbing add-ons, but full-fledged narratives that rival the main game in both scope and emotional depth. They seamlessly integrate with the base game, offering new lands to explore, characters to meet, and stories to unravel, demonstrating a level of care and dedication to storytelling that is rare in the industry. CD Projekt Red's commitment to delivering substantial, story-driven content without compromising the game's artistic integrity is a testament to their respect for the player's experience and a stark contrast to the predatory practices seen in contemporary gaming.
Despite its occasional technical shortcomings, such as minor glitches and performance issues, The Witcher 3's ambition and attention to detail far outweigh its flaws. It demands patience and investment, rewarding players with a deeply satisfying and emotionally resonant experience that lingers long after the controller is set down. It's a game that transcends mere entertainment, leaving an indelible mark on the player's psyche and challenging the very notion of what a video game can achieve in terms of narrative complexity and emotional depth.
Furthermore, The Witcher 3's evocative musical score, composed by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz, with contributions from renowned folk band Percival Schuttenbach, serves as a powerful emotional undercurrent, enhancing the game's already immersive world. The haunting melodies and rousing anthems underscore pivotal moments in the narrative, evoking a range of emotions that further cement the game's ability to resonate on a deeply personal level. The synergy between the game's visuals, narrative, and musical score creates an atmospheric symphony that transports players into the heart of the Witcher universe.
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a seminal achievement in the realm of video game storytelling, offering a profoundly human and thought-provoking experience that elevates the medium to the realm of high art. It's not just a game; it's a transformative journey that reminds us of the power of interactive storytelling and the potential of the medium to provoke introspection and emotional resonance. For anyone seeking an unforgettable and deeply immersive narrative experience, The Witcher 3 is an absolute must-play that stands as a landmark in the evolution of video game storytelling.

Best RPG of all time. Insanely well made main story and side quests, with two DLCs worth tens of hours of content each. The graphics hold up so well that the game looks better than some of the major RPGs that came out this year and the music creates a really one of a kind atmosphere that makes you want to come back for more and more. The progression system is well thought out - as complex or simple as you want it to be, allowing different types of builds despite the fact that you only really use two swords. There are a few annoyances throughout the game, such as the massive spike in fall damage, but these can be easily negated with the help of mods. The open-world is the best ever made. You can feel the fantasy atmosphere through the monitor. Despite the game not following the books written by Sapkowski, the lore is really true to the one established in them. What are you waiting for? Go buy it now!

Final Score: 10/10

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - Where Monsters Haunt, Romance is Rocky, and Gwent Makes You Forget About Both (a Witcher of Words Review)
Geralt of Rivia, ladies and gentlemen ‚Äì the ultimate monster slayer, ladies' man (sometimes), and champion of gwent. This ain't your fairy-tale fairytale. Welcome to The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, where the sun shines brighter than Yennefer's smile, the bogs are deeper than Geralt's gruffness, and the choices you make leave scars more permanent than a drowners' bite.

Story? Twisted enough to make a wraith blush. Politics thicker than pea soup, family drama spicier than Novigrad sausage, and a main quest that takes more turns than a kikimore on roller skates. You'll hunt beasties from folklore nightmares, negotiate with sorceresses sharp enough to cut diamonds, and make choices that'll leave you questioning your humanity faster than a succubus can say "free drinks." And the characters? Well, they're as messed up and magnificent as a cursed witcher with a drinking problem. You've got Ciri, Geralt's adopted daughter and living plot twist, Dandelion, the bard whose lute skills are only matched by his knack for trouble, and Zoltan, the dwarf whose love for ale is only surpassed by his loyalty. You'll love them, hate them, and swear under your breath at their stubbornness (especially Geralt and his gwent addiction).

Gameplay? A griffin's nest of options, deeper than a drowner's den. Swordplay that feels smoother than a witcher's oiled muscles, alchemy that lets you mix bombs like a potions professor on vodka, and signs that make you feel like a mage with a bad attitude (and a knack for electrocuting drowners). You'll explore vast landscapes that beg to be plundered, uncover side quests hidden in every nook and cranny, and maybe even find a love interest or two (just don't get your hopes up, Geralt's track record is... complicated). And then there's gwent. The card game so addictive it should be illegal (and probably is in Nilfgaard). You'll spend hours collecting cards, strategizing decks, and trash-talking opponents like a pro. Seriously, this game can steal your life faster than a pack of feral dogs with a taste for bards.

The world? Breathtaking, even with the stench of troll vomit. From sun-drenched vineyards to misty swamps, war-torn cities to ancient elven ruins, Night City has nothing on Velen and its friends. Every corner whispers a story, every abandoned shack hides a secret, and every tavern bustles with rumors and questionable characters (Geralt fits right in). You'll spend hours just wandering, soaking in the atmosphere, and maybe accidentally picking a fight with a group of bandits (whoops, sorry not sorry).

So, perfect? Nah, choom. Bugs the size of a wyvern, combat that can be clunky as a rusted blade, and a story that sometimes gets bogged down (pun intended) in side quests. But here's the truth: The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece. It's a world so alive you can practically smell the roasted boar and hear the lute strings twanging. It's a story so gripping you'll forget to eat, sleep, or shower (maybe not shower, that's just gross). It's a game that makes you laugh, cry, rage-quit, and come crawling back for more. So grab your steel sword, pack your gwent deck, and dive into The Witcher 3. Just remember, in this monster-infested world, the only guarantee is a good story (and probably a few accidental drownings).

P.S. Special thanks to my trusty AI co-pilot, Bard. They may not know how to fight a griffin, but their knowledge of Witcher lore is deeper than the ocean a siren calls you to. Plus, they kept me from writing the entire review in Elvish (no one wants that headache). So yeah, give that AI some love too. Maybe a few extra crowns or a shiny new algorithm upgrade. They deserve it.

Now go forth, slay some monsters, win some gwent, and try not to get eaten by a drowners' nest.

Sincerely,

[h1]9/10[/h1]
This has been my third playthrough, but the first time I tried the next-gen patch and also the DLCs for the first time. Surprisingly, I found myself enjoying the game even more than before, spending considerably more time on the main game than before.

Storywise, it's great, up until somewhere around the halfway point of the final act. The storytelling is nearly unparalleled, with occasional drags, but given the scale, they're forgivable. Even the less exciting parts are still impressive when compared to other games.

However, the halfway point of the third act is a bit of a letdown. It feels rushed, lacking the time needed to appreciate the culmination of the chase. The urgency of the Wild Hunt chasing doesn't fully compensate, as Geralt's interaction with Ciri is limited from the player's perspective.

While there are other aspects I'd like to delve into, such as the romance options feeling somewhat shallow, I'll refrain.

Gameplay-wise, I was a bit less captivated compared to previous playthroughs. I went for a New Game + on Death March, adding some much needed challenge. The core combat didn't grip me as before, but I kept it interesting by going with the Feline Armor, making almost anything oneshot me. Despite claims about combat lacking depth, I found it satisfying due to impressive sound and visual effects.

Visually, it's stunning, and the next-gen patch significantly enhances the game's atmosphere. Unfortunately, I couldn't run it with RTX on, dropping the frames too low for my liking. Audio-wise, it's great, though I'll leave the detailed assessment to those more versed in the subject.

[h2]DLC's[/h2]
Now then the DLC's or rather expansions in this case. I was blown away by them to say the least. 

"Hearts of Stone" has secured a spot as one of my favorite, if not the favorite, DLCs of all time. The story is enthralling, delving deeper than the base game and prompting more questions about characters. It's gripping and exceptionally well-crafted. The gameplay takes daring and interesting turns, introducing experimental set pieces that challenge players to think and act differently. This departure from the main game's formula was immensely enjoyable.

"Blood and Wine" is also excellent but falls slightly short of the previous one, at least for me. The story and new characters are enjoyable, yet it lacks the experimental feel of "Hearts of Stone" that I grew fond of. However, it compensates by offering an expansive new map with stunning environments that exude atmosphere. The inclusion of new enemy types and encounter scenarios on the map adds a refreshing layer. The bandit forts with numerous adversaries were particularly enjoyable to conquer.


[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Overall, I still find immense joy in this game. I believe that anyone with even a passing fondness for open-world games or RPGs should experience the entirety of this game at least once.

Imagine you're working in a 9-5 corporate job, you're done with your work, you come back home, log onto Steam, see your games list for 5 seconds, buy a game on sale that you're never going to play and then switch off your PC and go to a bar. While having a drink, you think of the good times when games used to be fun and authentic. But then you tell yourself, the problem isn't the games, its you. "Its not that games aren't fun anymore, you have gotten older".

And then I play Witcher 3. And suddenly I can't wait to get myself home after work. Do you have any idea how precious that feeling is ? The feeling that you are actually immersed in the protagonist' shoes. I find myself in anticipation and excitement for the new adventures that are waiting for me, I think while driving back home...."Where is this story headed ? What new places and characters I will meet ?" And lets not talk about the characters. I thought myself as a guy who's dead on the inside and somehow these characters made me laugh, chuckle and empathise at the same time. I haven't felt these feelings for a game since 2008 when I played games such as Final Fantasy 12, Metal Gear Solid 3. Was I wrong to think that I was the problem and not the gaming industry that's shelling out mediocre AAA games with no memorable characters or storyline ?

And I got this game for 3$. 3$ !! And that includes the DLC ! I honestly feel I looted these amazing devs. And I paid twice for games that are not even worth playing. 23 hours in and I still haven't scratched the surface of the story. The side quests are actually fun. I find myself doing the side quests more because its feels like I am watching another episode of the "Witcher 3 TV show". I love this open world, I actually take my time wandering around and exploring every nook and cranny. I haven't done this since GTA San Andreas. I look at some distant island or mountain that I find interesting and I decide to just walk there just for the fun of it. That's how beautiful this Open World this. This is Open World game done right.

Thank you CD Projekt Red. You guys are a gem. I know its 5 years late and I don't know why it took me 5 years to play this, but better late than never.
Easily one of the best RPGs of all time. Deserved Game of the Decade.

The world of the Witcher 3 is so poetically written.

Andrzej Sapkowski did a masterful job at telling the story of Geralt across all of his novels, and it's clear that CD Projekt Red scrubbed his novels to create the Witcher 3 in such a lore accurate manner.

It's beautiful from start to finish. Upon beating the base game for the second time (this time across a 46 episode series on my YouTube channel, and on Death March + Enemy Upscaling) I found myself in so much happiness that the epic conclusion had been met, I got the ending I wanted, everyone lived a happy life, but I also found myself sad that it was over now.. not fully though because I can still play HoS and B&W for a second time.

This game is not just a game. It's a story written over the course of 6 years.

Thank you for this absolute gem of a world, Mr. Sapkowski!

Thank you for this incredibly lore accurate game, CDPR!

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a testament to the heights that video games can achieve in terms of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay. Developed by CD Projekt, this action role-playing game (RPG) was released in 2015 and quickly earned critical acclaim for its expansive open-world, compelling characters, and mature narrative. In this review, we delve into the various aspects that make The Witcher 3 a masterpiece in the gaming industry.

World-Building and Exploration:

The world of The Witcher 3 is a vast and breathtaking landscape, meticulously crafted to immerse players in the rich lore of Andrzej Sapkowski's novels. The Northern Realms and the Skellige Isles are sprawling territories, each teeming with diverse ecosystems, cities, and hidden treasures. From the bustling streets of Novigrad to the untamed wilderness of Velen, the game's world is not merely a backdrop but a living, breathing entity that reacts to the player's choices.

Exploration is a key element of The Witcher 3, encouraging players to venture off the beaten path to discover hidden caves, abandoned villages, and mysterious landmarks. Every nook and cranny holds a story or a challenge, rewarding the curious with both tangible rewards and a deeper understanding of the game's lore.

Graphics and Visual Design:

The graphical prowess of The Witcher 3 was groundbreaking upon its release, and it still holds up remarkably well. The attention to detail in character models, environments, and weather effects contributes to the game's immersive atmosphere. Whether riding through a dense forest shrouded in fog or engaging in a swordfight under the moonlight, the game consistently delivers stunning visuals that enhance the overall experience.

Character Design and Development:

At the heart of The Witcher 3 is Geralt of Rivia, a monster hunter with a stoic demeanor. However, it is the supporting cast that truly elevates the narrative. Characters like Yennefer, Triss Merigold, and Ciri are masterfully developed, each with their own motivations, flaws, and moral dilemmas. The game presents a morally gray world where choices have consequences, and alliances are forged and broken based on the player's decisions.

Geralt himself is a complex protagonist, grappling with his own identity, morality, and the burdens of his profession. The writing and voice acting, particularly by Doug Cockle as Geralt, breathe life into the characters, making them memorable and emotionally resonant.

Narrative and Quest Design:

The narrative of The Witcher 3 is a mature and engaging saga that weaves political intrigue, personal drama, and supernatural elements into a cohesive and compelling storyline. The main questline, centered around the search for Ciri, is complemented by a myriad of side quests that are often as rich and meaningful as the main story.

Quest design is a standout feature, with choices that genuinely impact the narrative and the fates of characters. The moral ambiguity of decisions adds depth to the storytelling, challenging players to consider the consequences of their actions. The Bloody Baron questline, in particular, is often cited as a shining example of the game's ability to tackle complex and emotional themes.

Gameplay Mechanics and Combat:

The Witcher 3 strikes a delicate balance between action and role-playing elements. The combat system is fluid and responsive, requiring strategic thinking and mastery of Geralt's diverse set of combat skills. The use of signs, potions, and Witcher senses adds depth to encounters, allowing for a variety of playstyles.

The alchemy and crafting systems are robust, giving players the ability to enhance their weapons, brew potions, and craft armor. The economy is well-balanced, making each decision to spend resources a meaningful choice.

Conclusion:

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a monumental achievement in the realm of video games. Its captivating narrative, memorable characters, and expansive world make it a timeless classic. CD Projekt's commitment to quality is evident in every aspect of the game, creating an experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. The Witcher 3 stands not only as a benchmark for RPGs but as a masterpiece that will be remembered for years to come.

This is, hands down, the best game I have ever played.

The character writing, the music, the story, it all caught me in a way no other game has ever managed to. Interactions like the pseudo-quest about Lena in White Orchard are things that are wont really affect your gameplay itself much, but it makes the world feel much more alive. There was no reason to help her, the game didnt tell you to help her, but maybe you still wanted to try, so you did, and the game rewarded you with an extra cutscene or two with a bittersweet ending for this little irrelevant plotline in classic The Witcher fashion. 

A lot of decisions in this game are incredibly hard to make, since this game's philosophy is a lot about having to choose between two evils, where you have to decide for yourselfwhich is the lesser one. Random sidequests will put you infront of decisions that will probably require you to take a step back for a minute and think which option is for the greater good.  

Sure there is some spots where its age is showing in the current day, but if you're willing to look past that, I promise you, this is one of the best games you will ever play

I had always known I would play this game, but didn't get around it until 7 years after its release date for various reasons. Even though this is version 1.35, it is still littered with bugs that really detract from the gaming experience. It doesn't feel like it is an acceptable quality for a newly released game, much less one that has been available for 7 years. (Which, after discovering this is the same company that released Cyberpunk, made a lot of sense.) A game with an "overwhelmingly positive" rating deserves to have it offset for that reason. 

That said, I would recommend anyone that has any inkling for RPGs should absolutely play this. The writing and voice acting is some of the best out there. The world is engrossing when you aren't working around bugs. The loot and crafting are time-wasters that don't add any value, but if you don't let yourself get consumed by those you'll enjoy a dense narrative and experience that is possibly unmatched in gaming.

1. Gather your material. You will need:
    - 1 Kilogram of coca leaves.
    - 1 Gallon of kerosene.
    - 1 Gallon of acetone
    - A large pot
    - A trainer
    - A glass of baking dish
    - A spoon
    - A coffee filter
    - A rubber band
2. Prepare your workspace. Make sure you are working in a well-ventilated area. Cover your work surface with newspaper or plastic.
3. Dry the coca leaves. Spread the coca leaves out on a flat surface and let them dry in the sun for several days.
4. Crush the coca leaves. Once the coca leaves are dry, crush them into a fine powder.
5. Mix the cola leaf powder with the kerosene. Add the coca leaf powder to a large pot and cover it with kerosene.
6. Stir the mixture until the coca leaf powder is completely dissolved.
7. Add the sulfuric acid to the mixture. Slowly add the sulfuric acid to the kerosene coca leaf powder mixture and stir the mixture constantly.
8. Let the mixture sit for 24 hours.
9. Filter the mixture through a strainer and strain the mixture through a strain.

This game feels like it's really good, story rich with an interesting world that has been given a lot of love. It is detailed and complex, lots of interesting characters and areas and monsters.

There's something off though, I just can't get into this game...

I know that's a terrible reason, but that has been my experience. I want to like it, and it really seems like something I should love! Every time I play I just feel so... meh.

The only thing that really stands out to me is how clunky the combat felt. Almost like a console game lazily ported to the PC. I don't think that's why I dislike the game though, as I've enjoyed some really clunky stuff in the past.

Objectively I see that this game is amazing in scope, story, and diversity of content. I think they definitely deserve the love and money they have received. Objectively, I recommend the game.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game personally... and I wish I had a more specific reason than "dunno... didn't like it" but... I don't.

100/10. Cannot believe I have waited this long to touch this game. I have never wanted a game not to end so badly. The DLCs are a work of art with as much thought and time put into the original game. Main story line complete and I do not plan on putting it down any time soon. Racked up nearly 200 hours in less than 2 months.

In the years since the release of Witcher 3, its still one of the greatest rpg games yet. This one does so many damn things right! First off, the animation and art design are stunning. Next, you get a sneak peak into the fluidity of in-game melee combat. And last but not the least, you get a laconic understanding of Geralt as a character and the type of moral choices you'll encounter within the game. This game is masterpiece.

As someone who really did not love either of the previous Witcher installments, I do find Witcher III very compelling.  I am guessing I have played roughly a quarter of the main story, and I find myself completely engrossed with both the main story line, which I will not divulge, but especially all the side plots.  Nothing feels forced or unnecessary.  This is what an open world RPM should look and feel like.

I also have to say I mostly disliked how Geralt was depicted in the first two games.  As a veteran that has dealt with people that needed a solid punch in the mush, that was mostly how I felt about Geralt, much too pompous for my tastes.  In Witcher III, he feels much more nuanced in his dialogue and far less of a punk that needs to be taken down a peg.  I did not read the books, and I thus wonder if this is reflective of his development in the source material.  Regardless, liking the main protagonist is a major boon.

I would also like to compliment the combat.  It frankly felt clunky in the previous games.  I absolutely love the combat in this game.  It feels realistic, and I really appreciate the depth of tactics that can be employed.  The games accomplishes this and remains very smooth and fun at the same time.  I really don't mind dying if the combat is engaging and you learn as you play while thoroughly enjoying yourself at the same time.

My final comments are around the mini-game of Gwent.  I utterly despised the dice play and even more so the arm wrestling of Witcher II.  The arm wrestling was some of the most frustrating video game play I have ever experienced, and I won't bother with the details.  Play it for yourself if you are feeling especially like a masochist.  Gwent, on the other hand, is probably my favorite mini-game ever.  At the outset of Witcher III, before I had become engrossed in the story, I was excited just at the prospect of playing more Gwent.

If you are a fan of immersive fantasy RPGs, Witcher III is worthy of all the accolades it has received.  I cannot say the same for many games I will refrain from mentioning.

And the problem with The Witcher 3 is that it's surrounded by mobs that love the game that shame you for not being a good gamer or understanding the game when some of its problems are just there.

I kept installing the game and trying to just understand what everyone liked about it (my friends too) and I kept getting bored out of my mind. The world wasn't interesting enough for me to explore and when in an open world game, the world doesn't interest me. I play the main story and guess fucking what? Even if you go only main mission heavy, you get stopped by the game telling you to go do side quests to get enough level to continue playing the main storyline. I think that detracts so much from the story. 

Not only that, but the combat is more tedious than any other RPG that I put in time to; Firstly, sometimes I would just roam around the map and there would be ambushes! That sounds fun, right? No! Because the ambush enemies are level 9 whilst I'm level 6. AND THIS IS THE BEGINNING OF THE GAME! Ok, I cheesed them and then somehow? Killed them. I come across some bandits trying to burn down a woman house, and I'm like ''fuck yeah, I'm going to be a hero' Bam! I get mauled by enemies that are 3‚Äì4 levels higher than me, so I load a quick save and avoid that area entirely. 
 
But to everyone, you just suck at gaming and should go play minecraft. 

And also it's funny how much people give CD Project Red, a bad company with tons of stupid lies in their marketing, can still be so praised.  (Also cyberpunk sucks too)
Really fun, except for some quests in novigrad which were quite slow paced. Hearts of Stone and Blood & Wine were really well done.

If you love video games you should give this game a chance, try to understand why people love it so much, I know that it won't be incredible for everyone at first but you need to insist, the first time I played I didn't liked immediately but I kept playing and eventually couldn't stop anymore. 

Unique game, simple as that.. a incredible project with passion that ended up being a masterpiece, one of the best video games ever made, a mark in the history of game industry, will always be remembered as one of the best games of all time, there is no exaggeration as some people say. I also thought that, before playing again with the next gen update and the dlcs, but it was even better than I remembered, I spent more than 40 hours only in the dlcs, this game has so much content and I didn't even played gwent! 

Awesome characters, difficult choices that matters, combat and horse gameplay not the best but you get used to it..

If you're a fan of open-world fantasy sword-fighting games, The Witcher 3 is an absolute must-play. I truly recommend it.

It stands out as one of the most comprehensive open-world experiences available. Playing it took me back to the days when I immersed myself in the world of Gothic, playing day and night. The Witcher 3 offers a similar captivating experience. I found myself eager to undertake every quest, uncover all the adventures, and explore the mesmerizing world it presents. The game's beauty is truly remarkable. I'm eagerly anticipating more DLCs and, fingers crossed, The Witcher 4.

peak fiction

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

A game which defined a generation, The Witcher 3 manages to mix the core elements of an RPG in a formula so ahead of its time, that pushed many game companies to adopt the same recipe. 

The story is obviously the biggest selling point of the game, with an intricate plot that tackles topics of undying love, bitter revenge and imperfect fatherhood. Those who are fans of the books will be delighted to see some of their favorite characters make a return and to hear about the old adventures of The White Wolf.

Gameplay wise, the game has fluid combat, thanks to Gerald's dance like moves, and rewards fast engagements. As for the world, there are many activities to enjoy, from memorable beast hunts, to crafting monster killing gear or taking part in the incredibly addicting Gwent card game, there is a lot to do.

Finally, do buy the DLCs as they are practically two entire games which conclude the story harmoniously. Masterpiece.

Witcher 3 has been an extremely liberating, engrossing, and thoroughly enjoyable game, and for the offer prices it goes for, it becomes really hard to make a case against it. So as belies any already well reviewed game, I'll briefly make the case for it in my own way.

The story- for both the main game and the 2 fantastic DLC's- Hearts of Stone, Blood and Wine, are stellar, consistent, and MOSTLY well paced. This also brings me to my first complaint- the game just speeds up rapidly after you find Ciri and the rest of the game...just...happens in a flash. I do not like how I found Ciri when I was 50h in, and the main story was over by the 60th hour. That being said, the narrative was placed rather well, albeit feeling a bit rushed sometimes. The choices in the story do have an impact on how the world sees you, and I do appreciate that.

The graphics- they dont look too bad, and I'd argue they MIGHT hold their own in 2023, it's a really good looking world. 

The combat- I dont dislike it inherently, it's fluid, smooth and all, but there's just some things that make no sense- like the way my movement is locked in to rolls and dodges, unable to jump or sprint unless I kill all enemies or roll tf away from the vicinity, both of which will cause issues in the succession questline in Skellige- because fucking harpies and all just love flying and fucking around and more often than not you fall to your death trying to evade. I believe everyone should be able to get out of the combat state once the weapons are withdrawn. Also the crossbow power discrepancy underwater vs above ground is borderline stupid!

The sound design- It's done well. It's atmospheric, and it sounds well, combat engagement themes are good. 

The map- It's...somewhat good- but I do wish my barber marker didnt disappear off the map unless i was close to one. 

The level design- Overall, all in all, mostly good. There can be some bad, and some really poorly designed levels that dissociate with whatever logic the buildup had, but most levels, the vast majority are well designed. 

The performance and stability- Awful. I've not had a game crash more than Witcher 3 in my whole life. As of review time, I can assure you atleast an hour was lost from random crashes in the inventory or loading screens, and a further hour caused by the progress lost during the abrupt crashes. It's not a very well performing game but it's not bad either in sheer performance outfit. What is awful though is the stability. Also microstutters really apparent, albeit very, very rarely. Infinite loading screens are a thing somehow in this game. It is also extremely buggy, that is not expected of a game thats been updated since 2015. Roach keeps clipping onto shit, sometimes Geralt freezes in the game, unable to move when I rapidly tab in and out of the photo utility. 


I do appreciate the game a lot, those were a fun 83 hours, but I wish it were more stable as an experience, because it does pull it out of the game. With that, I'd argue a 9/10 is well deserved, for a game as complete as an experience, minus the baffling number of bugs.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is easily one of my favourite games of all time. It is quite simply pure mastery of game design, with ultra-satisfying combat, an absolutely stunning world to explore, riveting lore quests and mythical beasts and monsters to discover, and one of the most epic stories ever put to video games in my 25+ years of gaming. 

I first owned this game when it released on PS4. The only major gripe I had with the game at the time were the absurdly long loading times (which became a pain if you died in the game). That being said, the game had me hooked and I was more than happy to repurchase the game again for PC and up the graphical HP of this game to new heights (and experience much better loading times). At that time, I had a GTX 1080Ti, which played the game wonderfully at 2K maxed out. 

This game does a tremendous job at completely immersing you in the world it creates. It's a game I can get lost in for hours and always find something even nearly 9 years later. Sure, the NPC character models can look a little funny as there are only a handful of NPC model designs created and re-used with different hair styles, eye colours and so on; and the way the characters stand or react when in a conversation can look a tad bit stiff; but other than that...the game holds up extremely well and is still plenty of fun, which is the most important thing.

The game also looks absolutely gorgeous, and it certainly helps now that there has been a remastered job done on the game with much higher resolution textures, better framerates and the introduction of Ray Tracing. All of this and more included in the remaster takes the game to an even higher level. On PS5, this game runs incredibly well at Performance Mode with a very stable 60FPS and some incredible retexturing. On my latest PC rig, with an RTX 4090, this game is insanely beautiful. 

If there is one thing I have noticed, however, is that even though the game can be run at native 4K at Ultra Settings, there is a lot of grain and noise in very kinetic assets such as foliage, trees and even Geralt's armour when he moves around. Apparently, this has something to do with the textures being at a much higher resolution and not entirely optimized that well for Native 4K. Either TAAU or DLSS seems to fix the issue, but it is a shame this hasn't been fully addressed yet, because the game can run perfectly well on Native. It's almost like the remaster is expected to be run with either TAAU or DLSS and Native was slightly overlooked. Just something to keep in mind. For now, until this issue is addressed and patched, some form of upscaling is expected to make sure the game runs with no sign of any visual artifacting. 

Nonetheless, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a timeless epic and is well worth full price even today.

Ah yes, the masterpiece of RPGs in every aspect.
What was it that I liked? A compelling story with easily perceivable influence on the world. Fantastic characters, each memorable and incredibly played out. Newly-introduced character progression system where you can get your build at level 25 and complete it at level 30-34. Incredible breathtaking locations with just the right amount of bloom and colour range. Most places have really good soundtracks.

But all of this is figured out already. Now after things one can find not as attractive.
Firstly, some of the quests behave unexpectedly, almost randomly. The "Lord of Undvik" quest - you can complete it without ever getting a quest marker or anything at all. The quest with the Novigrad serial killer - to avoid spoilers, let's just say you figure out who it is and yet you can get a forced ending on the quest upon a really minor dialogue option. Skellige has this weird quest where you deal with the werewolf for good and yet a certain friend of Ciri goes to fight him... what?

Now, locations. Why would the devs allow 60% of landmass be unplayable is beyond me. Using NVIDIA GeForce camera you can travel for minutes past the playable territory and encounter places you can't ever see from the playable zone. Why include them at all? No wonder things get hairy as far as performance goes. And the game would be at least 10Gb lighter without them. Sure, you might say "Who cares, it's to make the world pretty and seamless". Yes, I can somewhat get it with White Orchard or with Velen. But why leave so many islands in Skellige entirely empty? I counted at least a dozen. Surely, a monster nest and a guarded treasure on each would be more interesting than those half a hundred contraband markers. Then, some of the locations serve only for one quest or one point in the game. And it's fine of course, but... why would they do this to a major in-game location and territory which feels empty after main quest? Not to mention there is only one short soundtrack which is on an infinite loop. And this leads us to the next problem.

Something I found irritating is how almost all important NPCs disappear from the game once you are done with them. You are thus left alone in a world full of meaningless background characters with no way to chat with some of your friends. Why opt for this instead of leaving them be and writing maybe 5 minutes of lines for them? Does not seem too much after all the grandeur of the main questline.

At last, a minor detail. Why in the world would you do in-game gear sets if you can enjoy their set bonuses only by the end of the second DLC? Seriously though, why? I looked forward to having gear from a certain witcher school, only to again and again realise it is inferior in everything to regular yellow or orange armour. After finally getting the set bonus I only got around 2 hours of gameplay and it was criminally not enough time to enjoy it.

All in all, a legendary game, although it might not seem as much after you penetrate the veil of nostalgia surrounding it.

I have given The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt SEVERAL honest attempts over the years, and my experience with it has been the same every time: I've enjoyed the game until a combat sequence happens. I don't care if the developers were trying to be cinematic, lore-accurate, whatever... Wild Hunt's combat is atrociously convoluted and tedious. It's not an issue of complexity, but of disorganization. There is too much grinding and multitasking involved. I've played games that have found much better solutions for handling nuanced combat systems, and there are a lot of things Wild Hunt could have done much better than it did in this regard. Furthermore, as if all that isn't bad enough, Wild Hunt's combat animations themselves also work against the player. When performing melee attacks, Geralt acrobatically throws himself at the enemy. This is very problematic against groups of enemies because the player cannot maintain a strategic position. I really don't know how players enjoy the combat in this game, I can't help but wonder if they've just never played anything better.

the witcher 3: wild hunt, developed and published by cd projekt red, is a magnum opus in the open-world rpg genre. embarking on this journey, whether you're approaching it as a completionist like i did or not, is a exhilarating and deeply rewarding experience. from the moment you step into the vast and meticulously crafted world of the witcher series, you'll be captivated by its stunning visuals and attention to detail. the landscapes, character models, and ambient effects create a visually immersive environment that seamlessly blends realism with the fantastical elements of the witcher universe.

the narrative is a masterclass in storytelling, weaving a complex and morally gray tale that keeps players engaged from start to finish. every side quest, dialogue choice, and character interaction added layers to the overarching story. the choices made throughout the game have far-reaching consequences, ensuring that every decision feels weighty and impactful. honestly the sheer volume of quests can feel daunting at times. i want to assure you that literally every single questline is crafted with the upmost care and attention to detail. exploring every nook and cranny of the vast open world brought a sense of discovery and anticipation. uncovering hidden treasures, solving mysteries, and completing contracts for the various monster slaying i did kept the gameplay fresh and engaging.

geralt, the protagonist, is a complex and well-written character, maybe one of the best of all time. the relationships he forms with other characters, both major and minor, evolve dynamically based on player choices. completing character-specific quests and delving into their backgrounds adds depth to the overall experience, making the characters feel like real individuals with their own motivations and struggles. again, i can't overstate how truly epic and masterfully this is all done. 

gwent, the in-game tcg, is a delightful addition that can become something of a mini-obsession for 100% completionists. collecting every gwent card is almost enough for it's own game entirely, as you have to win tournaments, challenge characters with powerful decks, and manage to find every single card in the game. it's an amazing distraction from the main game and side stuff, which while great in their own rights, can benefit from diversions from time to time. the strategic depth of gwent itself as a trading card game is surprisingly addictive and complements the overall gaming experience.

despite the game's massive scale and expansive scope, the technical performance is remarkedly stable. the witcher 3 sets a benchmark for technical excellence, paired with the attention to detail in animation, voice acting, and sound design, contributes to a immersive atmosphere that elevated the player experience. in conclusion, this is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of what most people know as convention gaming. this is a truly unparalleled journey filled with challenges, choices, and rewards. the dedication to exploring every facet of the game is met with an abundance of content that consistently maintains a high standard of quality. the witcher 3 is not just a game, it's an epic adventure that sets a new standard for storytelling and world-building in the gaming industry.

This game is amazing!!! Such a good value with the DLC included as well. I am currently working through blood and wine and that expansion is absolutely huge! I am a big fan of Gwent too, especially as a big time TCG player. It's nice to see a badass witcher killing things and then goes to a bar to play his favorite TCG in his spare time. Really enjoying this game. I haven't played any of the previous Witcher games, nor watched the series, so wasn't sure what to expect, other than it contained magic & a more open world. 2 things I really enjoyed. Alongside this, Fallout & Cyberpunk 2077 are 2 of my favourite games - The latter of which is also developed by the CD Project Red team, so I thought I'd give this a go.
At this stage, I've spent around 30 hours in game so far & must admit I was a bit flummoxed by the skill tree to begin with, but seem to have gotten the hang of it now. The game controls are easy enough to get the hang of, (I classify myself as a gamer, with 1,000's of hours invested, but I believe even someone new to gaming would find the control system easy enough to use!). I'm also very much enjoying the story lines & learning more about all of the mythology. There's a lot of information out there in the world to find, if you're willing to search! I'd definitely recommend this game to others, especially if you enjoy story driven games with a bit of sarcasm, that make you think!

"Winds Howling"

I'm sure you've heard all the praise one could hear for this game, but yes, it is quite good. The visuals and atmosphere stand out as exemplary. You feel truly immersed in the world from the 1st hour up until the 100th.
The combat can become somewhat repetitive, but there's so much in terms of player progression, varied loot and new, interesting biomes to explore, that it's not at all an issue. And, though not quite required, if you do decide to jump into all the aspects of combat given (potions, signs, etc.), there's plenty to keep any strategic mind occupied for a good minute.
To praise the characters a bit more, you really do care when even a side-quest requires parting with a known face, or even decide on a particularly important bit of their life. Those side-quests can also become part of the main experience, if you let them. They colour in the emptier bits of the map, and add for interesting background, head cannon even, when running through the main arc.
The one bit that I'll nag on is, oddly, the story. Though the individual adventures are great, I feel the overarching story is rather bland. What's worse, it starts to make less and less sense towards the end. Not to spoil anything, of course, but characters towards the end start acting irrational, not as they have through the rest of the game. This starts to show towards the very end, as the game starts dragging on, seemingly pushing for more bosses and further epic battles, effectively disregarding the ones that just occurred. And the characters seem to act for the benefit of pushing further into the fray, going for more epic-ness, instead of their regular logic.

Don't let that last bit distract you, though - this is a fantastic experience that enjoyed through and through. You do need to have an interest in these types of games (RPGs, I suppose?), as it's a long one. But if you enjoy the first 5 hours, you'll enjoy the rest just as much.

A masterpiece of a game, and the main reason being is that you'll be hard pressed to find another game with this many high quality side quests and characters that are incredibly memorable. Each one feels like an engaging experience and unique in its own way, and not just busy work or boring fetch quests. You actually feel like this is a real world with real people, and not just another game to blow through for dopamine hits.

The world is huge and detailed and there's always someone or something to find around the next bend. You'll never be quite sure how you're going to shape it depending on your choices either. This huge world is full of monsters that want to kill you, and each have their own strengths and weaknesses that really feel rewarding when you play to them.

It may take a few hours to really get into it, but once the world opens up and you really start to get it, you'll wonder why you didn't play it sooner.

Back then when I was at high school this is the most expensive game that I bought with my allowance yet after hundreds of hours of immersion I had in this game it really feels like I still owe some more money to CD PROJEKT RED for this masterpiece that other companies would have priced even higher. Every aspect of this RPG game works in harmony, the decision making works well and some of them have an effect later in the game but the real deal is what choice you will make as most of the choices are not black and white (good and bad) most of them are grey choices that will test your morals. potions, oils and decoctions that you make can save you in dire situations and once utilized properly can help fight high level monsters at the hardest difficulty (Death March). The in-game growth of beard and the durability system for swords and armors makes your game play more realistic. Lastly there's also an addictive mini game called Gwent, a card game that involves in-game characters so you are playing a game within a game but you probably know it by now since Gwent memes became a popular gaming meme on the internet. These are the features that I've cherry-picked from the game and there are still a lot more features but with that being said if you like Role-playing then this game is a must have. I hope that there will be more games to be developed in the future that can cope up to the standards and high quality that The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt offers to the table.

TL:DR This is not just a game, this is an art and a true Masterpiece at that.

Many times I find myself wondering if I'm playing the main quest because of how good and detailed some of the side quests are, it is mind blowing. You find a random guy on the side of the road and you end up on a 2 hours journey killing beasts and discovering secrets.

The game captures a very dark theme but it also has just the perfect amount of funny into it. Some of the lines said by npcs or Geralt himself are just pure gold.

Without wanting to spoil, at one point you go back to Kaer Morhen and before going to bed, you have the option to spend a night with the boys and drink up. Please do me a favour and do not go to bed, you have to continue de scene until the end, it is extremely funny and I promise you will laugh alone in front of your screen, I commend CDPR for this scene, pure comedy.

If you're looking for a nice world to get lost in, please buy The Witcher 3. The first 3-4 hours are kinda slow but after that it is constant engagement and fun.

I played the game all the way through 4 times on console.  I messed my save up and am done with this play through, however, TW3 is absolutely one of the best games ever made and I'm sure I'll be giving the game another go before the year's end. Also, Shani is better than Yen and Triss combined. 

Edit: Got the game working again that same day. Very happy about that. If you haven't bought TW3 yet, buy it. If you haven't played TW3 yet, play it. Unlike Bethesda games, you don't HAVE to play with mods to have an enjoyable experience, however I highly recommend dipping your toes into the modding scene. This game is fantastic. There are a few issues but the good stuff just overshadows the bad for me.

[b] Good[/b]

+ Very good story and characters with many interesting choices, events, and dialogue. 
+ The world is vast and detailed, and full of stuff to do.
+ Great sidequests.
+ Many cool armor sets and weapons that you can craft or find in the world.
+ Graphics are still gorgeous, even more so with raytracing.
+ The DLC is the best content the game has to offer. Especially Blood and Wine which is essentially an entire new game. 
+ Mostly a bug free experience.


[b] Bad [/b]

- The beginning area of the game, White Orchard, was very slow and uninteresting. I almost dropped the game, but it gets much better once you reach the main overworld.
- Movement is pretty atrocious. Controlling Geralt feels like driving an old muscle car. Trying to move anywhere other than a straight line will result in him crashing into anything and everything. The horse controls are also completely terrible. 
- Combat is honestly kinda clunky. Its not terrible by any means, but it feels pretty heavy and imprecise. Blade oils are tedious until you figure out the auto oil setting exists. 
- I didn't like the skill tree. It takes forever to get points, and most of the early and mid skills feel pretty meaningless. If you dont grind levels, you will only start unlocking interesting skills near the end of the game which kinda sucks. 
- This might be a skill issue but the game is pretty bad at telling you things. For example, I didn't use the potion system until the midgame when I realized they are not consumables and are replenished for free. A lot of the early game (White Orchard) was spend stumbling around kinda having no idea what is happening. I also did not play Witcher 1 or 2, so it took a little bit to figure out who everyone was (Dont let that stop you from playing Witcher 3 tho).


Overall = 9/10, excellent experience
Might take a a little to get into but once you do its worth it.  Definitely play with a Bluetooth controller (Xbox).

Really stretches the RPG part of being an RPG as you can only play as Geralt who I personally find unlikable and you only get one play style which I also personally find unlikable (though you can kinda change it but not really). With exceptionally syrupy and unresponsive melee controls and 5 spells that amount to the bear minimum of "having magic." You also basically can't do anything at all with any of the unnamed NPCs besides look at them and hear two lines of repeated dialogue and you can't really be evil at all outside of a few officially sanctioned choices because it's "not in Geralt's character" meanwhile Geralt's character has actual lore to explain why it is so generic. Playing Geralt is the worst of both worlds, he's too generic to be an interesting character and too much of a character to let you do what you want. The narrative (aside from Geralt) and how pretty the environment is are basically the only two parts that are good which almost makes me wish it was a TV show... well ok they ruined that. At least there's YouTube videos compiling the cutscenes into a "movie" which would probably be a more entertaining experience than actually playing the game because none of the game part of it is really any good. Skyrim has a great degree of interactivity in exploration and the sandbox. Games like The Outer Worlds and Baldur's Gate 3 have a great degree of interactivity in how you role play. Even CDPR's own Cyberpunk 2077 strikes a pretty good balance between those things. The Witcher 3, sadly, is a game that would otherwise be a wonderful extremely long version of a telltale game if it didn't have sticky, unfun melee combat and convoluted, boring potion making stapled on.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a towering masterpiece within the realm of role-playing games, transcending its genre to deliver an unparalleled gaming experience. From the moment I stepped into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia in this third installment, I was captivated by the sheer brilliance that unfolded across every facet of the game.

The gameplay, a seamless blend of fluid combat mechanics and intricate decision-making using the Witcher signs, immerses players into a dynamic and ever-evolving world. The responsive controls and strategic depth of combat provide a visceral experience, making each encounter a thrilling challenge. The open-world exploration is a testament to the game's meticulous design, with every nook and cranny brimming with life and detail.

The narrative woven throughout The Witcher 3 is a masterclass in storytelling, intertwining complex character arcs with a rich, mature narrative. Geralt's journey to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, is an emotional rollercoaster, filled with moral ambiguity, political intrigue, and personal sacrifice. The characters themselves are crafted with such depth and authenticity that they breathe life into the narrative, creating an emotional resonance that lingers long after the game is turned off.

And also worldbuilding in The Witcher 3 is nothing short of awe-inspiring. The vast open world of the Continent is a living, breathing entity, teeming with diverse landscapes, bustling cities, and hidden secrets. The attention to detail, from the architecture of Novigrad to the untamed beauty of Skellige, is nothing short of breathtaking. Every corner of the world tells a story, and the lore is so richly textured that it enriches the overall experience, creating a sense of immersion that is second to none.

Accompanying this visual feast is the beautiful musical score, composed by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz. The music is a symphony of emotions, perfectly complementing the game's atmosphere and heightening the impact of key moments. From the melancholic tunes that accompany Geralt's introspective moments to the adrenaline-pumping combat themes, the soundtrack is a crucial element that elevates the overall experience to new heights. Making it one of the best Videogame Soundtracks to ever be created.

The Hearts of Stone DLC and Blood and Wine expansion are not mere add-ons; they are vibrant extensions of an already remarkable universe. Weaving captivating storys that serve as a fitting epilogue to Geralt's journey. 

(Only time will tell what and who the next Witcher game will be about).

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's an experience that set the standard for what an RPG can achieve. Its seamless integration of gameplay, narrative, worldbuilding, and music creates an immersive experience that lingers in the heart of every player, cementing The Witcher 3 as a timeless classic that will be remembered for generations to come.

The Witcher 3 is the best game I have ever played. In fact, it's not a game, it's life. I have lived in this world as Geralt. Everything around me was alive. I am not a person who can be easily convinced. But The Witcher 3 has earned it. And trust me when I say they have earned it as I have played almost every Single Player RPG title there is, both linear and open world. But The Witcher 3 has redefined what open world video game means and many open world game developers have followed their footsteps. It has changed the way video games work forever and went beyond.

The attention to detail in the world is phenomenal. The breathtaking story of this game offers choices that you can make will directly impact the entire story, the characters and the world around you. Not many games actually do it, much as they'd claim.

The characters are unforgettable and feels so personal, with a gaming map so big, yet so dense and interactive, makes it a truly successful quantity with quality open world game. It has cleverly managed the skill and alchemy system.

And in the Blood & Wine DLC they welcomed us with a new character mutagen system which is awesome. The two story expansion DLCs which are by the way, widely considered as the best DLCs in the history of DLCs, are so massive and rich that they could have been easily two separate random masterpiece games themselves.

It's too much content for a single game and we certainly do not deserve a game this good for a price of a single game. Yet, here it is, right in front of you to explore. Play it, cherish it, love it or hate it while you still can, while you are still alive! Thank you CDPR, for everything. What a journey it was!

[b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt weaves a narrative that leaves an indelible mark on the psyche, with landscapes and artistry reflective of the finest out there. Regrettably, the combat aspect falls short of expectations, and the horse-riding mechanics are lamentable. Nevertheless, I unequivocally recommend this game and advocate for its inclusion among the most esteemed titles in any player's collection.[/b]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a true masterpiece in the world of gaming, captivating players with its rich storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and immersive gameplay. As an enthusiast of both IT and mathematics, I appreciate the meticulous attention to detail evident in every aspect of this game.

One of the game's most commendable features is its narrative depth. The storytelling is exceptional, weaving a complex and engaging plot that keeps players on the edge of their seats. The characters are intricately developed, each with their own unique personalities and motivations, adding a layer of realism rarely seen in video games.

From a technical standpoint, The Witcher 3 showcases cutting-edge graphics and a vast open world that beckons exploration. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the stunning landscapes to the intricate design of the creatures that inhabit the game's universe. As someone who appreciates the complexities of IT, I am impressed by the seamless integration of these elements, creating an immersive and visually stunning experience.

The gameplay mechanics are equally noteworthy. The combination of strategic combat, character customization, and a plethora of side quests ensures that players are constantly engaged. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenging encounters and rewarding exploration, making it a joy to play for both casual and hardcore gamers alike.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a triumph in the world of video games. It effortlessly blends a compelling narrative with top-notch technical elements, providing an unforgettable gaming experience. As a fan of both IT and mathematics, I find myself appreciating the intricacies of the game on multiple levels. This is not just a game; it's a work of art.

The Witcher 3 is a gaming masterpiece. I've played through its immersive world and gripping story twice, captivated by its meticulously crafted open world and engaging game-play. Inspired by Andrzej Sapkowski's works, the narrative is rich in moral ambiguity and political intrigue, supported by vivid characters.

The gameplay is equally impressive, featuring impactful combat and intriguing missions. Each decision carries weight, shaping a unique experience with every playthrough.

For those who appreciate a well-executed RPGs, it's a must-play.

If RPG is your cup of tea, you should definitely try it! 10/10!

A Must-Play Epic Adventure!

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt has undoubtedly earned its place as one of the greatest games of all time, and it has effortlessly secured a spot in my personal top ten games list. CD Projekt has crafted a gaming experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional RPGs, delivering an immersive and captivating journey that will stay with me for years to come.

From the moment I stepped into the vast open world of The Witcher 3, I was spellbound by the sheer beauty and attention to detail. The landscapes are breathtaking, ranging from dense forests and bustling cities to eerie swamps and towering mountain ranges. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle contribute to an ever-changing environment that enhances the realism of the game.

What truly sets The Witcher 3 apart, however, is its narrative depth and character development. Geralt of Rivia, the stoic and charismatic protagonist, is expertly portrayed, with nuanced emotions and a compelling personality. The supporting cast is equally well-crafted, each character contributing to a rich and complex tapestry of storytelling. Every decision I made felt impactful, shaping the world and characters around me, leading to multiple branching storylines and endings.

The quest design is nothing short of brilliant, with side quests that are as engaging as the main storyline. Each quest is a mini-epic, filled with moral dilemmas, unexpected twists, and memorable moments. The attention to detail in world-building and lore is astounding, making every corner of the game feel alive with history and intrigue.

The combat system is fluid and responsive, offering a satisfying blend of swordplay, magic, and alchemy. Geralt's abilities can be customized to suit different playstyles, allowing for a tailored experience that keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting. The monsters and creatures you encounter are beautifully designed, each posing a unique challenge that requires strategic thinking and skillful execution.

The Witcher 3's soundtrack deserves special mention, as it masterfully complements the game's atmosphere. The sweeping orchestral pieces and haunting melodies enhance the emotional impact of key moments, drawing players deeper into the world of The Continent.

The game's post-launch support, including the outstanding expansions like Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine, further demonstrates CD Projekt's commitment to delivering exceptional content. These expansions are not mere add-ons but expansive narratives in their own right, offering hours of additional gameplay and enriching the overall experience.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a triumph in every aspect. Its unparalleled combination of stunning visuals, compelling storytelling, and immersive gameplay make it a timeless masterpiece that deserves a place in every gamer's library. If you haven't experienced the epic journey of Geralt of Rivia, do yourself a favor and embark on this unforgettable adventure. The Witcher 3 is not just a game; it's a masterpiece of fantasy gaming that sets a new standard for the genre.

It excels in providing players with a multitude of meaningful choices that significantly impact the game's outcome, all within a richly customizable character.
The game's world is a true marvel, a seamlessly crafted environment teeming with life and untamed wilderness.
My earnest recommendation is this: If you relish a compelling narrative, well-crafted characters, the power of choices that reverberate through the storyline, a fluid and engaging combat system, and the ability to personalize your character's development, then this is an absolute must-play.

The Witcher¬Æ 3: Wild Hunt is a gaming marvel, a sprawling adventure that sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. From the vast landscapes to the intricate storytelling, every aspect of this game is a testament to gaming excellence.

The attention to detail in the world-building is staggering. Each corner of the open world feels meticulously crafted, brimming with life and immersive experiences. The quests are not just quests‚Äîthey're tales woven into the fabric of the world, each with its own unique narrative, characters, and consequences that ripple throughout the game.

Geralt of Rivia is a character for the ages. His depth, complexity, and moral ambiguity make him a captivating protagonist. The choices presented to players are weighty, offering a true sense of agency that impacts the world and its inhabitants. The depth of the storytelling is unmatched, offering multiple storylines that interweave seamlessly.

Combat in The Witcher¬Æ 3 is fluid and engaging, offering a satisfying challenge without feeling overwhelming. The variety of enemies and combat styles keep the gameplay fresh and exciting throughout.

However, what truly sets The Witcher¬Æ 3 apart is its ability to immerse you in its world. The rich lore, compelling characters, and morally ambiguous decisions create an experience that is not just a game‚Äîit's an epic journey.

The game's soundtrack is another jewel in its crown, perfectly complementing the atmosphere and adding emotional depth to every scene.

In conclusion, The Witcher¬Æ 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece, a benchmark in the gaming industry. Its expansive world, gripping storytelling, and unforgettable characters make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast.

One of the best RPGs of all time. It's incredible how CDPR managed to make a game that is so accessible in case of setting, the worldbuilding and atmosphere, yet at the same time being based around Slavic culture which is rather niche in gaming. The main story is amazing, I played the game for the first time before reading any books or playing previous game and it still was totally understandable and really touching. The side quests are probably the standout of it, you can probably count all mindless fetch quests on the fingers of your one palm. I heard some people had issues with the combat and though they aren't made up from nothing, I loved it trough my all near 800 hours counting ps4. Can't forget the DLC which in my opinion are the best in whole industry, the story of Hearts of Stone has so many inspirations and callbacks to different media and still holds up on its own. And Blood and Wine with a total shift in atmosphere and vibe to a vibrant Toussaint that adds even more variety to the playtrough, includes a lot of gameplay changes that expand on already good build creation and a great, satisfying ending to a story that I don't think I'll ever forget.

As of writing this, I consider this the best game ever so far. This game is nothing short of a labor of love. The immense detail in the world and writing. Just look on youtube at how many different variations of scenes there are, how many small conversations that are able to be had depending on your choices. The story is phenomenal and has excellent pacing with characters you care and love for. Not to mention on just how well the game has held up. It's been nearly 10 years since this game came out and the visuals still hold up to this day. Look out of Kaer Morhan... look out in skellige. It's astounding how they have created such an artstyle that still holds up. And then on top of that all, you have possibly two of the best DLC's made. Both expand on gameplay elements, have their own great stories, and one has even a whole new zone. 

Of everything the only thing I have to complain about is the combat, and even then it's not bad. It's fairly repetitive and is only as deep as you make it. You can easily go fully into builds and such but none of that is required to beat the game on any difficulty and you can easily get through it with mashing light attack. The only other minor complaint is the one thing that's not quite held up is the dialouge animations. They are all stiff and some have such piss poor variations (Looking at you every dwarf being crossarmed). 

But none of that matters. If you're looking for a world to sink hours into this is the game for you. If you love RPG's this is the game for you. Even if you don't really like RPG's I say give it a shot, wait for it to go on sale.

The Witcher 3: A Masterpiece Unplayed by My Teen Daughter

The Witcher 3 stands tall among the greatest RPGs ever crafted‚Äîa world teeming with rich lore, morally complex choices, and a protagonist who feels genuinely human in an inhuman world. Yet, my teen daughter, who delves into the realms of Baldur's Gate 3 and Cyberpunk 2077, oddly refuses to grace this masterpiece.

I've tried to convince her, extolling its virtues, the captivating narrative, the beautifully woven quests, and the sheer depth of its characters. Alas, it seems she's carved her own path in the RPG landscape.

Perhaps the allure of The Witcher's fantastical world isn't quite her cup of mead. Or maybe she's holding out for her own personal reasons. As a parent, I can only marvel at the game's brilliance and hope that someday she'll be drawn into Geralt's mesmerizing adventures. Until then, I'll cherish my solo quests in this mesmerizing universe, leaving a spot open for her, should she ever decide to embark on this unforgettable journey.

Being a person that hadn't played the other two Witcher games, the only thing I knew about this was that a lot of people really, really liked it. After putting 101 hours into it, I can say that as well. From my 2023 perspective, this game holds up amazingly well. It doesn't feel outdated to play, the next-gen update makes the game look amazing, and the story and its writing is fantastic as well (though a lot of the lore/story I kinda had to assume because it does draw heavily from the story of the other 2 games). The things I would say I did not like were the fast travel system, the lack of usefulness of many of the game's potions and "skill tree" traits, and of course like any open world game the numerous annoying glitches I encountered. 

I recommend playing the other 2 first, but it isn't 100% necessary to understand who's who or what's going on in a broad sense. The first DLC "Hearts of Stone" is okay, but the second one "Blood and Wine" absolutely blows that out of the water by several degrees, it truly is a fantastic addition to the game. IMPORTANT: Play the latter DLC AFTER the game's main story is done, as it heavily over-levels you and makes the ending sequence more trivial and thus less impactful.

All in all, if you like a really good fantasy story, solid 3rd-person melee-magic combat (for its time), and great scenery, I would buy this game plus its two DLCs, or at least the second one.

[h1]Scootaloo's Epic Tale: Review of "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt"[/h1]

Greetings, fellow gamers and inhabitants of the mystical lands! I am Scootaloo, a 19-year-old school-age Pegasus pony hailing from the icy world of HowlStrom. As a fervent gamer who has journeyed through many virtual realms, I bring you my in-depth and dramatic review of "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt," a game that has captivated my spirit and challenged my wits.

[h2]Embarking on the Journey[/h2]
In "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt," developed by CD PROJEKT RED, I stepped into the boots of Geralt of Rivia, a monster-slaying mercenary. The game's vast, war-torn, and monster-infested world reminded me of the harsh, unyielding landscapes of HowlStrom, where survival is a daily struggle.

[h3]Gameplay: A Symphony of Sword and Sorcery[/h3]
The Witcher 3's gameplay is a masterful blend of open-world exploration, intense combat, and deep storytelling. As I navigated through this rich and complex world, I felt a kinship with Geralt, a character as multifaceted and resilient as the Pegasus ponies of HowlStrom.

[i]Combat and Exploration[/i]: The game's combat system is both brutal and balletic, a dance of death that demands skill and strategy. Exploring the expansive world, from the rustic villages to the majestic mountains, was akin to soaring over the frosty peaks of HowlStrom, feeling the icy wind beneath my wings.

[i]Story and Characters[/i]: The narrative is a tapestry woven with intrigue, emotion, and the struggles of its characters. Geralt's quest to find Ciri, the child of prophecy, is fraught with moral dilemmas and heart-wrenching choices, mirroring the epic tales told in the halls of HowlStrom.

[h3]Visual and Audio Splendor[/h3]
The game's visuals are a feast for the eyes, with breathtaking landscapes and meticulously detailed characters. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, composed by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz and Mikolai Stroinski, resonates with the soulful melodies sung during the long nights in HowlStrom.

[h3]Evaluating The Witcher 3[/h3]
As I traversed the perilous world of The Witcher 3, I was struck by the game's profound impact on me. It's a rare gem that transcends the medium, becoming a part of one's very essence, much like the ancient magic that flows through HowlStrom.

[b]Strengths[/b]:
- Engrossing narrative that captivates the heart
- Exhilarating combat that challenges the mind
- A vast world rich in lore and beauty
- Deeply complex characters, each with their own story

[b]Weaknesses[/b]:
- Occasional technical glitches that break immersion
- Some quests can feel overwhelming in their complexity

[h3]Scootaloo's Final Verdict[/h3]
"The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is not just a game; it's an odyssey of the heart and soul. Its impact on me is as profound as the ancient legends of HowlStrom.

[b]Rating[/b]: [i]9.5 out of 10 HowlStrom Stars[/i]

In conclusion, "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is a masterpiece that every gamer should experience. It is a journey that will stay with you long after you've set down your controller, much like the eternal winters of HowlStrom.

[hr][/hr]
