If you like medieval RPGs this is definitely a must play.  If you liked Skyrim then you will really like this game.  The attention to detail and actual consequences for your quest choices (and 15 different endings I hear) as well as difficult morally grey decisions make it an immersive world that will pull you in and make you think about every choice.  Combat takes a bit of getting used to as its all third person if you are used to first person games but take the first map and quests slow and you will get used to it after a few hours.  Best option seems to me to play in story mode first and then come back to do the hard mode challenge for the achievement (that's my plan anyway :)  

If you get the next gen update things look amazing so don't let the 2015 release date dissuade you.  Had to turn settings down a bit for stable FPS on my older rig but it still looks amazing.

Will probably come back and try the first 2 in the series after I finish this one.

DO however take the rating seriously on this one - there are a LOT of dark subjects taken on in this game so definitely NOT for under 18

Great graphics playing on the next gen version. Sometimes I find myself just riding around enjoying the scenery. The story and world design is among the best Ive ever seen in a game. There are a multitude of different varied enemies all with their own weaknesses and strategies and their own backstories. The characters are written very well and are relatable, I often felt bad for some of the more unfortunate characters. The different "rituals" that Geralt uses to defeat the various monsters are very interesting and feel like they have been inspired by real world legends/traditions. 

My only complaints of this game is that sometimes the controls can feel clunky, especially during combat. For example you have to wait for Geralt to finish his attack animation before opening your tool menu and it can get annoying at times. Also the dodging and rolling can use some refinement. Sometimes when fighting multiple enemies I would take damage from a melee attack when it was clearly a miss. Some monsters can just instantly attack you with little to no telegraphing and break your combo. 

Overall however I would still give this game a solid 8/10 and would consider it a must play for anyone that likes fantasy games or rpgs.

[b]Cons[/b]
- Fairly low consequences for death

I recommend this game to everyone! [i]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/i] has an engaging story in a beautiful open world and gives you the freedom to make impactful decisions in both combat and dialogue.

What can I say about The Witcher 3 that hasn't already been said?

Well, now It's the perfect time to play if you haven't yet. It's basically finished in terms of all the DLC and updates. You can play it now and have the full complete experience - and it's awesome. Grab it on sale and don't skimp on the DLC, it's fantastic.

Next up, they're working on releasing serious mod tooling which will probably be released next year. In a few years you can come back to it and hopefully have some excellent community created content to explore.

That's not to say there isn't mods you can use right now, mostly smaller quality of life stuff. Check the Nexus and look for mods that have been updated sometime since July, 2023 or later. Those are most likely to work with the current version of the game. They might mention Next-Gen in the title or description.

Have fun!

I will now proceed to tell you random tips and tricks I wish I knew when I started playing:
[list]
[*] Don't sell your Witcher Gear, that's the green colored items that come from various Witcher schools. They can later be upgraded into some of the best armor in the game. Put them in your stash if you don't need them right now.
[*] When you get too close to the edge of the world it'll open the map, you can then fast travel anywhere or close the map to be put near where you were but pointed in the right direction.
[*] Stuff sells for more if you're talking to the vendor that specializes in that item.
[*] When you're getting attacked underwater you can use your crossbow and kill them in one shot.
[*] When you're just starting out loot and sell everything for cash.
[*] If you hold your crossbow button you can manually aim, but if you just tap it it'll autoaim. Manually aimed headshots do more damage.
[*] You might get a bad ending if you romance both love interests. 
[*] Buy recipes from the shops.
[*] Play Gwent, it's fun and addictive.
[*] If you want to collect all the Gwent cards then play everyone right away, you might not get a chance to later as the story progresses.
[*] Summon your horse faster by looking in the opposite direction you want him to spawn.
[*] Use Quen and when you get damaged back up and use it again.
[*] Read, or at least open all the books and notes and then sell them.
[*] It's not like other games where you craft potions, use them and craft more, rather your potions will be replenished for free when you use the meditate function.
[*] If you want to hunt animals for food, you can just run into them with your horse and they'll die.
[*] You can loot a monster nest after you blow it up!
[*] You'll obtain a lot of useless currency that you can exchange into real money at Vivaldi‚Äôs Bank in Novigrad.
[*] If you find a "Place of Power" use it to get a buff, and also an ability point the first time you use it.
[*] Don't worry about how you spec your character at first. You can use a "Potion of Clearance" to respec your character later.
[*] You can steal stuff, just run away from the guards and they'll forget about you.
[*] Use Axii on a wild horse and it'll be yours to ride.
[*] If you're in a boat you can fast travel to docks.
[*] Save early, save often.
[*] Buy every gwent card you see from shops.
[*] When you're unlocking skills with ability points, you need to equip that ability by dragging it over to the open slots on the right or it won't do anything for you.
[/list]

My time in the game says 93 hours but I probably put at least 200+ when I had the game on xbox. On both steam and xbox I have every achievement and have played through the game 7 times. To be honest those are rookie numbers, but I think it speaks to how good the game is. Gwent is more addicting than fisstech. The next gen update makes an already beautiful game even more so. The world is immersive and fun to explore. The characters are intriguing. The choices are engaging, difficult, and sometimes haunting. The world feels alive and you feel apart of the world rather than some omnipotent god changing everything to your will. The combat is fun and makes you want to learn more things to unlock more options to change your experience. My favorite part of the game are the monster hunts, you do feel like a witcher with a contract to complete some of them. And last but definitely not least the baron quest line will break your heart no matter what you choose, but my god is it worth it.

One of the many games where you will avoid fast travelling at every expense and will actually take time to traverse through the nooks and crannies of the map, even the little ones.

Took forever (literally several years and three attempts at buying the game) to get into the game. But once it clicked: it became a whole week or more of hyper-fixated gaming!

There's action, exploration, mystery/puzzle solving and investigation, and a wonderfully interesting world that is similar enough to our own to make it realistic but enough fantasy elements for it to be a world completely of its own. While there are areas that show the games age or moments where the mechanics/gameplay suffer from "genre staples" this game is absolutely worth it especially if you catch it on sale which I have seen many times in the last few months.

Just don't let the White Orchard/tutorial area deter you if you are a fantasy or open world fanatic.
i have slept with everyone

The only thing i'm mad about is not getting into this game sooner. I,like many people,was scared off by the daunting amount of potions,oils,weapons, and expansive bestiary. All that combined with the vastness of the open world and combat that takes some getting used to, this was a game I kept trying and giving up a couple hours in. Then I started to read the books and was hooked. I got mad that I couldn't experience this world for myself cause I sucked at the game. I just said fuck it and put my head down and really gave this game another run. Now almost 80hrs in and I can safely say it is one of my favorite games of all time. Instead of fighting it, I really made an effort to learn all the ins and outs of this amazing game and accepted that it is just a part of the process. The amount of choices you make that actually affect the outcome of the game is mind blowing. The main story is truly amazing and has such good arcs and pacing. That combined with the amount of witcher contracts and side missions really immerse you in the world and make is feel alive. The amazing cast of friends and foes with such amazing voice work and choices to make just add to that immersion. The combat is amazing and it is so rewarding when you finally slay that beast using all your specific tools, oils, and potions to defeat. I can say without a doubt if you were like me and are mad this game has never clicked for you, just say fuck it and put your head down and really give it a try. If you get about 9 or 10 hours in and it still hasn't done it for you then my condolences, I do pity you. 9.5/10 final score and I will have 200+ hours bet on that shit

Being an RPG, the choices it gives you and how they affect the gameplay are amazing, for a fact if you choose not to kill a monster you might even see it around (friendly) roaming in a couple of in-game days. The opposite might happen if you choose to kill it, and you may get the message in the form of a letter telling you its backstory. The point is that the depths this game has is amazing. I would recommend any newcomer to try out the trilogy. IT'S WORTH A 1000 TIMES !!!!!!!!!!

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a magnum opus in the realm of role-playing games, delivering an unparalleled gaming experience that transcends its genre. Developed by CD Projekt Red, this masterpiece is a testament to the studio's commitment to storytelling, world-building, and player immersion.

From the moment you step into the vast and meticulously crafted world of The Witcher 3, you are engulfed in a rich narrative that weaves together political intrigue, moral ambiguity, and personal quests. As Geralt of Rivia, the titular Witcher, players embark on an emotional and thrilling journey to find Geralt's adopted daughter, Ciri, pursued by the mysterious and otherworldly Wild Hunt.

The game's narrative prowess is only matched by its breathtaking open-world design. The Continent, a sprawling land filled with dense forests, bustling cities, and treacherous swamps, feels alive and teeming with stories to uncover. Every nook and cranny is meticulously detailed, creating an immersive environment that encourages exploration and rewards curiosity.

What truly sets The Witcher 3 apart is its morally gray storytelling. Choices matter, and the consequences of your decisions ripple through the narrative, shaping the world and relationships around you. Characters are not simply black or white; they are complex and multifaceted, making every interaction a moral dilemma that leaves a lasting impact on the story.

Combat in The Witcher 3 is both fluid and challenging. Geralt's combat style, a dance of swordplay, magic, and alchemy, is a joy to master. The monster-hunting contracts, epic boss battles, and dynamic encounters keep the gameplay fresh and engaging. The alchemical system, where potions, oils, and bombs play a crucial role, adds depth to the strategic aspect of combat.

The game's audiovisual presentation is a feast for the senses. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack sets the tone for each moment, whether it be an intense battle or a quiet stroll through the wilderness. The attention to detail in character design, animation, and environmental graphics is nothing short of breathtaking, elevating The Witcher 3 to a cinematic experience.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a triumph of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay mechanics. CD Projekt Red has crafted a game that transcends its medium, delivering an emotional and unforgettable experience for players. Whether you're a fan of fantasy, RPGs, or simply exceptional storytelling, The Witcher 3 is a must-play that will leave an indelible mark on your gaming journey.

It was one of my wishes to finish the Witcher 3 before this very year ends, suffice to say my quest finished without much time to spare !

On many fronts, The Witcher 3 shows an incredible care and craftsmanship, given how detailed the world is makes a lot of sense considering this world started to span from the ink of a pen decades ago.

The characters are well written and the amount of voice acting that has been done in multiple languages is truly tremendous.

Personally, the world of The Witcher partially lost me after two dozen hours or so. Simply put the consequences of my choices were very often unclear, situations where they were vague at best became a frustrating occurrence.

The game's mechanics took a big hit due to the length as well for me,  I personally started to get uninterested in combat after my 30 first hours, my perks were pretty much all set and I should have probably changed the difficulty as passionate fans seem to find a high amount of value and strategy in the higher difficulties.

Although this was not one of my personal favorite experiences this is one of those games that deserve to objectively be praised as a masterpiece. I believe that on every front, from artistic direction to pure game design not many miss steps are taken. On top of that the developers added an incredible post launch support that I have rarely seen put into place for a single player only title.

Who knows maybe some year in the future I will attempt a new game + on a higher difficulty haha.

It's impossible for anyone not to recommend this game, and anyone who says otherwise is completely mistaken and has a distorted perspective of a good game.
I say this with all certainty, most of the negative reviews only concern themselves with a single point of the game "the combat" others find the "combat difficult and not noob friendly" which doesn't make sense, because the game's combat is the most simple as it exists.
And I put this in this way because they find the shared analyzes ridiculous, since the games that have come out since the Anthem Syndrome will only come out with poorly made games, without any structure in the story, characters with weak backgrounds and the Witcher not only the game but its entire universe They deserve to be highlighted as excellent games to set an example of a good game or what makes it good.

(History Overall and Characters)
- From start to finish, I'm speechless, every choice you make, good or bad, has an absurd impact on the characters and the ending of the game itself, the Witcher 3 is the continuation of the previous games where it brings back notable characters from past games.
The game manages to convey the same feeling of being present in that world, of actually living the daily life of a witcher and of making tough decisions at critical moments. Only reading lovers could understand this feeling of truly entering this world. 
Only reading lovers will be able to understand this feeling, we end up feeling like we are really inside the story of the characters and the world itself, it's not for nothing that great games end up being based on Books already made.
And despite this, we ended up becoming interested in wanting to know more about the game's world, I was one of the people who fell into Witcher 3, I never got to touch 1 and 2 but I had already seen something, and when it's finished I will definitely give it a leap forward in previous franchises, I don't expect the same level as Witcher 3.

{Combat and Mechanics}
The combat is not very challenging, with just a few hours to minutes you can understand the basic mechanics, which end up being a reason for many to ignore the game, despite this I found the style of combat that the game gives us interesting. The character's movement ends up being buggy and not synchronized with the game's NPCs, often when dodging or attacking an NPC who is in stun, you still take damage even if the enemy NPC is doing an attack animation and it is cancelled.
Even so, I don't find combat boring, I always experiment with ways to try and make it fun, always using combat tactics to simulate that I really am a real witcher.

{Graphics and performance}
The graphics and the world itself are full of details and things to do, compared to some games where they make you walk 500 km to do something and I find it boring, if I walk around the game every now and then there is always some interaction or special event with someone NPC leaving more and more curiosity and desire to explore new rare or unknown interactions.
Performance, although some have reported problems even with PCs at the same level as mine, I have never encountered problems resulting from poor performance, crashes, corrupted saves, etc. 
I even consider Witcher 3 to be an excellent, very well optimized game.

(Side Quests and DLC)
In some games we can consider that the side quests are literally to fill you up and make you waste game time, but in this game all the side quests are for you to do, I believe that the contract missions where you have to kill some monsters are not have so much impact but completing missions will give you the possibility to interact with new characters that can affect the main quest in general. Honestly, I wasn't bored with the side quests, which even surprised me.
The game's expansions are excellent, nothing to criticize them for, and I'm sorry they didn't make an expansion of the Blue Mountains area where at the end of the Bloody Baron's quest he ended up heading off with his wife.

Try the game, stop being silly about the combat, if you think the story is horrible, start considering reading some books and opening your mind on that aspect.

A game worthy of it's praise and high ratings.

The story- enticing, full of life, unexpected events and important details you're allowed to miss.
The characters- indistinguishable from humans, filled with real emotions, attachments to people and ideals.
And you too, will become attached to them; often seconds before you decide their fate; and the direction of the story, as you have a wild variety of options and endings to choose from.

The combat is designed with the players' interest in combat itself. Should you wish to play as realistically as possible, you'll choose the hardest difficulty and approach each encounter with care and preparation (potions and oils pair well with studying the beastiary). 
Should you come here mainly for the story, the easiest difficulty will still make sure you don't feel overpowered and encourage tactics.

The combat may look simple, but there's plenty to learn. Overconfidence may lead you to a quick defeat. Many times, I've thought myself a legendary witcher- only to go  headfirst into a pack of thugs or drowners. An unlucky hit is all you need to get taught a lesson by Dr. Stunlock. 
Dodge for monsters.
Block for humans.
Enter a fist fight championship with a bear. 

And the final praise- you need not grind if you don't want to. <3

*    For everyone that wants to rollback from the pre next gen version to 1.32:
go to the game > properties > beta > select classic branch from the drop down list.


*    Disabling red launcher

1) Rigth click on game in libraty -> properties -> General -> add --launcher-skip to LAUNCH OPTIONS
2) Rigth click on game in libraty -> properties -> Local files -> Browse
3) find file called "launcher-configuration.json"
4) open it with by notepad
5) change line <<"fallback": "DirectX 12">> by <<"fallback": "DirectX 11">>
6) save changes
7) launch game and enjoy game without launcher


Played in GOG first, now on steam, just for the record.

Some tips:

Don't forget to also equip your skills after acquiring them. Skill points can be reset with a Potion of Clearance available from certain merchants for 1,000 crowns each.

Skull-level enemies aren't generally worth the trouble as the reward will likely be unusable or scale to your level anyway.

Don't get too burned out going for every ? on the map, especially in Skellige where many of them are just smuggler's caches located in the sea. On the other hand, not all places of interests are marked with a ?, so explore a bit and keep an eye out for suspicious-looking spots on your map.

Axii works best in dialogue when the target is alone, using it in front of others has higher odds of things going awry. The tier 1 Sign ability Delusion is required to pass higher level Axii checks in dialogue.

Gwent-playing merchants and innkeepers reward you with a card when you beat them for the first time, and many cards can also be bought directly from stores. A man near St. Gregory's Bridge in Novigrad sells a book that lets you keep track of which areas still have Gwent cards to be won.

The contents of read books are stored in your journal, so non-quest books can be sold safely.

There are two "points of no return" in the game, but they are very obviously signposted.

You can loot monster nests after you destroy them.

Make use of the Bestiary to find the best ways to fight each enemy type.

Make heavy use of your Potions, Bombs and Oils as they only need to be crafted once after which strong alcohol items (which are practically infinite) will automatically replenish them when resting.

Decoctions are replenished with Alcohest, though their heavy Toxicity makes them harder to use outside of Alchemy builds.

Getting surrounded will get you killed. Control fights and stay at the edges of them. Two rolls back is a great distance to throw a bomb from, to replenish a sign, to reload your crossbow, etc.

The crossbow will automatically aim towards a targeted enemy even without manual aiming. It's also your only method of slaying enemies underwater.

Hold down the attack button while on horseback to slow down time and make it easier to land hits.

[h1][u]A RPG Milestone[/u][/h1]
Replaying 'The Witcher 3' in August 2021 reaffirmed what I felt during my first playthrough in May 2015: This game is a masterpiece, setting standards for RPGs.

[b][u]Pro:[/u][/b]
+ Exceptional storytelling that sets the bar for narrative excellence.
+ Immersive and meticulously detailed world design.
+ Thoughtfully designed and well-executed gameplay mechanics.
+ Continues to set the gold standard for RPGs, much like 'The Dark Knight' for superhero movies.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
"The Witcher 3" remains an unchallenged [u]MASTERPIECE[/u] in the RPG genre. Its profound impact on storytelling, world-building, and gameplay mechanics continues to define the benchmark for new games.

[b]-- GAMEPLAY --[/b]
The combat in this game is really fun and engaging, thanks to the amount of "tools" and weapons avalible to you, Oils, bombs, potions, crossbows etc. Sadly, as main weapons, the only really good options are the 2 swords, but this is because of the lore and immersion. Armors look good, and there are a lot, suitable for different playstyles.
The crafting system is a bit generic, but perfectly fine and immersive for this game. 
What is annoying here is the constant need to repair your gear, it is just an extra chore, and it does not anything meaningful to the game experience.
The talent system is really simplified, with few actually good options, and even from the unlocked talents, it is limited how many you can set to active, so making unique builds, really going in depth with character customization is missing from this game.
The questing experience is really great, though the investigation part of these is really simplified, so you don't really need to use your brain.
Exploring the world is a really great experience, with lot of stuff to discover, monsters to hunt, treasures, hidden quests to find, making it really rewarding.
[b]10/8[/b]

[b]-- GRAPHICS --[/b]
The world, the characters the monsters all look amazing and the artstyle really fits the dark fantasy of the witcher games.
[b]10/9[/b]

[b]-- SOUNDS --[/b]
The voice acting, the music, the ambient sounds are all a perfect match.
[b]10/10[/b]

[b]-- STORY && CHARACTERS --[/b]
The story continues the previous games, taking your old saves into account. It is a great, immersive story, which can easily pull you in, and make you excited.
The storytelling, the pacing is really great, it is something that hard to achieve.
The complex, interesting characters, elavate the experience, making this, one of the best fantasy stories in video gaming.
[b]10/10[/b]

[b]-- REPLAYABILITY --[/b]
There is new game+, different difficulties, and tons of different choices with different outcomes which can make replaying the game interesting.
[b]10/7[/b]

[b]--TL;DR--[/b]
The Witcher 3 is one of the greatest RPG in video game history, with fun immersive gameplay, a great story and a huge amazing gameworld to explore and lose ourselves in.
[b]10/9[/b]

"Come on, Roach."

Imagine you're working in a 9-5 corporate job, you're done with your work, you come back home, log onto Steam, see your games list for 5 seconds, buy a game on sale that you're never going to play and then switch off your PC and go to a bar. While having a drink, you think of the good times when games used to be fun and authentic. But then you tell yourself, the problem isn't the games, its you. "Its not that games aren't fun anymore, you have gotten older".

And then I play Witcher 3. And suddenly I can't wait to get myself home after work. Do you have any idea how precious that feeling is ? The feeling that you are actually immersed in the protagonist' shoes. I find myself in anticipation and excitement for the new adventures that are waiting for me, I think while driving back home...."Where is this story headed ? What new places and characters I will meet ?" And lets not talk about the characters. I thought myself as a guy who's dead on the inside and somehow these characters made me laugh, chuckle and empathise at the same time. I haven't felt these feelings for a game since 2008 when I played games such as Final Fantasy 12, Metal Gear Solid 3. Was I wrong to think that I was the problem and not the gaming industry that's shelling out mediocre AAA games with no memorable characters or storyline ?

And I got this game for 3$. 3$ !! And that includes the DLC ! I honestly feeling I looted these amazing devs. And I paid twice for games that are not even worth playing. 23 hours in and I still haven't scratched the surface of the story. The side quests are actually fun. I find myself doing the side quests more because its feels like I am watching another episode of the "Witcher 3 TV show". I love this open world, I actually take my time wandering around and exploring every nook and cranny. I haven't done this since GTA San Andreas. I look at some distant island or mountain that I find interesting and I decide to just walk there just for the fun of it. That's how beautiful this Open World this. This is Open World game done right.

Thank you CD Projekt Red. You guys are a gem. I know its 8 years late and I don't know why it took me 8 years to play this, but better late than never. <3

Alright, listen up, future Witcher! If you're ready to be thrown into a world where monsters, magic, and morally gray decisions are the norm, you've hit the jackpot with The Witcher 3.

Dive into The World:
Picture this ‚Äì a massive open world filled with gritty cities, creepy swamps, and lush landscapes. The Witcher universe isn't your typical fantasy setting; it's dark, it's dirty, and it's damn captivating. You're Geralt of Rivia, a stoic and contemplative badass monster hunter with a silver sword and a tongue sharper than the blade. Get ready to navigate political intrigue, tangle with mythical creatures, and make choices that'll haunt you.

The Witcher 3:
Now, let's talk about the game itself. Clocking in at a solid 100+ hours, it's not a sprint; it's a marathon. The main game is a rollercoaster of emotions, and if you throw in the Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine expansions, you've got yourself an RPG feast.

Pros:
1) Epic Storytelling: It's like a Netflix binge but in game form ‚Äì gripping, unpredictable, and addictive.
2) Monsters Galore: Seriously, the creatures you face are nightmare fuel, and it's awesome.
3) Beautiful Chaos: The graphics are a visual treat, and the environments range from hauntingly eerie to jaw-droppingly gorgeous.

Cons:
1) Learning Curve: Don't be surprised if you fumble a bit at the start.
2) Glitches Happen: Every now and then, Geralt might decide to dance instead of fight.

In a nutshell, The Witcher 3 isn't just a game; it's a freakin' experience. Get ready to lose sleep, make questionable choices, and fall in love with a world that's as dangerous as it is beautiful.

Single handedly one of the best, story-driven, immersive RPG's ever developed. My all time favourite game. Every quest has meaning and the highest attention to detail. No filler content whatsoever. Both DLC's feel like they're their own game rather than an add on, with new characters and a meaningful questline. The combat may seem basic and dull for some but those who can immerse themselves in this world will not even notice. This game is definitely not flawless but for me it gets a 10/10. All devs should look up to The Witcher 3 and hold all games to this standard.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Apparently I got this game back in 2015, played for 4 hours and put it down. I guess I just thought it was skyrim with a white haired dude. Boy that was a mistake! This game is great. It has amazing world building, acting, and story telling. It's quickly becoming one of my favorite games. 

If I had to offer any criticism, it would be that the combat seems a bit sloppy compared to something like HZD, or especially Elden Ring. However it's still quite fun, and seeing as how the mechanics/physics are from 2015 it's expected.

It'a also great to see after all these years they threw in a free next gen update, unlike some folks who charge over and over for their game riding on the backs of modders free labor *cough*.  It looks great given it's age and runs like a champ. Anyway TLDR: Buy this game, play this game.

MOST EPIC RPG OPEN WORLD GAME

Alright, let's dive into The Witcher 3, the game where I've clocked over 500 hours, which is basically a part-time job but with more swords and less paperwork.

The World:
This world is so stunningly real, I occasionally check outside to make sure I'm not actually in a medieval fantasy. The landscapes? So beautiful, they make real life look like a low-budget indie film. Every village, city, and creepy crawly forest is a feast for the senses,  and occasionally, a feast for the monsters trying to nibble on me.

The Gameplay:
Combat here is like a dance if the dance involved slicing and dicing things that definitely don't want to tango. It's the kind of fun that's only slightly less dangerous than juggling chainsaws. And Gwent, it's the digital equivalent of potato chips. Can't play just one round.

The Story:
Epic? More like epic on steroids. It's a rollercoaster of emotions with more twists than a pretzel factory. Geralt, our gruff, silverhaired hero, has more depth than a philosophy book, and the plot lines are so engaging, you'll forget what a social life is.

Final Thoughts:
If you haven't played The Witcher 3, what are you even doing? it's an escape to a world so rich, you'll consider paying taxes there

I have 300 hours on the PS4, so ignore my steam record. 

Look, The Witcher 3 is the BEST VIDEO GAME EVER MADE. This is NOT a subjective opinion. This is a FACT. 
While there are other games that surpass it in RPG elements and combat, NO game on God's green Earth has ever surpassed it's lore, story and world building. So all these elements make up for it's mid combat/rpg mechanics. 
By the time you finish this game, you're going to wish there was a memory erasing device to erase this game completely out of your memory so you can feel the thrilling experience of playing it for the first time.
-Every side quest feels like a MAIN quest
-Every character feels real, you will fall in love with them (and do 'other' things with them ;)
-Filled with politics, moral and ethical dilemmas - You will have to make choices you don't want to make, but sometimes doing something is better than doing nothing at all.
-Every action has a consequence 
-The Tax Man will come after you if you're doing something you're not suppose to be doing
-Make sure to prepare for every monster hunt
-You can negotiate the price of jobs and exploit peasants in desperate need for more money
-Don't go around killing every monster you see. First check the job board to exploit the local peasants.
-Become a Card Game Master, participate in Gwant Card tournaments and become the King of Games
-There are prostitutes
-Take out loans from a Dwarvan bank to fund your prostitute addiction

It a classic masterpiece. You are getting always back in the world of Witcher, and you can never get tired of it. The game still gets updates, and the dev team supports it, with fixes for bugs, features, upgrades, and much more.

Amazing. I like how the characters are created, every one of them is unique.
Sometimes seems too easy, but in the end pleasurable experience. I was raised on the books about the witcher and I feel almost like reading the interactive book. The atmosphere of the game is similar to what Sapkowski created.
Highly recommended!

[h1]A Masterpiece Unraveled in Every Pixel[/h1]

[h3]Introduction:[/h3]

Enter a world where the line between fantasy and reality blurs, and where the choices you make carve out your destiny. "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is not just a game; it's an immersive journey through a meticulously crafted universe, where every decision weighs heavy and every monster you slay echoes through the vast landscapes of its open world.

[h3]Graphics and Visual Splendor: [/h3]

From the moment you step into the Northern Realms, you're greeted with a visual feast that transcends mere gaming graphics. The attention to detail is jaw-dropping; each tree branch, every drop of rain, and the flicker of candlelight in the darkest corners of the world are rendered with a level of precision that sets a new standard for open-world games. The sunsets over Novigrad and the moonlit swamps of Velen are not just backdrops; they're canvases of digital artistry.

[h3]Narrative Depth and Player Agency:[/h3]

At the heart of "The Witcher 3" lies a narrative that's not just epic in scale but deeply personal. Geralt of Rivia, the White Wolf, is no traditional hero. He's a complex character with a history, emotions, and moral dilemmas. The game doesn't shy away from presenting you with choices that have consequences, both immediate and far-reaching. Every dialogue option, every action, shapes the world and the relationships within it. Your decisions don't just affect the story; they shape its very fabric.

[h3]Open World and Exploration: [/h3]

The open-world design of "The Witcher 3" is a triumph. The vastness of the map isn't just for show; it's a living, breathing world teeming with life. Every village, cave, and castle tells a story. Whether you're tracking a monster through the dense forests of Skellige or engaging in political intrigue in the busy streets of Novigrad, there's always something to discover. The game rewards curiosity, turning exploration into a narrative in itself.

[h3]Combat and Monster Hunting: [/h3]

Combat in "The Witcher 3" is a dance of steel and magic. Geralt's fluid movements and the variety of weapons and spells at your disposal make every encounter unique. Monster hunting is not just a task; it's an art. Each creature requires a specific strategy, and preparing for a hunt is as crucial as the battle itself. The thrill of facing a griffin in the highlands or a werewolf under the light of the full moon is an experience that lingers long after the battle is won.

[h3]Musical Score and Atmosphere: [/h3]

The haunting melodies composed by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz elevate the atmosphere to new heights. The music not only complements the game's emotional beats but also enhances the sense of place. From the melancholic tunes of Velen to the heroic anthems of Skellige, the soundtrack is a symphony that weaves seamlessly into the fabric of the game.

[h3]Conclusion: [/h3]

"The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is a triumph of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay. CD Projekt Red has not only raised the bar for open-world RPGs but has created a timeless masterpiece that will be remembered for years to come. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a newcomer to the fantasy genre, "The Witcher 3" is not just a game; it's an experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. In the vast sea of video games, "The Witcher 3" stands tall as a beacon of excellence, a game that transcends its medium and becomes a work of art.

La progressione e l'RPG del primo, unito alla narrazione e gameplay del 2. Mondo vasto, coerente e soprattutto divertente.

Forse pero' e' stato alzato eccessivamente sopra un piedistallo, tantoche' la gente, a distanza di anni, ha iniziato a ricordarsi cose sbagliate sul gioco: le scelte narrative prendibili non sono tantissime e le variazioni del finale sono poche. Cio' non significa che sia un male, ma ricordandosi male, il pubblico ha avuto aspettative sbagliate su CP77, quando in realta', entrambi fanno uso dello stesso tipo di narrativa (storia principale, missioni primarie opzionali che influenzano direttamente la main quest e variazioni importanti presenti solo nelle sequenze finali). L'unica vera differenza e' la maggior caratterizzazione di Geralt paragonato a V.
Tutt'oggi il gioco presenta tanti bug e i movimenti a cavallo non sono poi cosi' entusiasmanti.

Il primo tripla A di CD Project, ma sempre con i livelli di uno studio indipendente.

Heard a lot about this game, so going in my expectations were high. This game was way different than the ones I had played before, mainly because of the lore and backstory. I had to catch up with the series before starting the game (thankful that I did) and I had a blast. Being longer than other games I have played before, and considering I have trouble focusing, this was a challenge. And as I got closer to my goal every time, the feeling of it slipping away, that desperation, was unparalleled. I encountered a few bugs in the game which were very annoying, I do not know whether they came up because of the next-gen update or if they were there to begin with, but it got annoying after a certain point. Anyway, I got the good ending (thankfully) and I'm happy to put this game in my top 10 list.
Definitely would recommend this one,too. 9/10 from me.

i love this game i easy have over 500 hours on ps4 and couldn't stop myself from reliving it on pc. i still use the ps4 controller because its easy to plug in and play theres zero fiddling around with settings plug in the ps4 controller and it automatically changes everything. if i could blind play this to experience the full thing again i would. this game for me has always tested the strength of my moral compass and my compassion every time. i feel like this is going to go down as one of my favorite games i have ever played.  on pc there is some fairly annoying bugs and some hard crashes but it seems as though its after many hours of consistent gaming. i play on ultra and there is an issue that sometimes it seems to get super fuzzy then water seems to appear in places it shouldn't. if you go in the "water" it will make you swim then just crash. easy to avoid i just save exit and reload the game. a couple times it has crashed one start up but that not normally a problem its happened like 3 times or so. but other then that its the same great game which is normally found for good discount i got it for 75% off and couldn't be happier. i think it would be impossible to make this game better even the mini game gwent is awsome to the point i spend hours hunting down and looking for people to play cards with. i hope they dont mess up the next one by leaving geralt story. i actually bought the books based of my love for this game

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is a top-tier RPG lauded for its vast open world, gripping storylines, complex characters, and immersive gameplay. It's visually stunning, offers impactful decision-making, and has a compelling protagonist in Geralt. However, its size might overwhelm some, and combat could feel repetitive over time. Nonetheless, it's a must-play for RPG fans due to its rich storytelling and engaging world.

Long overdue in playing this game. Taking a lot of time to get accustomed to the game-play and various aspects of the game. It is gearing up to be a great game. But it is a slow burn and expecting it to get better from here on out.

I tried to get into this game on three separate occasions and it never felt even remotely compelling. The main character is written to be GRUFF AND TOUGH and he takes every opportunity to be GRUFF AND TOUGH because he desperately needs everyone to know how GRUFF AND TOUGH he is. Or maybe he's just a bag of sh-. If you like playing a good guy hero, you don't even get the option, because heroes are not GRUFF AND TOUGH!

The setting is apparently intended to be extremely depressing, and it does a good job of being extremely depressing. I don't know why you would want to play a game like that, but if that's a compelling reason for you, then give it a whirl while it's on sale.

Also, apparently some people really love Gwent. I thought it was boring and trite, but admittedly, I touched it only once based on initial first impressions, so perhaps it gets better with more cards.

53 hours into it right now and still far from the end I guess... God-damn!! it's so immersive. So much to do in it. I have a feeling that it will top my list of best RPGs (according to me) and maybe even the best game.
I would highly recommend using a controller. The M&K controls are clunky af and will make geralt walk in random directions at times. It's frustrating. It's even worse on roach. Other than that, 10/10
A great winter purchase

The 182 hours here were a second (or third?) play through, I originally started on another platform. I've sunk many, many hours into this gem.

First, the support and dedication to this game was really good since it's release to the big overhaul, as usual for CDPR games.

It's beautiful, it's huge, it's entertaining to the last, it has several great DLC. And it has stories. Oh so many stories. Yeah, there's the main story line, but I'm talking about all those small ones. In a mix of side quests, NPC dialogue, notes and environmental storytelling there are small, and, as typical for the Witcher, usually morally ambigous and sad tales everywhere, all intertwined, to tell bigger stories. Of a family. A farm. A village. A region.

It brings the hard lands of the franchises universe to life, in all it's hard, grim-dark rural country with it's - at the best of times - difficult and often no-win decisions and it's contrast to the often decadent cities. And then it paint's, in vivid detail, the horrors of several wars, past and ongoing, over that scenery. If you love stories, if even in a CRPG you not only enjoy the monster slaying and number-go-up mechanics but to immerse yourself into another world, The Witcher 3 is the best game in years, BG3 included.

This is easily one of my top three role playing games of all time. The other two, being Skyrim & Dragon‚Äôs Dogma. 

I love games when they get the sounds and sights of Nature right. This game renders Nature, the sun, the wind, the forest, the fields and the sky ‚Äì very beautifully. 

The quest stories are deep, meaningful and enjoyable. The medieval cities, towns, and landscapes are gorgeous to behold. And the soundtrack that accompanies your exploration is one of the best that I‚Äôve ever heard in game.  

To be certain, the injustice and harshness of this medieval world ‚Äì is very dark and grim. 

But you, as Geralt of Rivia ‚Äì can bring a bit of light and justice to a small few. 

And that my friends, makes it all worthwhile. 

 ~/~


Update: For whatever reason this game no longer works on Linux Mint 21.2‚Ä¶ so I‚Äôve switched over to MX Linux 23.1 and it works like a charm. 

Maybe something is going on with Ubuntu upstream; I‚Äôm not certain. But I feel much better using a Debian Based distribution ‚Äì and as it turns out, not only does it work flawlessly ‚Äì but it‚Äôs much faster.
Kill monsters. Get trim.

I have not played the prior games, but that should not stop you, it didn't stop me and I am fully immersed in the world of The Witcher!
The story is gripping and does not kill your immersion by forcing you to know the events of the previous games like so many triple A titles do nowadays. Aside from this, it helps ease you into the world by offering loads of dialogue to help you piece previous game's events together, while keeping the story moving forward at the same time due to the incredible amount of time and effort put into the writing of this game.

On the surface, it seems like another RPG whereby the player is sent one place to kill or retrieve something, rinse repeat. But no, no this game has many special quests and unique charm. There is a lot of political nuances dotted without, relationships between the characters that actually make you empathize with them, love, death and betrayal, all attributed to an immense open world and great story telling. The game is by no means easy either, so If you want a challenge, this game will break you on the harder difficulties but it is well worth it. Studying the bestiary, drinking potions/decoctions and preparing for a fight, only to finally slay that monster? There are few games that deliver such a feeling of satisfaction and accomplishment like this.

Overall, a great game which I have no doubt in my mind will become a timeless classic. CD Projekt Red have truly out-done themselves. If this series' success is anything to go by, CD Projekt Red's next game: Cyberpunk 2077 will be worth EVERY penny.

[h3] A Masterpiece of RPG with Minor Caveats. [/h3]
[b] Rating: [/b] ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

[b] Review: [/b]
I've spent considerable time exploring the world of "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" and can confidently state that this game is a true masterpiece in the RPG genre. Here's what I particularly enjoyed:

    [b] Deep and Captivating World: [/b] Every location and character comes alive thanks to the attention to detail. The game's world is vast and full of interesting places and quests.
    [b] Compelling Characters: [/b] Geralt of Rivia is a superbly developed main character with a unique personality and sense of humor.
    [b] Engaging Storyline: [/b] The plot captures your attention from the first few minutes, and the branching choices genuinely impact the game's progression.

However, there are aspects that could be improved:

    [b] Combat System Balance: [/b] Sometimes the fights feel unfairly difficult or, conversely, too easy.
    [b] Depiction of Female Characters: [/b] Some aspects of how female characters are portrayed in the game raised questions for me.

[b] Conclusion: [/b] Despite some flaws, "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" remains an excellent choice for RPG lovers. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who values a deep story, an immersive world, and multifaceted characters. It's one of those games that leaves a mark in your heart even after you've finished it.

Oh boy, where do I even begin? This review is effectively going to be a love letter to the game that may have taken the top spot for my favorite video game ever made. 

For starters, you take control of what is one of the most popular and beloved protagonists in media history across books, games and television. Geralt of Rivia. CD Projekt Red deserves an endless amount of praise for how they handled this. The story is so accessible to everyone even those who have failed to play the games predecessors (Like myself) or even read the books. (Which the first game takes place directly after) Right off the bat with no real explanation needed, you can feel and understand the importance of a lot of these characters involved in Geralt‚Äôs life from the beginning. With a world filled with already so much deep lore and backstory I find this to be incredibly impressive. But with Geralt being the center of it all, I actually adore that he‚Äôs not even the main character in this specific instance. The dark gritty tone the game starts off on is perfect. Paired with absolutely beautiful music that sets you right into the world so effortlessly. The pacing is done just right. You‚Äôre thrown in the mix, being left with so many questions and emotions. But you have to wait, and taking your time is the best part about this entire masterpiece. 

The graphics are stunningly beautiful, and at times truly breathtaking. For an 8 year old game it still holds its own extraordinarily well. (I understand the next gen update but who cares) The combat while holding only 1 of 2 complaints I have about the games entirety, is still a TON of fun. It has some jank, but when you get the hang of it it‚Äôll quickly be something you get over. The game does a great job of giving you all the tools and information that truly engrosses you into feeling like you are a Witcher! From the beastiary, to the oils, potions all of it is just awesome.

Furthermore, the game succeeds at the pure RPG elements that I crave from so many games that can‚Äôt quite nail it the way you dream of. Most importantly for me is the choice and consequence opportunities, and man, do they do it right. So many instances where I was just stressed debating back and forth on what to do, and I love it! That‚Äôs how games should make you feel, it‚Äôs a feeling I desire where something I do makes a real impact on the storyline or the outcome of a character. There‚Äôs so many quests that stick out in my mind when it comes to this. Even better this includes side quests! A trend so often in modern gaming is how pointless, boring and overall forgettable most side content is, but not here. I adore how each character and story is capable of giving added context and depth to the main plot of the game. Tying them in so effortlessly that if you skip out on a lot of this stuff you‚Äôre doing yourself a HUGE disservice. Some of my favorite moments come from these secondary objectives, and there‚Äôs so much of it. Including the treasure hunts or the Witcher contracts. Better yet, I love that they don‚Äôt stray away from the dark side of life sometimes. Not everyone gets a happy ending, and this game isn‚Äôt afraid to show that. Sometimes things just suck no matter how you spin them. 

In addition, the world building is absolutely top notch. Each NPC feels real and they‚Äôre carrying on doing their normal everyday things that are so easy to miss when you‚Äôre just running by to your next objective. Random encounters from people walking up to you or having their own meaningful conversations. It‚Äôs just that extra attention to detail that many developers bypass because of the admitted difficulty and overall insignificance. But it really does help in making the world more alive and immerse you in a way many games fail to do. Each section of the map has its own quirks and I truly find each one interesting and captivating. I love all the towns and villages you can come across, all having a unique experience and feel to them. 

In conclusion, this game absolutely stole my heart. I loved the almost everything about it, this is the exact kind of experience I was craving when I decided to tackle this from my backlog. I once again applaud everyone involved in making this project. I feel like I could ramble even more if I wanted. Just man‚Ä¶ What a game, and experience. I can‚Äôt wait to tackle the DLC‚Äôs and come back and play it again someday in the future. I was so sad it was over, but there‚Äôs still so much to do and I truly can‚Äôt wait.

[h1] 10/10 [/h1]
From the very beginning, The Witcher 3 impresses with its vast and diverse world. From dense forests and dangerous swamps to beautiful cities, every corner of this world seems to be saturated with stories and adventures. Visual execution of the game is at the highest level. Breathtaking views, detailed characters and changing weather create an incredibly realistic atmosphere. The plot, based on the books by Andrzej Sapkowski, does not leave indifferent. The main character, the witch doctor Geralt from Rivia, goes on a wild hunt for his stolen adopted daughter. Intrigue, political conspiracies and a sea of surprises - all this makes the plot exciting. The Witcher 3 gives the player the freedom to make choices that affect the development of the plot and the world around them. Moral dilemmas make you think, and every decision has consequences. The Witcher 3 is literally overflowing with content. The game leaves no chance to get bored.

Advantages:
+Vast open world
+Stunning graphics and design
+Captivating story and characters
+Freedom of choice and moral dilemmas
+Rich content

Disadvantages:
-Difficulty for beginners
-No multiplayer

This game is phenomenal, up there with Skyrim as my top fantasy open world game.
The Pros:
-The main story is great, tho some people complained about The Wild Hunts as the main villain, I found them to be great in the story context. Especially how the people in this world treat them like a mere folktale.
-The side quests are amazing, this the true meat of the game, do not rush the main story, take your time to delve in the story of the people of The Continent. Some of the best writing I have ever seen in any video games.
-The branching stories and the various ways you can solve the quest(with variable ending) are great and made the world feel alive and made your choices matter.
-The combat is fine and fun, might not be the most creative out there but there's a lot of room for various kind of build.
-The graphic is great even though the game is 8 years old already, the enviroments are gorgeous(especially Toussauint).
-Sound design is great.
-Armor designs are great.
-Weapons designs are amazing.
-Monster designs are top notch.
-The DLC are amazing.
-Heart of Stone got amazing story and atmosphere.
-Blood and Wine basically give you at least another 30 hours of gameplay in a new map that is well crafted.
-Great replayability.

The Cons:
-The camera in the fight can be wonky sometimes.
-The world can feel more alive, stealing and murdering basically don't have any effect like let's say stealing in The Elder Scrolls Series. The guard basically useless in this.
-Sometimes, they sprinkle 5 seconds of gameplay between long cutscenes, might aswell just continue the cutscene if the only thing I need to do is walk less than 10 feet.
-Found a lot of small annoying bugs like how Roach can't gallop sometimes.

Overall this is an amazing game. CDPR magnum opus thus far.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt' is an unparalleled triumph in the open-world gaming arena, redefining immersive storytelling and character development in ways previously unimagined. When pitted against other titles in its genre, it stands out for its originality and freshness, particularly in how it weaves its narrative and builds its characters.

The game's environments are nothing short of breathtaking, offering a tapestry of landscapes that are both stunning and evocative, complemented by a mesmerising soundtrack that enhances the sense of immersion. Each location in the game is not just a backdrop but a character in itself, integral to the storytelling.

The brilliance of 'The Witcher 3' is not limited to the main game. The expansions, 'Hearts of Stone' and 'Blood and Wine,' are masterclasses in how to enhance and expand an already rich world. They add over 40 hours of captivating gameplay, offering more depth and value than many full-priced titles, showcasing CD Projekt Red's commitment to quality over quantity.

CD Projekt Red's efforts in crafting 'The Witcher 3' have set them apart as a developer deserving of the highest respect. This game has achieved something rare ‚Äì it connected with me on an emotional level, leaving a lasting impression that transcends the typical gaming experience.

In conclusion, 'The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt' is not just a game; it's a work of art, a milestone in gaming that will be remembered and cherished by those who experience it.

I decided to update my review as the game has been updated again after all these years. It honestly feels fantastic that they still care so much about the game. And trust me, this is not a "Skyrim re-release". They added a lot of stuff, new quests, armor, weapons. But best of all, they've rebalanced the skill and talent trees. So now more things are viable from the early game, even on deathmarch difficulty. Though with the changes now I feel DM is not as hard as it used to be. Overall I like the update, both graphically and gameplay wise. 

TL; DR at the bottom.

I have never played the other witcher games or read the books before the Witcher 3, BUT this masterpiece changed everything. It's simply the best fantasy game out there and I‚Äôm pretty sure it will become a huge classic.
It just made me feel so many things I cannot even list them all. Got me so emotional sometimes it was almost embarrassing.

The story is solid, quality writing and the (cut)scenes are done so professionally it almost feels like a movie that just goes on and on, pulling you in more and more, as you get attached to the characters. And the realization hitting you, that nothing is black and white in this universe. One can feel sympathy for the most deformed, hideous creatures, while sometimes it's the humans who are the most disgusting and evil inhabitants of this world.
There are three stories that are the most significant (main games and the two DLCs main quests), but most of the side quests have some significance. Whether you get back an old woman‚Äôs frying pan or take on a contract to kill a bloodthirsty monster, you will be surprised by the stories what these smaller quests can deliver.

Graphics are gorgeous, the landscape is diverse, from a gloomy miserable swamp to a colorful land with hills vineyards scattered all over it. The vast open world feels like it could be just watched from above and even then it would be interesting. The world lives, the NPCs have daily routine, they move from place to place with purpose.

Oh and the music, the music goes so well with everything mentioned above. From epic fast paced compositions made for battle, to the eeriest lullabies... just perfect.

The combat. It feels good. On the first two difficulty settings it is easy to just meet any adversary rushing in head forward, however, the games core mechanisms shine the brightest on the hardest. At early levels you have to use everything (the bestiary for example) to gain advantage. And even with an "end game" -ish build, you could face some difficulties if you don't pay attention. The talent system may be not the most in depth one amongst other games, but it still provides a large amount of possibility for different types of gameplay.

TL; DR:
So even if you read the full review, I probably missed some things that Witcher 3 did amazingly, and sorry for that. But i think you can get a good idea of the overwhelming positivity provided by the community towards this piece of art.

As you can see I invested quite some time in this game and probably will in the foreseeable future. Yes, it's just simply fantastic. For me this masterpiece will become the standard of the fantasy genre and for the single player games.

[list]
[*]STORY 10/10
[*]GRAPHICHS 10/10
[*]MUSIC 10/10
[*]GAMEPLAY 10/10
[/list]

[h1] Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - An Epic Adventure Through a Richly Crafted World [/h1]

Graphics and Visuals: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ
The Witcher 3 boasts stunning visuals that immerse players in its beautifully crafted world. Each region feels distinct, from the bustling streets of Novigrad to the haunting swamps of Velen. The attention to detail is astounding, with weather effects, day-night cycles, and lifelike character models that bring the game to life. However, occasional graphical glitches and minor frame rate drops hinder the otherwise outstanding visual experience.

Gameplay and Combat: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The gameplay in Witcher 3 strikes a perfect balance between exploration, combat, and character progression. As Geralt of Rivia, players embark on a vast open-world adventure, tackling quests, battling fierce monsters, and making impactful choices that shape the story. The combat system is fluid and challenging, requiring tactical thinking and precise timing. With a wide variety of weapons, magic spells, and character abilities, players have multiple options to approach each encounter, enhancing replayability and combat diversity.

Story and Writing: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
Witcher 3 boasts a masterfully written narrative that captivates players from start to finish. Its rich lore and deep character development create emotional connections with Geralt and the diverse cast of engaging characters. The player's choices have far-reaching consequences, resulting in multiple branching storylines that keep players invested in the world. Each quest is meticulously crafted, providing intriguing moral dilemmas and unexpected twists, making the storytelling truly exceptional.

World Design and Exploration: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The open-world design of Witcher 3 is a triumph. From sprawling cities to isolated villages, each location is meticulously created and full of life. The world feels lived-in and believable, with NPCs engaging in their routines and conversations that add depth to the experience. Exploration is rewarded with hidden treasures, enchanting vistas, and memorable encounters, encouraging players to venture off the beaten path and discover the secrets that lie within.

Sound and Music: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The sound design in Witcher 3 is exceptional, with ambient noise, creature growls, and the clashing of swords that create a truly immersive experience. The voice acting is superb, with convincing performances that breathe life into the characters. The music, composed by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz, adds depth and emotion to each scene, be it a haunting melody or a triumphant battle theme, making the audio design a standout aspect of the game.

Conclusion:
Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is an outstanding RPG that has set a new standard in the genre. With its breathtaking visuals, immersive gameplay, engaging storyline, and unforgettable world, it demands to be experienced by every gamer. Despite occasional graphical glitches, Witcher 3 delivers an epic adventure that will keep players hooked for countless hours. It's a masterpiece that deserves its place among gaming's finest.

Upon completing this game, my mind was consumed with the desire to erase my memories, just so I could relive the entire gaming experience once more. This particular game stands out among the few that have evoked such a sentiment within me. It is a testament to the love and dedication of the creators towards Witcher fans, RPG enthusiasts, and video game lovers in general.

Every aspect, from the captivating main campaign to the intriguing side quests and exhilarating monster hunts, down to the smallest details, has been meticulously crafted in a visually stunning world. Undoubtedly, this game has provided one of the most exceptional gaming experiences and will undoubtedly serve as a benchmark for the decades to come.

I genuinely want to like this game but the story is just unnecessarily convoluted, sometimes outright bland. I found myself skipping most of the cut scenes because it was just too boring. 

For a game where story is such an integral part, I did not find any joy in progressing through the main quest because of boring sub plots.

The entire story so far goes like this -

- You search for Ciri, you find clues in a place where a person knows something about Ciri, and that person strikes a deal with you that you'd have to collect a potion for him in order to give you information about Ciri, and while you are collecting this potion, you find another person who knows about this potion and you'd have to do him a favour to collect this.

Its just sub plot over sub plot and maybe I'm in the minority but I just didn't find any of this fun.

Despite the flaws, I have to admit, the gameplay is fun, rewarding and the RPG element incorporated in this game is definitely engaging. Even some of the dialogues and voice actors were surprisingly good for a weaker story (unfortunately, the same can't be said for the main character). Geralt is probably one of the least charismatic protagonists i've ever seen. 

5/10 game for me.

Coming from someone who has played both the Witcher 1 and the Witcher 2, the Witcher 3 was more or less the same game but on a grander scale of immersion and interactivity. 

Like all Witcher games, the story, characters, world-building and lore are why we all fall in love with this series. While there is no branching storyline in the main story like you see in the Witcher 2, all the choices you make in the Witcher 3 including those in side missions have consequences that can affect future story events and questlines. In fact, some of the side-missions in this game could pass off as being main quests since they do have a direct impact on what ending you get. Quests are so well written that you can even get different cutscenes and dialogue simply because you started a quest at a different time of day or did a quest objective or completed another quest at a different order. To this day, people are still finding new things in this nearly decade-old game, which shows how great the attention to detail was.

For a game with so many choices, the Witcher 3 also does a brilliant job in respecting choices you make. Sure, sometimes a choice may yield unintended consequences, but it will never be because of your character doing something completely different to what you have decided to do. There are so many choice-based games out there where picking a choice may cause a character to perform an action that isn‚Äôt in line with that choice, due to how vaguely the choice was presented or simply because the writers wanted to add an element of shock or surprise. The Witcher 3 does not fall into this immersion-breaking trap and instead relies on its strong narrative to create this effect.  

Another reason why the storytelling is so great is because of its believable open-world. The game has a full day/night cycle where NPCs will have their own lives and schedules. Some will even have new dialogue after completing certain story events. It‚Äôs not the most dynamic system out there, but it‚Äôs enough to set a realistic world. The absence of loading screens when exploring a map also allows for better immersion within this world.

Speaking of exploration, exploring in this game is always rewarding since loot scales with your character level (you will find higher level weapon and armor as you level up). However, this stops becoming relevant once you start crafting the Witcher gear which overpowers all the other gear in the game. Nonetheless, exploration is still worth doing as you can find all you need in food, materials and gold just from looting. Geralt is still able to go unpunished for looting people‚Äôs homes, but that‚Äôs a game mechanic that dates back to the very first Witcher game and is pretty much a staple in most RPGs. The Witcher 3 does improve on this a bit by making certain guards hostile when caught stealing, but some might find this added mechanic annoying. 

Traversal is easily the weakest part about this game. Travelling on foot is fine, and the parkour in this game is surprisingly good as you can climb or jump onto most reachable roofs and platforms. However, travelling via boat is very clunky and tedious, and it is only made worse by the inclusion of a durability system. Horse-riding can also be just as bad, as any small obstacles you stumble onto can cause Roach to suddenly stop moving (which CD Projeckt even admitted to themselves via an in-game quest). Fortunately, we never have to rely on these modes of transport for too long at any instance as the map is filled with fast-travel points all over the world. 

As for the combat, it is very similar to the one in Witcher 2 - same real-time hack and slash combat with Witcher signs and rolling & parrying mechanics. However, this time they added a side-step manoeuvre, which is great for dodging attacks while still maintaining proximity to the enemy (the previous game only had rolling so whenever you dodge an attack you would always create distance). There are also no more quick-time events like the ones you see in Witcher 2, but this does mean there are less cinematic fights if that‚Äôs your thing. The worst part about the combat is its awful targeting system as Geralt would sometimes attack a random mob instead of the closest one. You could swing at a completely different direction despite having an enemy or targetable object right in front of your character. There‚Äôs also the issue that you cannot jump during mid-fight, so you can unintentionally become stuck somewhere like in a ditch, which makes for awkward fighting. Initially, the overworld may seem lacking in enemy variety, but there‚Äôs actually a lot of different monsters you can encounter, especially those from contracts and places that stray far away from the main path. I highly recommend playing this game at the hardest difficulty (Death March) because it forces you to utilise your potions, oils and bestiary knowledge more, making you feel more like a real Witcher (plus it‚Äôs necessary for 100-percenting the game in one playthrough for all you achievement hunters out there). 

On a tech scale, the next-gen update provides much vastly improved graphics in the form of upgraded textures, higher detail level, ray-traced reflections and shadows, higher crowd and vegetation density, and greater draw distances and foliage visibility range. As a result, the environment is now brimming with more flora and fauna, breathing more life into this world. The only downside is that the more realistic lighting of ray-tracing makes the interior of buildings too dark to navigate in, which means you will need to carry a torch or candlelight at all times. There‚Äôs also a noticeable hit in performance and increase in game crashes, but the graphics upgrade is worth these trade-offs. The game honestly looks like a triple-A game that was made from this year.

In summary, despite its shortcomings in certain mechanics, the Witcher 3 is still a masterpiece thanks to its strong storytelling alone. Fans of the series will enjoy the same structure of storytelling with returning characters and references from the old games and books, while new fans can enjoy an original story that was designed to be standalone. The DLCs are also worth playing, and one can argue they are better written than the main story. The Heart of Stone DLC has a tight and well-crafted story with very unique missions and impressive boss fights, while the Blood and Wine DLC is basically another game itself as it adds another map that is packed full of content. Bring on the Witcher 4!

This game is so incredibly buggy. At time of posting I am playing version 4.04 on Direct-X 12.

First, I couldn't get the game to launch. Took me hours to finally track the issue down to one of the utility programs that auto-runs when I boot up my PC. Disabling this utility app allowed the game to launch instead of sitting in the background of Task Manager.

Then, I temporarily broke my game because I enabled Ciri's alternate appearance option in the main menu. This is [i] official DLC for the game [/i] and having it enabled would crash my game and not let me load back into my saved games!

Now I'm dealing with constant crashing when I go to load a quick save or an auto save file. Only manual saves will allow me to reload the game once it is running without crashing to desktop. Additionally, I cannot select a save file to load into the first time I boot up the game; the only way to load a save without the game crashing is if I select [b] continue [/b] from the main menu. Checkpoint saves seem to work normally.

At this point, I'm absolutely fed up trying to coax this game to run without it constantly corrupting or breaking my saves. This is a game that came out in 2015! How did you manage to break it so badly with an update?!

"The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is a masterpiece of an action RPG that offers an immersive and captivating single-player experience. While it doesn't have a multiplayer component, it excels in delivering a rich and detailed open world filled with intriguing characters, complex narratives, and morally ambiguous choices.

In "The Witcher 3," you step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, a monster hunter for hire, as you navigate a war-torn fantasy world. The game boasts a vast and diverse landscape, from bustling cities to dense forests and treacherous swamps. The narrative is deeply engaging, with branching storylines influenced by the choices you make.

The game's strong points include its well-developed characters, morally gray decisions, and a dynamic combat system. The world is teeming with monsters to slay, quests to undertake, and mysteries to uncover. If you enjoy single-player experiences with a strong emphasis on story, character development, and exploration, "The Witcher 3" is an exceptional choice.

 The Witcher 3 has so much content and rich dialog, it  makes Skyrim, or any other RPG I've played rendered inferior. A First person Mod exists and that sounds like a whole new experience. 

Also Gwent will suck you in for hours just trying to get a better deck. I wish you could stake your own best card and potentially win it back if you lose it. But, I'm nitpicking.

 Get this game, love it, cherish it, and pray The Witcher 4 has this much and even more content when it comes out sometime in the next millennia.

Positive: 
- A lot of the menus are well thought out. 
- On-screen instructions are helpful. 
- Navigation is good. There are only a few parts that leave you guessing.  
- No major glitches or bugs to report. 
- Beautiful natural open landscapes. Probably the nicest I have seen in a game. 
- Generally, well written. 
- The gameplay is good. I like that doors open without needing to press buttons. 
- You can play as another character sometimes. 
- Great cut scenes. 

 Negative: 
- Music is very repetitive and needs to be turned down or off in places like dungeons to give the scene a better atmosphere.  
- Not enough battle time. 
- Going from quest to quest can be confusing as no markers are placed. You must complete the quests in a nonlinear order 
to complete prior quests. Also, sometimes you must complete secondary side quests to move on, but it does not instruct you to do so. 
- Long winded at times, 100+ hours. 
- Fishing rod, but no fishing capability?  
- *The rest read below. 

 

Conclusion: 

I can see why this game got so much attention. The huge map is wonderful to explore, leaving what feels like the possibility for endless exploration. The menus/HUD and gameplay are very well thought out. The writing and graphics are very good. Honestly, I see no need to keep diving into the good so let's look at the subjective. 

After coming from titles such as Dragon Age Inquisition and Skyrim the Witcher III is a different experience. Love it or not is personal but you best be prepared to put away your weapons and put on your Sherlock Homes hat. A lot of this game is playing a detective. Maybe that‚Äôs okay? I came into the game blind, so it was a surprise for me.  

The intro really stands out along with the last quarter of the game. The issue is that I often didn‚Äôt really feel like a warrior while playing. During dialogue the main character sometimes displays traits of inner weakness. To me this conflicted with his sword bearing persona. 

Despite these critiques the game is very well done and certainly deserves great recognition. If a 4th edition was released, I would certainly play it. 

 

RECOMMENDED   8.5/10
