The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a timeless masterpiece that, even years after its release, continues to captivate players. Its immersive world, morally complex narrative, and well-developed characters create an unforgettable experience. The musics adds a haunting and emotional layer to the game, making it impossible to forget. Whether revisiting the Northern Realms or simply listening to its iconic soundtrack, The Witcher 3's enduring appeal speaks to its status as a classic in the RPG genre. The open-world environment offers endless exploration and surprises, ensuring that each playthrough feels fresh. The game's impact on gaming is evident, with its influence seen in the aspirations of many subsequent titles. In every aspect, from storytelling to gameplay and music, The Witcher 3 proves itself as a perfect game that stands the test of time.

CD Project Red is basically a decent studio that sometimes pushes things out before they're ready and then goes to great lengths and expense to make good. The Witcher 3, like other CD Project games, is now excellent and is easily recommended as one of the best gaming experiences out there still (in 2023) and remains one of the highlights of its generation of open world games. It pushed boundaries and broke new ground in rich, immersive open world exploration that is narrative driven with an exciting, absorbing story and an engaging set of characters and personalities that you genuinely come to care about. Some of the gameplay is janky, and the NPC AI leaves a lot to be desired, but overall, The Witcher 3 is a game for the ages.

"The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is not just a game; it's a breathtaking journey through a world brimming with rich narrative and stunning landscapes. As Geralt of Rivia, you're not just playing a character; you're living through an epic saga. The storytelling is unparalleled, weaving intricate plots with memorable characters that stay with you long after you've turned off your console. The open-world is vast and alive, filled with quests that are as compelling as the main storyline. Combat is both challenging and rewarding, striking a perfect balance between skill and strategy. This game is a rare gem that sets the bar for RPGs, blending immersive gameplay with a world so detailed and vibrant, it feels real. "The Witcher 3" is an absolute must-play, a masterpiece that transcends the genre.

The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt is one of the best games I have played in my entire life. You must've heard this line countless of times right about now, although it might not be as extreme as mine. I'll gladly give my explanation in excruciating details. If a game takes us at least a hundred hours to beat, I'm sure it's the least one can do to review the end of Geralt of Rivia's journey.

Not sure where to start, but this game marks the third and the last journey in Geralt of Rivia's "The Witcher" series. Or Geralt the exterminator. Geralt the shephard. Geralt The Slayer. Geralt The Hide and Seek player. As a player of the whole series, I can safely say we have seen a transformation of the character as well as the environment throughout the course of the three games. The previous games had their flaws, and though these flaws are not disengaging to the point where I'd be completely disinterested, they still were quite bothersome. However, I can easily and safely say The Witcher 3: The Wild hunt is flawless in every shape and form.

Recently, I've taken up an efficient way of beating games in my personal opinion where I dont have to force myself to spend more time than I have to depending on my curiosity. The reason being, if I force myself to be a completionist with a game, especially if it is a Role-Playing Game, I'd be disengaged from the world itself and might not even feel involved anymore in the world the characters live in. Luckily the opposite had occured with The Witcher 3 and I initially went with the flow. However, I saw myself veering off to exploring and asking NPCs about monsters' whereabouts and helping out those in need besides the main plot. It didn't feel superficial nor disengaging from the rest of the game. In fact, every quest felt like it mattered in comparison to the overall world.

One of the main reasons I was attached to this game is the storytelling and the pacing of the plot. You literally live in the character's mindset and the narrative, although sometimes takes place from different perspective, still takes you through geralt's mind. The animation and the graphics as well as the soundtrack and the great performance intertwines with the narrative in a beautiful fashion. At first, I felt overwhelmed, but as I delved deeper into the world of The Witcher, I didn't want to get out of it. Sure enough, 150 hours later, I'd look for more sidequests before finishing the story.

Choices in the game are not all about Right and Wrong, it's a little more than that and to be honest it is hard for me to explain since there was a consequence for each action I've taken. I did not regret a single choice I have picked however bad the consequence seemed.

Combat is actually great as opposed to the previous games. The series' weak point in my opinion was always in the combat and thankfully, this game saved it with its variety between signs and combat. There are so many combinations one can come up with and so many different play styles are present as opposed to the clicking of the mouse in Witcher 1 or the button mashing in Witcher 2 without the emphasis or need on Signs as much as here.

Don't get me started on the aesthetics of Witcher 3. The music is beautiful and really takes you to a different world. I am sure I would type more but I am out of words right now and I can only say I feel quite empty after finishing this wonderful project by CD Projekt. There are no other developers I would entrust an RPG experience than CD PRojekt. Keep it up guys and I'm looking forward to their future games and expansions.

The Witcher 3 is, without a doubt, a Game-of-the-Year caliber game for me. The recent update that enhanced the graphics was a welcome addition, but truth be told, even before that update, this game held its ground remarkably well. It's simply astounding.

This game has etched itself a permanent place in my heart that no other game can replace. The experience it provides is nothing short of extraordinary, one in a thousand, I'd say. Every aspect of this game, from its storytelling to the intricate world-building, is meticulously crafted and thoroughly engaging.

The depth of the characters, the captivating narrative arcs, and the sheer vastness of the world make it a journey worth every penny. The attention to detail in every corner of this game is a testament to the dedication and passion of the developers.

Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt is a gaming masterpiece. With simple yet effective mechanics, it offers an immersive world with stunning environments and a rich, engaging narrative. The game's depth and attention to detail are unparalleled, creating an unforgettable experience that sets a new standard for gaming. Continous updates and the next-gen version made the game absolutely stunning even nowadays. Controls take time getting used to and the combat could be a bit more. However, this modern classic is still a must-play.

This game is very fun with lots of variety and quests that have meaningful choices. However, this is a game for if you have LOTS of time on your hands. It took me about 85 hours to complete the story and dlc and that was with me moving pretty quickly through it. The story is VERY long and convoluted so at times I felt myself getting mentally exhausted with all the different things happening. The characters in the game are pretty scripted and are not very memorable but the game has some pretty interesting romance options if you're into that, though I didn't feel very satisfied by the end game results. Blood and Wine made me feel like welp now I have a static NPC to look at after exhausting their dialogue. The atmosphere is pretty decent with areas in the game being very distinct in their look and feel. The combat is fairly challenging yet rewarding, parrying was one of the biggest things I had to work on. Realized you have to press the parry button only ONCE for it to work, otherwise you wouldn't parry even if you hit it at the right time. Overall if you're into dark fantasy RPG's that delve into mature topics and themes, then this is the game for you.

As one who enjoyed the OG version on friend's laptop in 2015, then now immersed in the NG version, I have to recommend this game to any new gamers even years down the line. The basic criteria of its genre, including world building, plot organization, and character development are all as superb as any other classic games can get, or even beyond.

The main advantage of this game, is mainly based on its layered approach in main quests and almost all side quests, of which, many are interconnected to convince you of a real and dynamic world in progress. The amount of details, the ability to trigger your emotions after your carefully decided moral choices, are not yet found on other games. This is further strengthened by a group of charismatic characters, who all developed comprehensive arc alongside the journey. I would argue that all people from all cultural and social backgrounds, will find the game deeply resonating with their experience, one way or another. 

However, it is also noticeable, in contrast to the story aspects, the game controls such as combat, numeric balance, character related system designs are awful even back when its launch in 2015. The action feedback mechanism in combination with poorly designed input latency/cd is the most frustrating experience for beginners. Many times encountering character not moving/reacting to your commands several times a second, can be annoying. This is amplified by poorly integrated skill system, which although already strayed away from the original book's settings, is not complex and interesting enough for gameplay oriented setting. 

Therefore, another major advantage of this game to me, is the modding community and environment. Mods addressed many major problems people faced before, and contributed directly to the introduction of NG version. Witcher 3 stands as one of the most welcoming games for mods, like Skyrim and etc. This highlights my main recommendation for this game in 2023 and beyond, specifically due to modding community's incredible vitaity.

In conclusion, this is a game for who pursues story driven gameplay, not keen on competitive combat, and one who enjoys late medieval styled realistic world for exploration. It is to my knowledge, a great game portrayed the complex nature of myths development and pre-industrial era social dynamics.

I love this game so much that I bought and played through the game again just to get all the achievements on Steam, even though I had previously put over 100 hours on console when I originally beat both the main game and DLCs.

Just to give some context, I played Witcher 1 when it first came out and I was a massive fan. I was let down a lot by Witcher 2. While I liked the story in Witcher 2, everything else was a disappointment to me, especially the atmosphere. I actually had to restart Witcher 2 three times until I finally forced myself to finish it. Because of my disappointment with Witcher 2, I wasn't excited about Witcher 3, so I was thrilled when I finally played it and felt like the Witcher magic was recaptured.

Almost everything about Witcher 3 is great. The music is one of the best soundtracks ever. The graphics and art direction are insanely good and still look like a modern game in 2023 (yes, I know they updated the graphics). The story, characters, voice acting, writing, etc., are all top-notch. The DLCs are amazing. The only two nitpicks are 1) while I like the combat overall, it can get a little stale when playing for 100+ hours, and 2) I don't like what they did with the Geralt-Triss-Yennefer love dynamic. I could write pages of why that love triangle is flawed and stupid for multiple reasons, but I'll skip that for now.

Bottom line, this is one of the best games ever made and should be played by anyone who loves RPGs.

The Witcher 3 is an enigmatic game at times, particularly at the beginning of the game if the player lacks the context of The Witcher 2 and is prone to skipping cut-scenes. however after a couple of hours at the beginning of the game, it truly opens up into something special, particularly once one has reached Velen in the main story-line. The game can be many things to different people, set to its lowest difficulty the game becomes a story-based narrative game with combat adding flavor to the engrossing open world, but at higher difficulties such as Blood and Broken Bones and Death March, the game begins to take on souls-like characteristics, rewarding the player for learning about and thoughtfully utilizing the deep combat and crafting systems. Blood and Bones finds itself as feeling like a souls-like hybrid, more accessible than a traditional souls-like, but still challenging and rewarding, whereas Death March integrates the punishing feel of a souls-like, forcing the player to engage with the systems in place to gain any traction in the world, rather than firmly, but not overwhelmingly simply pushing the player in their direction in the Blood and Bones difficulty.

Overall though, The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece, for the right person, this sort of game really caters to someone who enjoys games that engross one with a deep story and beautifully deep RPG systems, but may not appeal to someone who is just looking for a game to pick up and play for a couple of minutes. Though if one is a new player to RPGs, I'd highly recommend The Witcher 3 as a way to enter into the genre, particularly at lower difficulties as it allows the player to learn and engage with RPG mechanics, without them being overwhelming.

Overall 10/10 game that most assuredly is worth your time.

After doing 100% achievements I feel obligated to leave review.
Witcher 3 is not 10/10 game like many state (as there is almost no such thing as perfection) but probably is best RPG, especially "modern" RPG game. Well written quests, weapons and armors to choose from, references to other games and more. Characters are easily like'able, DLC's are on their own better than Ubi's or Bethesda's games. My only recommendation: besides installing graphical mods (achivements still work) try playing on Death March, even from a get-go. Besides ONE boss from DLC, the game feels balanced but DM forces you to use oils and potions which are somewhat trademark of Witcher's set, makes game little more immersive. Tried playing game on anything lower and I was able to no-brain my way to the end.

Witcher 1 will still remain my favourite story-wise but third game became a benchmark for good action rpgs.

The Witcher 3 is one of the best RPG experiences around, with a long but captivating story that ramps up as the game goes on, and is masterfully told with compelling characters and intricate world building throughout, where choices do matter. For me, this game is best enjoyed by not only focusing on the main story, but taking time to complete the side quest content. The side quests in this game are mini-stories of their own which add extra flavour to the dark world The Witcher inhabits. I might not be selling them enough, but they are easily the best side quests I have experienced in any game I've played (I've played and finished more MMORPG's/RPG/open world games than I can count). I think it's only a benefit to take time to complete them.

My only critique of the game would come down to the combat, it's nothing to write home about but is serviceable, it feels like some weird mix of old Assassin's Creed and Dark Souls but it's passable. Though it's certainly not enough for me to not recommend this game or hesitate from saying it is in my top 3 games of all time. I highly recommend the DLC's also, particularly Blood and Wine, which is a fantastic expansion-like experience with a story that has to be the best DLC story I've ever seen. It's probably the best DLC I've played along with the Shivering Isles in Oblivion.

[h3]The Witcher¬Æ 3: Wild Hunt[/h3]

Hello friends, today I will review the game called The Witcher¬Æ 3: Wild Hunt. This game tells the adventures of Geralt, a monster hunter in the open world RPG genre. Geralt is looking for a girl named Ciri, who is seen as an omen of doom and can change the shape of the world. But there are both humans and monsters after Geralt. The atmosphere, graphics, sounds and story of the game are very impressive and gripping. While playing the game, you experience Geralt's emotions and decisions. Some parts of the game are very exciting and action-packed, while others are very emotional and touching. The difficulty level of the game is also quite high, especially in monster hunting and side quests. It takes about 100 hours to finish the game.

Good points of the game:
- [b]Graphics:[/b] The graphics of the game are very beautiful and realistic. Geralt's facial expressions, hair, beards, everything is very well designed. The game's environments are also very varied and detailed. Mountains, forests, cities, villages, castles, everything looks beautiful. The colour palette of the game is also very harmonious and atmospheric. When you play the game, you really feel yourself in that world üòç
- [b]Sounds:[/b] The sounds of the game are also very successful and impressive. I recommend you to play the game with headphones, because you hear the voices of Geralt and other characters. These sounds increase the realism and emotion of the game. The voices are suitable for both the characters and the environment. All of the voices are very well dubbed. The game's music is also very beautiful and appropriate. The sounds of the game are one of the most important elements of the game. üéß
- [b]Story:[/b] The story of the game is also very interesting and unusual. The game tells both a fantastic and realistic story. The story of the game tells both Geralt's past, present and future. The story of the game tells both the fate of Ciri and the fate of the world. The story of the game is both action and drama. The story of the game reflects both Geralt's personal journey and his relationship with other characters. The story of the game is very deep and meaningful. After finishing the game, you can't get out of the effect for a long time. üìö

Bad aspects of the game:
- [b]Battles:[/b] The battle scenes of the game are the strongest aspect of the game. The game's battle mechanics are very fun and challenging. You don't just attack with two buttons and defend with one button. There is a lot of variety in battles. You can use different weapons, spells, potions, bombs, traps. A lot of strategy is also required in battles. It is not enough just to set the timing well. Battles increase the atmosphere and fluency of the game. Battles are the most fun aspect of the game. üòÅ
- [b]Puzzles:[/b] The puzzle sections of the game are also very interesting and challenging. The game's puzzles are not usually based on finding or matching symbols. The puzzles are very relevant to the story of the game. Puzzles do not slow down the pace of the game. Puzzles are the most mysterious aspect of the game. üòé
- [b]Replayability:[/b] The replayability of the game is also very high. Once you finish the game once, there are many reasons to play it again. The game has different endings and choices. The game has hidden elements and side quests. Replaying the game doesn't just mean doing the same things over and over again. Playing the game again increases the effect of the game. üòä

All in all, The Witcher¬Æ 3: Wild Hunt is a very impressive and immersive game. The game is very successful both visually and aurally. The game is very interesting, both fantastical and realistic. The game is both action and drama. The game is both a work of art and an experience. The play both entertained me and made me think. The play made me happy and sad at the same time. The play both frightened and encouraged me. The play both surprised and satisfied me. The play was an unforgettable play for me. I recommend the game to everyone.

If you like games that are more like a movie with several options for how the game will go, this is a great option. It has decent graphics, and a good story just like the TV series.

If you want to play a game with minimal interruptions and minimal grinding to get the thing you're seeking, move along. This isn't for you. I fall into this category, so I got bored with the game quickly and found myself skipping every ounce of dialogue after the billionth cut scene and boring back and forth.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt released in 2015 by CD PROJEKT RED is one of the most legendary and addictive gaming experiences you'll ever have. The sheer amount of content is absolutely staggering, and it's all at a triple A level of quality.

You play as Geralt of Rivia, a legendary Witcher (professional monster hunter and mutant), in one of the most dark and grim fantasy worlds out there. Geralt and his kind were created to protect humanity, but humans fear and despise him, so he mostly stays travelling. Your journey begins in White Orchard, where you are dedicated in finding someone who is like a daughter to you, Ciri. Ciri is not a mutant but she has been trained as a Witcher, and she also carries the Elder Blood within her, which is a rare lineage which boasts powerful magic and special abilities. Geralt, along with a colorful cast of friends and lovers, must band together to find Ciri and save the world from Eredin and his twisted Wild Hunt.

The Witcher 3 is a passion filled game made with the highest quality and amount of effort possible. It took me 35 hours to complete the entire main story on Death March difficulty, and I felt like I was going pretty fast generally. The characters and universe are extremely memorable and endearing, which is odd considering how bleak and unforgiveable their lands are. This is a hopeless husk of a world they are living in, and yet, the player behind the controller will be constantly filled with joy and impressed with the vibrant and beautiful colors / graphics.

I also wanted to make a special mention for Gwent, it's one of the most fun strategy collectible card games I've ever played and it's insane how much thought and effort was put into it considering it's a secondary mini game. The game can often feel like a movie at times, but it's a movie that lets you control it which is how you do it. The cutscenes are obviously fantastic, but they're actually more rare than you'd first imagine, most scenes in this game are conveyed via the game's actual engine and dialogue choices. On the topic of choice, this is a true role playing game at it's core as your decisions will actually matter and take drastically different effects, while you are obviously playing a pre-created character for you . . . Geralt, you can still very much decide how you want his journey to go and what kind of person he will be.

The Witcher 3 is a legendary title and it pains me to not give it a perfect score. The primary reason is that I feel The Witcher 4 is inevitable to come out and I know they can do even greater things than what they've done here.

Epic is this action RPG with captivating graphics, a remarkable soundtrack, and compelling storytelling. CD Projekt Red delivers a memorable experience, making it a must-play for fantasy enthusiasts.

Graphics and Presentation:

The graphics are undeniably impressive, and showcases a beautifully crafted open-world filled with diverse landscapes. The level of detail of environmental elements adds to the immersion, making the world feel alive and vibrant. The seamless transition between cut-scenes and gameplay enhances the overall presentation, enhancing the experience. However the low variety in npc faces somewhat subtracts.

Sound:

The voice acting deserves high praise, as it brings life to the characters by adding emotional depth to their interactions. Geralt of Rivia's gruff yet charismatic voice perfectly embodies the iconic Witcher. The original score delivers a powerful and atmospheric soundtrack that complements the gameplay, intensifying the impact of key moments. Everything else also sounds great, including the horrifying monsters. However the score is sometimes out of place.

Story and Characters:

The story delivers an emotionally charged narrative. The rich lore and intricate political landscape of the Witcher world provide a compelling backdrop for Geralt's personal quest. The diverse cast of characters, each possessing distinct personalities and motivations, enhances the storytelling experience. Every choice holds significance.

Gameplay:

The gameplay is competent, offering a variety of combat styles, a robust alchemy system, and meaningful choices that impact the story. However, the presence of level-gating can be frustrating at times. While level progression is common in RPGs, the sandbox nature may feel constrained when certain areas or quests are locked behind specific character levels. This can limit the sense of freedom and exploration that a true sandbox experience should offer.

Conclusion

"The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" delivers a captivating world filled with memorable characters, remarkable storytelling, and breathtaking visuals. Its excellent voice acting and original score further elevate the gaming experience. While the level-gating may somewhat hinder the sandbox experience, the overall journey through this rich and immersive world is undoubtedly one that every RPG enthusiast should embark upon. And the two story expansions are also remarkable, each in their own way. I would rate this 8/10 Adequate.

The story is compelling with meticulous attention to detail, and the characters and environments are visually stunning. However, a couple of aspects bother me. Firstly, despite being described as an open-world game pre-release, it's not entirely so. There are zones to load into, and although they are sizable, it doesn't quite align with my expectations of an open-world experience akin to games like Skyrim or Far Cry.

The combat is another aspect that doesn't sit well with me. Despite updates, the movement feels peculiar, leaning more towards console controller gameplay rather than being optimized for mouse and keyboard. Lastly, the inability to save during certain story events has led to some frustrating encounters. Waiting for the last save to load, enduring repetitive dialogue, or skipping sections, and then replaying the encounter can be tedious, especially if it's a challenging sequence.

Despite these shortcomings, I genuinely enjoy the game and would recommend it.

After finally finishing this game, I have a lot of thoughts. First off, this game still looks beautiful and the soundtrack is so amazing! This alone makes The Witcher 3 great. With the books Sapkowski created a beautiful world with beautifully deep characters. Seeing his work turned into 3d really makes me happy.

Storywise I have to say it's alright. You try to find people and while you do you see flashbacks of what they have been up to. What I did not like however was being barred from quests because I played too much of the main quest without knowing! I felt like I had to do every side quest, fearing it would randomly fail. Though at one point I couldn't bother doing any other side quests, because I wanted to keep the main story going and I was overleveled anyway.

Like the main quest, I'll rush the end a little bit: The main characters felt well made, while side characters usually were very one dimensional. Best example is nearly every peasant being "help us, m'lord! T'was a monster aye!". Geralt was just a glorified dog at some point. Skillbuilding felt alright and fighting itself was very nice. Alchemy never again felt as necessary as in Witcher 1, sadly. Swallow was the only potion I really needed.

All in all I enjoyed playing and I was happy to do all achievements. I probably won't play it again though.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt isn't just a game; it's a captivating journey that has gracefully stood the test of time. Melding an intricately woven narrative with stunning visuals and deeply satisfying combat, CD Projekt Red's masterpiece remains a shining example of enduring game design. Geralt of Rivia, our enigmatic protagonist, navigates a world where choices hold significant weight, transforming every decision into a gripping chapter in an epic tale. The landscapes are picturesque, the monsters are fantastically nightmarish, and the combat unfolds like a meticulously choreographed dance of steel that continues to leave players yearning for more. In a gaming universe filled with one-night stands, The Witcher 3 is the long-term relationship you'll remember ‚Äì an enchanting experience that not only withstands the test of time but ages like a fine wine, leaving you in awe long after the credits roll.

I've played through the main game and both DLCs twice. Even 8 years after release, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt remains one of the best RPGs you can play. CD Projekt Red produced a masterpiece with this game. It looked amazing at the time, and it still looks very good.

In terms of gameplay, you will walk, ride, swim, and sail around 3 massive maps. You will engage in responsive action combat and make use of your witcher signs and alchemy to battle both humans and a large bestiary of monsters. You'll meet interesting NPCs, and make tough choices during quests, both main ones and side ones.

As you play, you'll level up Geralt, find or craft new armor and weapons, and more.

This company set a new standard for side content. Almost every quest is worth engaging with, and will feature some interesting piece of lore, or plot twist. While the world is not reactive in the way that sandbox games are, there is still a huge amount of freedom and a decent acknowledgement of player choices and actions.

No review I leave can really capture the love and respect I have for the game. Geralt is one of my most beloved video game characters of all time. I could write a 10 page essay on why I edge to this game but I will leave it short and sweet: this game is nothing short of a masterpiece. I originally got it for xbox but of course had to pick it up for PC when it came out.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is nothing short of a masterpiece. From the moment I stepped into the vast and immersive world of Temeria, I was captivated by the sheer brilliance and attention to detail that envelops every aspect of this game.

Let's start with the visuals ‚Äì breathtaking is an understatement. The landscapes are so beautifully crafted that each corner of the map feels like a hand-painted masterpiece. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle add an extra layer of realism, making every sunset and stormy night a spectacle to behold. Whether traversing the bustling city of Novigrad or exploring the hauntingly serene Skellige Isles, the graphics create an unparalleled visual experience.

The character development and storytelling in The Witcher 3 are second to none. Geralt of Rivia is not just a protagonist; he's a multifaceted character with a rich history, and his journey is laden with moral dilemmas, intricate relationships, and unexpected twists. The supporting cast is equally compelling, with each character contributing to a narrative that is emotionally gripping and intellectually stimulating.

Combat in The Witcher 3 is a ballet of steel and magic, offering a satisfying blend of tactical depth and fluidity. Geralt's array of combat skills, combined with the variety of monsters and bandits to face, keeps every encounter engaging and challenging. The alchemy and crafting systems add layers of strategy, allowing players to tailor their playstyle and evolve Geralt into a formidable force.

The world is teeming with side quests and activities, each with its own unique storyline and moral quandaries. Whether aiding a troubled spirit or participating in a Gwent tournament, every side quest feels like a meaningful addition to the overarching narrative, enhancing the depth and longevity of the gameplay.

Musically, The Witcher 3 is a triumph. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack by Marcin Przyby≈Çowicz complements the game's atmosphere perfectly, eliciting emotions that range from melancholy to exhilaration. The voice acting, led by Doug Cockle's stellar performance as Geralt, is impeccable, adding another layer of authenticity to the characters.

In summary, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's an epic odyssey that sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. CD Projekt Red has crafted a work of art that seamlessly blends a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and immersive gameplay. If you haven't experienced the magic of The Witcher 3, I implore you to embark on this journey ‚Äì it's a gaming experience that will linger in your heart long after the credits roll.

This is, without a doubt, in my "Top 10 Best Games Ever" list, and I've been a hardcore gamer since '95, yet none have stood out as much as titles like the "Mass Effect" trilogy, "Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain", "Skyrim", "Assassin's Creed: Odyssey" [i](and a few others)[/i] alongside this masterpiece, which offers:

[h1]- a medieval, morbid and grim, yet fairytale-like atmosphere [/h1]

[h1]- literally hundreds of hours of fun, action, intrigue, turnarounds and decision making with consequences[/h1]
[i](I personally spent over 1000 hours enjoying it and finishing the full story twice on a PlayStation 4, hence the lower number of hours here on Steam)[/i]

[h1]- beautiful landscapes, spine-chilling ambiental soundtrack, awesome overall graphics, a captivating story full of original characters, epic battles and I could go on for hours...[/h1]

Not only that, but even though it's a "AAA" title [i](that has surpassed and will continue to surpass A LOT of big titles)[/i], the base game which also gives you about 16 free DLC's is half the price of what other big companies are charging for their so called "AAA" games, and the "GOTY" [i](Game Of The Year Edition)[/i] which includes both its massive DLC's, is only 50 euros. I mean considering the epic proportions of this game with all that it has to offer "from A to Z", 50 euros is practically "giving it away" as far as I'm concerned.

Trust me. [b]BUY[/b] it, [b]OWN[/b] it, [b]PLAY[/b] it, [b]LOVE[/b] it and [b]REPLAY[/b] it using the "New Game+" feature!
[i](also, I recommend purchasing the physical DVD's because it is a "MUST HAVE" until you die)[/i]

[h1]11/10 - Would choose to play Gwent over banging Yennefer and Triss any day of the week![/h1] [i](except the week in which Geralt is horny or when I am :D)[/i]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a magnum opus in the world of RPGs, seamlessly blending breathtaking visuals, a rich open world, and a narrative that captivates from start to finish. At the heart of this masterpiece is Geralt of Rivia, the iconic Witcher whose stoic demeanor and moral complexity create a truly unforgettable protagonist.

Geralt's journey to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, forms the emotional core of the narrative. Ciri, a character of exceptional depth and power, adds a dynamic element to the storytelling. The bond between Geralt and Ciri is beautifully portrayed, providing players with a personal stake in the grand tale unfolding across the Northern Kingdoms.

The game also explores Geralt's relationships, including the compelling romance with Triss Merigold. Triss, a powerful sorceress, brings her own complexities and moral dilemmas to the story, adding layers of emotion and choice to Geralt's already intricate life. The dynamic between these characters is expertly woven into the narrative, allowing players to shape Geralt's personal story through their choices.

The open world of The Witcher 3 is a triumph of design, offering a vast and diverse landscape teeming with life. From the bustling city of Novigrad to the war-torn landscapes of Velen, each location feels alive and meticulously crafted. The attention to detail extends to the characters populating this world, each with their own stories and struggles.

Combat in The Witcher 3 is both exhilarating and strategic, with Geralt's fluid movements and a variety of combat styles keeping encounters fresh and engaging. The monster-hunting aspect, a core element of Geralt's profession, adds a layer of depth to the gameplay as players prepare for battles with supernatural foes.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a crowning achievement in gaming. Geralt, Ciri, and Triss, along with a host of richly developed characters, contribute to a narrative masterpiece. The meticulously crafted world, combined with outstanding visuals and gameplay, make The Witcher 3 an absolute must-play for anyone seeking an immersive and emotionally resonant RPG experience.

easily one of the best single player RPGs to come out in the last 10 years. The world is amazing, they have a bunch of books to get lore and use for world building and they just do such a wonderful job of it. Each region feels unique but similar enough to never feel out of place. the Main Story is phenomenal, amazing writing, amazing voice acting, it just has a way of grabbing you in. 
Many RPGs let you build a character, and going into this i expected being locked into the role of Geralt to be not as fun as building my own character (this game was my first experience with the franchise, now ive read some books and played the second game also) but man they not only proved me wrong, but changed how i think about approaching video games. now i see playing a specific character means they can tell a more complete story because they don't have to use generic backstories that fit everybody, but they can use all that backstory to create a much more epic game. this game has caused me to raise my standards in video games and i now tend to be disappointed in them a lot more because of comparing them to games like this or RDR2.
Combat is amazing too to top it all off. the different builds allow for a lot of fun different ways to play. slashing with a sword is fun and all, but bomb builds, sign builds, alchemy builds are all just as much fun and usually even more effective when used right.

A bit ashamed it took me this long to actually do a full playthrough of this game and it's accompanying expansions, considering I was an avid fan of Skyrim and other games of similar genres growing up. After finishing Cyberpunk 2077 I finally decided I had to give The Witcher 3 a go too. 

Now that I've finally taken the time to play through the game, it's quickly cemented itself as one of the best games I can recall having played throughout my life. Playing this for the first time felt very reminiscent of playing Skyrim for the first time around 10 years ago - that is to say, I really enjoyed it. 

Great combat with a lot of variables (e.g. through use of different abilities, weapons, potions, oils, etc...), amazing story, exemplary voice acting, and such a rich and vast world with a bunch of different sceneries and activities to partake in. Hats of to the developers, writers and everyone else involved in creating the game. The game also looks amazing for it's age, though I expect that's also partially attributed to the next-gen update a little while ago. 

10/10 game, in my honest opinion. 

Will for sure do a New Game+ playthrough sometime in the near future (really wish CD Project Red would add that option to Cyberpunk 2077 too but alas)...

The Witcher 3 I hope my review will be useful to you (^^,)

I bought during a sale, for $ 6 + all DLS for free.
And let me tell you that this is one of the best games I have ever played.
Let's go through the pros and cons:

+ let's start with the plot, otherwise why would we play RGP :)
the plot is multifaceted, with each stage the game reveals itself like a young rosebud, from city to city from location to location. every decision you make affects the fate of the character, and this affects the ending.

+ the combat system, you need to pay special attention to it, it is so diverse that you definitely won‚Äôt be bored, you can make a super fighter, a supernatural mage or a hidden assassin out of a character, and that's not all - there is no feeling that you are constantly doing the same thing same. a large number of combinations.

+ open world, uuu my low bow here, because each location is worked out and collected in great detail - and the game of 2015 is already 7 years old and it will surprise you, I assure you. from white orchard to Kaer Morhen - these views are to be enjoyed, you will love them <3

+ musical accompaniment:
everywhere the atmosphere in the game is present, thanks to the music, it is maximally selected, in every tavern, location, and even in the game lobby, the music will accompany you throughout this wonderful game.

I hope I didn‚Äôt miss anything in the pros, and if so, I‚Äôll add it later. :)

and so the cons:

- if you are an avid fan of perfectly completed games, and love 100% completed achievements, this game will be difficult.
Started more than 4 times to make everything perfect, but never unlocked everything 100% :(

I recommend this game to all RPG fans.
this game is worth every cent spent.

p.s. This is my subjective opinion and thanks for your attention.

I've owned this game since 2016 on GOG.com and just over 4 months and 500 hours ago, I had purchased the Witcher 3 Complete Edition again on my Nintendo Switch because of their newly minted "CROSSPLAY" feature that allowed me to finally try to settle into the game and then take it up on PC... Oh, I did settle into it and some part of it settled into myself!

I've only ever attempted to play The Witcher 3 on DEATH MARCH difficulty because it's not a game that you should simply play like other games, no... The Witcher 3 is an absolute masterpiece at the highest difficulty and you only get out what you put into it. That said, I've tried to get into it a few times, yet I couldn't go beyond the doldrum grind of White Orchard without becoming distracted and kept away from my PC. The Witcher 3 on the Nintendo Switch broke the chain of my 3 fruitless attempts of getting immersed.
The Witcher 3 will take ahold of your daily thoughts and you'll be compelled to see it through soon after you break free of the initial slog through White Orchard. Truly, there's no comparison and no equal to what you'll face as you enter Velen to begin your search for Ciri. The continent is so massive that purists such as myself who chose only to travel by horse will soon be faced with a massive dilemma that only "GROWS" far beyond any previous experience... You won't be shortening the experience by choosing to fast travel, you're merely reducing distractions that will take you weeks off that path as you venture off course to explore.
The characters themselves are uniquely their own persons and full of life as I've ever seen. You'll come to respect every subtle nuance that makes every interaction worthwhile as you choose to listen to their plighted past. Ciri's as colorful as the Von Everrics are woefully dark and you can literally feel what type of person you're dealing with as though you were speaking to a real person. There are moments where you will fear the outcomes of having an interaction that could reverberate throughout the game... Or it could even be a Witcher job for an "imp" that will leave you torn on what you choose to do as you lay in bed, restless as you wonder whether you made the right choice! They all are as fascinating as they are fateful in your you play the game!
The combat is absolutely superb, not a simple hack and slash with more dodging; moreover, the abilities that you unlock will all find their way into your approach to overcome every enemy. The ability to counterattack is just as useful as it is deadly to both parties, but you'll eventually learn how to use it being mere dumb luck in an attempted block. Your impressions and effective use of signs will absolutely deviate from your initial thoughts of them all. The combinations are endless as you unlock new iterations of signs you'd once thought futile, every sign has a place. It would serve you well to keep an open mind and a few unused skill points as you progress in the path... There will be situations that throw you squarely into a fight that you never accounted for nor anticipated as the story is unpredictable!

In speaking of the epic tale which you're attempting to unfold, I can only say that it is the best writing that I've ever seen in my life! There's really no comparison to how the game lures you into becoming emotionally invested in the outcomes which you've had a hand in weaving. Your choices will have far-reaching implications that could help, harm, or severely impact everything that you've done as you will unknowingly leave the continent reeling from your best attempts at doing the right thing... It's truly something to behold when your choices continue to follow you into every village you enter...

Sufficed to say, this is the greatest game ever created; from the story, to the landscapes, and to your choices in how you choose to conduct yourself... All will come to change for the better or worse, based solely upon a lowly Witcher's choices.

I highly recommend you buy the game and undertake it on a difficulty fit for making it the most rewarding...
DEATH MARCH! You won't regret it! (10/10)

I'm very late to this party but I'm not at all surprised by the love surrounding this game. 

My gaming experience has been pretty lackluster lately with games like Starfield and the troubled launch of Cyberpunk and few other experiences that lead me to begin to believe, "maybe gaming just doesn't interest me anymore?"

This game has literally reinvigorated my love for video games. I love the diversity of creatures, monsters, and the lore associated with them. The environments are captivating and beautiful even by today's standards. The voice-acting and story-telling are compelling, fun, and interesting. I was blown away by what I thought were minuscule choices having a large impact later in a quest or story-line. If you love story driven games where your choices actually have an effect on the outcome of the world, characters, relationships, and who lives and who dies you'll love this game. Especially if you are a fan of the Fantasy genre.

The Witcher 3 is a good game, but not one for me.
There is a lot of fun to be had in this game, but that fun is spread over an insane amount of playtime due to the significant amount of filler. This is a LONG game, even if you just aim for the main content this game will take a while to complete. I simply don't have the time or patience to play the Witcher 3 all the way through. Some days I have less than an hour to play video games, on those days it is not very motivating to boot up the Witcher 3. Especially since the Witcher 3 has lots of dialogue, which I can appreciate, but often times Witcher 3's dialogue fails to be anything other than boring. On my first major playthrough I remember resorting to skipping through most dialogue to get to the more interesting parts.
This was my second major attempt to play the game, and I didn't get as far this time. There are 3 major parts I remember enjoying about this game. The first was the combat. Especially on higher difficulties, some of the enemies can be a thrill to fight. The visuals mixed with the sounds and the music is incredible. Sometimes the fights can be repetitive however, or even frustrating. The main fights I didn't enjoy on the Death March difficulty were the bosses that could heal their health. This got frustrating as these fights felt impossible. There was one boss called Jenny o' the Woods. I levelled up a significant amount, prepared, etc but still couldn't beat her. She would always heal herself way too much before I could kill her. Of course, I could just come back to her when I was 20 levels higher or look up a guide but I didn't want to. It wasn't an enjoyable experience. The second part I enjoyed about this game was some of the dialogue. You can get Geralt to say some cruel and badass stuff, that just makes you laugh or at the very least leave the conversation grinning. However, these moments were few and fair between compared to the overwhelming amount of dialogue. The final part I enjoyed the most were some of the bugs and glitches. Sometimes they created for a hilarious experience. However, the majority of the bugs and jank in the game were not enjoyable.
There are a truck load of mods, but I would always end up breaking the game whenever I tried to install more than 10 of them. I played through most of the game on my second playthrough with all the foliage and hair moving around at 3x the speed. I never could find the cause, probably because I couldn't be bothered to.
At the end of the day, I am happy I tried the Witcher 3 but I feel no need to play through all of its 100+ hour story.

Honestly, I gave the game about four tries, and it's so mind-bogglingly boring at the beginning that it just can't keep me playing. I honestly can't understand why it has such big diehard fans. The combat is trash, the movement is trash, and every 30 seconds, you're stuck in some boring conversation with some random NPC. The voice acting is so dull; it doesn't make me want to listen to what NPCs have to say. All in all, I'm really disappointed, considering the hype about this game.

Witcher is just an awesome universe and its hard not to love the game.

The story line is just captivating and interesting as you play the main game and DLC and how you can determine what kind of Geralt you will be :) - a fatherly, an evil one or up to your wildest imagination. The characters in the game are rich in their background as you interact and learn about them and how they will help you in the storyline.

Scenery I just got one word: Mind-blowing. I personally like Kaer Mohan view and this is one of the main element of the game that you can treat your eyes into as you go to various places in the Witcher world. This is a bigger plus point if your GPU can support higher settings.

The gameplay including fighting and crafting and the rest can be tricky at first but there ain't anything you can do if you fall in love with the Witcher world :) After all, I think Witcher fighting gameplay is still easier than Darksoul in many ways with the help of your magic. Fighting style you can develop in your own style and thats one big plus point for me.

The game do include romance also so if you like some romance as you imagine yourself as Gerald while playing the game, you got that option too :) This part is for you to explore yourself - no additional spoilers for you :)

Overall, Witcher 3 is an fantastic open-ended RPG with its own unique combat system with its deep and rich storyline. This includes things you can do like crafting potions, weapons and all while keeping it real like remember to repair your precious armor and weapon! Lastly - Gwent! You get to play games in this game itself :) If you do not know what is Gwent yet, start playing Witcher 3 to find out. its more fun that way - trust me!

[h2]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece of open-world RPG design, offering an expansive and immersive world to explore, a captivating story with memorable characters, and a satisfying combat system.[/h2] The game's strengths lie in its ability to transport players to a believable and dangerous world, where every decision carries weight and every encounter feels meaningful. The main story is a well-written and emotionally resonant tale of family, loss, and redemption, while the side quests are often just as engaging and rewarding. The combat system is challenging but rewarding, and the game's alchemy and crafting systems offer a sense of progression and customization but [u]the sheer amount of content can be overwhelming, and some players may find themselves getting lost or feeling like they're missing out on things.[/u] [b] It is a game that will be remembered as one of the best of its generation.[/b]
For the life of me, I hope CDProjektRed never changes.  I was thinking I would be bored out of my mind like I was playing Skyrim, but I'm never bored.  Not only that, the graphics are top notch.

Might be the best game I've ever played. It's not a bestseller like Zelda or Skyrim, but his game is incredibly well rounded and gem to passed down to the next generation as a model for what an RPG should look and feel like.

The mechanics: combat, abilities, arsenal.. there is a great flow to your actions while fighting, or even movement scaling various buildings and obstacles, traversing perilous areas by foot, horse or boat.

The storyline is true enough to novel with enough coverage of lore to make all the possible moral and political choices interesting and believable

The character development is phenomenal, even side characters are a great treasure of conversation, romance and comedic relief, as well as some heartfelt and wholesome moments.

The world and landscape are breathtaking. You won't even realise that you've poured hundreds of extra hours into the game on side quests, material gathering and general inventory/arsenal improvement -- exploring the map itself is a treasure and finding interesting and hidden spots all over the world keeps you on you toes as much as the sunset has you glued to the various horizons. The colour palette for this game is 10/10.

Finally -- THE RUSSIAN VOICE ACTING AND TRANSLATION --    11/10 

It reads and sounds like a Nikolai Gogol novel. The voice actors for Geralt, Yen, Djikstra, and almost every other lovable side personage was SPOT ON. As a native English speaker who lived in Russia, I think the Slavic background is reproduced in the game to an amazing degree.

Again, the colours, the semi dense forest turned farmland and plains, turned river and cave. It was like riding a train from Poland through the old Soviet bloc. The background conversation and dialogue nuances -- so many aspects of Slavic mentality are represented in the various characters and their mannerisms.

The banking scene in Blood and Wine is a spitting image of what it was like trying to get official documents processed in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia. From one window to another, with all the personnel ducking and dodging you while feeling they've already done you a great sacrifice. So many small moments and pieces of cinematic experience captured the desperate feel of central European feudal times as well as the blend to totalitarian and communist undertones -- it was all perfect.

Thank you CD Projekt Red and Steam

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt offers an immersive, engaging, open-world fantasy role-playing experience with excellent combat. The game's side quests and characters are particularly well-done, providing interesting scenarios to explore overall game is very good must play....

Devs receive: $40 ($10 when it's on sale)

You receive: The best 120 hours of your life and a lifetime of post-witcher depression

2/12/2023

''Blood and Wine DLC''

This DLC was a 10/10 with the fact that you get a new city called ''Toussaint'' and you meet loads of new characters with a lot of new enemies and gear like armor and swords. Story overall was way more interesting then the DLC ''Hearts of Stone'' because of the following reasons-

- Larger amount of the characters that you can interact with.

- It has High Vampires in it which is a completely new enemy that you learn to fight against or reason with.

- You travel together alot in the story exploring ''Toussaint'' together with important people that you help to fight againts the vampires which made the experience more interesting.

- I felt like there was alot of more balance between figting and talking in the ''Blood and Wine'' DLC overall which made it better.


''Hearts of Stone DLC''

DLC was okay but felt like it was kind of boring overall, some of the missions were interesting but it didn't feel like it was enough things going on in story like it was mainly just running around talking. I think it needed a bit more balance between talking and fighting because the ''Blood and Wine DLC'' got that done pretty well.

Rating overall 6/10

The Witcher 3 is such an amazing game, it has an amazing story, great quests to make sure that you never get bored of the hours you put into the game, and even if you are not doing all the quests, the world in this game is beautifully designed that I am still in awe walking around or just riding Roach from one place to the other.

I have finished this game on the Nintendo Switch a few years ago, but then decided to buy this game again to play on my PC and experience the next gen update. It's hard to say for many games nowadays, but for The Witcher 3, it is definitely worth every cent that I spent both on the Switch and PC.

The only downside for my own opinion is that I do not like the control, as in the control for walking and riding horse (especially when it involves me turning around corners or tight space). But it only happens in very specific tight situations and definitely does not affect my overall enjoyment since you won't be turning corners and tight spaces every time in the game.

Other than that, I highly recommend this game.
I'm sure there are plenty of people who would quickly disagree with me... but currently this game IMO is the best RPG that has been made in the last few years.

I bought this game on Xbox in 2015 when it was released as I was starting a new career with my local fire department. I couldn't hardly study for my job. I spend hundreds of hours exploring the world. Since then I've bought it here on Steam and just started another play-through 9 years later. This game ruined gaming for me. Ever since then, I've been yearning for a story that grips me like this. An environment as beautifully crafted. Being rewarded for exploring every corner of the map. Nothing has brought me the satisfaction this game delivered. Even today, it still stands as the best game of all time IMO. It made me read all the books, go suffer through the combat of Wither 1 and 2, and whine about the Netflix series. It's an incredible, must-play game, that makes me fantasize about living in a world like it presents. 10/10.

At the time of writing this review, I have invested more than 100 hours into The Witcher 3 and have completed the main content alongside Hearts of Stone DLC.
.
After you get pass the game mechanic learning curve, The Witcher 3 provides impressive game play mechanics and immersive medieval Europe experience with vast number of likable characters. The main narrative is entertaining, and the pacing is executed relatively well. 
.
The major DLCs provides additional content and game play mechanics that added up to the based game extremely well. In Blood and Wine you will unlock additional city which lighten the mood of the game itself.
.
All in all, the Witcher 3 is an RPG masterpiece that has stood the test of time since its release in 2015. I believed that this game is worthy for a 9.5/10 recommendation score.

I can't believe I've never made a review for this game, but The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is more than just a video game; it's a transformative experience that captivates players from the first moment. It goes beyond mere entertainment and immerses you in a meticulously crafted fantasy world that's teeming with life, secrets, and moral complexity.

The moment I stepped into the vast and intricately crafted world of The Witcher 3, I was captivated. Its open world, meticulously designed and teeming with life, is a work of art in itself. The attention to detail in the landscapes, cities, and characters is staggering. Every nook and cranny is filled with stories, quests, and secrets waiting to be unearthed.

The beauty and fantastic craftsmanship of all the characters add another layer to this immersive experience. Each character is intricately designed, with their own unique personalities, struggles, and stories. It's not just Geralt who feels real; every interaction with the diverse cast leaves a lasting impression.

As you traverse this breathtaking world, the soundtrack becomes an integral part of the journey. The symphony accompanying your adventures isn't just background noise; it's a soul-stirring composition that evokes a range of emotions. Whether riding through the sweeping landscapes or engaging in intense battles, the music heightens the experience, making each moment memorable.

Despite being a few years old, The Witcher 3 holds up beautifully and continues to shine as a testament to timeless game design and storytelling. Its storytelling remains nothing short of masterful, drawing players into a morally complex and emotionally charged web of choices and consequences. Geralt of Rivia, the protagonist, faces dilemmas that make players question their values. This narrative depth is a testament to the exceptional writing and character development in the game.

The Witcher 3 holds a deeply personal significance for me; confidently and proudly claiming the title of my all-time favorite game. Its profound impact on me transcends the confines of the screen, creating a journey that has etched itself permanently into my gaming memories. This immersive world not only played a crucial role in helping me through a difficult time but also provided a much-needed escape and a source of solace.

The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece that deserves every accolade it has received and more. If, by chance, you haven't played this game already, you should do so now and discover the magic for yourself.

This game is an absolute masterpiece in terms of RPGs. It is unbelievably immersive and takes you on a journey through a meticulously detailed world. 
[u][b]Pros[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*]The storytelling is one of a kind, the Witcher 3 has established itself as a all-time great. The entire narrative is complex and contains well-developed characters.
    [*]The side quests are as compelling as the main storyline, which sets the level that the Witcher 3 is depicted at
    [*]Even 8 or so years later after release, people are still finding out new/different dialogue options dependant on what routes you choose
    [*]The combat system is engaging, each encounter is fun and challenging (as long as you play on Death March difficulty)
    [*]Great modding capability
[/list]

[u][b]Cons[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*]The combat system can feel slightly clunky, especially dependant on what input method you use. Game is best designed for controller input rather than mouse and keyboard.
[/list]

What can I say about this game, It's an absolute masterpiece. Just can't express in words how much I love this game.

Graphics are just beautiful and gorgeous, so many landscapes that leave me breathless and I just pause for a moment to admire them. Armor in the game looks great, weapons too. Animations are great and the character models are great. CD project red did a fantastic job.

A testimony to the music is the fact that it has been years since this game came out and I still listen to the soundtrack regularly in my free time, it's just that good. I never get bored of this soundtrack and I just wish that there was more of it.

Gameplay wise this game is amazing as well. No weak points with this title in my book. Controls are smooth and the way the combat system is built makes me feel like I am a real witcher. 

Story is also outstanding. The Witcher 3 makes you feel for its characters, you want to resolve their problems because you just care about them, a true example of good writing. And In my opinion the Hearths of stone dlc has the best story of the whole game, just love it.

Overall all an amazing game worth much more than its price in my opinion and I'm not say that you should take my opinion for granted  but that is just how much of influence this game has had on me. After the witcher 3 no other rpg feels on par with it. I strongly believe that everyone owes themselves to play this game, It's just that good. I urge everyone that reads this review to try this game. Definitely my all time favorite game, I may be biased, but I just love this game and I only wish I could replay it blind again, it's just that great of a game!

I forgot to write a review for this game god knows why and now i'm writing this two years after finishing the game. 

In short this game is one   of the masterpiece of this generation. Visually a stunning game. Forests, river, swamps, populated/abandoned villages everything just look amazing. My personal favorite was kaer morhen area. I turned off my hud and minimap just immerse myself into this beautiful open world of witcher. Whales in skellige sea left me mesmerizing.

Story and gameplay was was great. I'm not going to spoil it for you if you havent finished the game already.  Combat works flawlessly. I even enjoyed preparing to hunt or fight a monster, reading the bestiary for its weakness, putting proper oil to the swords, drinking the right potions. Loved the little details developer put in this game, people running for shelter when storm starts, random peasants shouting at the witcher, giving information about quests, children playing and singing, Geralt's facial hair growth and hundreds of other things like this.

The side quests are incredibly designed. They will put you in a dilemma. Also both of the dlc were amazing. 

Witcher 3 was really an amazing experience and adveture. Looking forward to W4.

I immersed myself in the mesmerizing world of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt back when the game first came out, and I can confidently say it's nothing short of a masterpiece! From the breathtaking landscapes to the richly detailed characters, every aspect of this game is a testament to the developers' dedication and passion.

The open-world design is unparalleled, offering a vast and diverse environment that kept me constantly engaged. Whether traversing the bustling cities, exploring dense forests, or sailing across vast seas, the attention to detail is astonishing. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle add a level of realism that enhances the overall immersive experience.

But what truly sets The Witcher 3 apart is its captivating narrative. The story is intricately woven, filled with morally gray choices that have meaningful consequences. Geralt of Rivia is a compelling protagonist, and the supporting cast is equally well-developed. The relationships you build and the decisions you make truly shape the outcome of the game, providing a level of depth rarely seen in the gaming world.

The combat system is both intuitive and challenging, rewarding players for mastering the art of swordplay, alchemy, and magic. The monster-hunting contracts add an extra layer of excitement, as each creature requires a unique strategy to defeat. The game strikes a perfect balance between action and strategy, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout.

The attention to detail extends to the visuals and sound design. The graphics are stunning, and the soundtrack perfectly complements the epic journey, enhancing the emotional impact of key moments. Voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life in a way that's truly unforgettable.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a tour de force in the gaming industry. CD Projekt Red has crafted a masterpiece that not only raises the bar for open-world RPGs but also sets a new standard for storytelling in video games. If you haven't experienced the magic of The Witcher 3 yet, you're missing out on one of the greatest gaming adventures of our time!

CD Projekt RED for several years managed to accomplish what other developers can only dream of - to create a gamer analogue of the "Game of Thrones" and achieve world recognition by expanding the target audience of The Witcher from a group of Sapkowski's brainchildren to the whole gaming community. In addition to the unique world in The Witcher, there is something that radically identifies it in the space of the RPG - it is a tremendous naturalism of everything that is happening. Developers do not adapt to the toothless norms of artistic expression, prescribing bashfully hide naked bodies and pools of blood, do not offend women and children and, of course, include as many representatives of all races and minorities in the frame, even where they are inappropriate. 
As in the plot relationship, and in the severity of the issues raised, the authors remain faithful to the spirit of the original. There is no good and evil here, the ideals of justice give way to real social problems. Tyranny, infringement of the rights of groups of population, widespread cruelty and, of course, the struggle for power - politicized fantasy in popular culture is very popular today, but in the world of role-playing games - a rare bird. "Witcher" is densely inscribed in the artistic basis and confidently uses its resource. Did the developers finally uncover the potential of the universe in the final chapter of the history of Geralt from Rivia? 
Masters of needlework 
As the degree of elaboration of the plot, characters and voiced social problems, and territorially the world of "Wild Hunt" has become larger and more complete than in the previous parts. Quite correct in this case will be a comparison, not even with them, but with the standard of "large size" - The Elder Scrolls. However, unlike the latter, the scale in The Witcher is not the goal, but a condition for immersion in what the "Scrolls" just do not suffice - into the soulful atmosphere of the Slavic epos. 
Galloping the horse overcoming dense forests and endless plains, strolling through the streets of local villages, climbing the snow-covered mountain peaks of the Skellig Island, not only get aesthetic satisfaction from the grandiose landscapes and incredibly beautiful graphics, but also you feel the scale and significance of what is happening. Each frame of The Witcher 3 is filled with life: the trees are swaying from the gusts of the wind, the village children are sporting by the lake, along the roads are gangsters and warriors. In the inn you can throw yourself into a gwint (card game) and have a beer. In Novigrad you can listen to the priest's sermon, and in the tavern - indulge in the memories under the delightful song of Priscilla. The living world of the game, full of adventure romance, is beautiful. 
Chasing a girl 
In order to understand all the nuances and subtleties of the events and better penetrate the atmosphere of the world, it will be useful to get acquainted with the books of Sapkowski. However, this condition is not mandatory: after visiting a tavern in the first village you delve into the political situation. The northern kingdoms are experiencing the expansion of Nilfgaard, people hardly conceal their dislike for the invaders, somewhere a guerrilla movement is formed, conflicts between the local population and the "blacks" are erupting. All this, as usual, is just the background for the main action. 
Geralt remains faithful to the indestructible principles of neutrality and refrains from interfering in state affairs. The hero and his problems are enough: the love of his life, Jennifer, is forced to cooperate with Emperor Emgyr, Triss Merigold is hiding from the local inquisitors in Novigrad, and with the adopted daughter, Ciri, the situation is very bad - it is pursued by the Wild Hunt. Actually, it is to the search and rescue of the lady that the main storyline is dedicated. 

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt compares favorably with its closest competitors: from Dragon Age: Inquisition - the manual study of quests, from Skyrim - focus on the plot and its nonlinearity. On
the strength of the feeling of presence, the creation of CD Projekt RED is several goals higher than anything that has appeared in recent years. The trilogy about Geralt receives a brilliant completion in the form of "Wild Hunt", uniquely becoming a classic of role-playing games. 

Pros: a huge world, stunningly beautiful and filled with a variety of unique content; a large number of stylistically verified and voiced dialogues; set of choice situations; an amazing atmosphere; an interesting and rich history of the world and characters. 
Cons: weak artificial intelligence; some witch's abilities can upset the balance. 
Rating: 9.5 / 10 good

Awesome game, I wish they never made the final update though, a terrible update.

It's really impressive how great the vast outdoor areas look thanks to the newly updated lighting. The open wilds already looked great, especially for an eight year old game, but dang, the improved ray traced lighting helps so much. Just more proof that lighting has been the weakest link in 3d game visuals since the second generation of 3d consoles and we can't get to full raytracing soon enough.

And of course, it's still the same excellent game as ever beyond that. Great story, great sidequests, very well written characters. The combat remains as... adequate as ever, and some aspects like inventory in particular and menu usage in general haven't aged very well, but at the very least, the biggest problems have been fixed now. Automatic oil usage is finally built-in, and alternate character movement makes Geralt a little less lurchy and clunky to move around. There's still about a dozen more quality of life improvement mods that should have been built in too, but hey, better some of the few problems were solved than none.

Speaking of improvements I would have preferred though, while the outdoors look amazing under the new lighting, interior lighting seems hardly changed at all. Apparently, sun and sky rays could be traced, but candles and torches couldn't? Not sure what's going on there, but the result is that the interior areas look much more dated than the exteriors, assuming you're using the latest bells and whistles.

Of course, there's more to this game than just beautiful backgrounds, and that's where the visuals don't succeed as much. No amount of improved lighting changes the fact that I just don't care for a lot the character designs overall and absolutely none of the monster designs. Not that they're technically lacking in any way, I just don't care for the designs themselves. But that's just par for the course with pretty much any western game relative to my tastes. If you're totally about realism and intentionally ugly monsters though, than it's all good. And hey, at least the music is a lot more pleasing to my ears than the character designs are to my eyes, the soundtrack absolutely holds up as well as ever.

It's often hard for me to give a simple yes or no, but not here. The Witcher 3 is a game that's about as close to perfect as any game has gotten, and has only gotten even better with the recent updates. Very, very recommended.

Definitely get the Complete Edition though, the DLC is both significant and even better than the main game content. In every way.

In 2023, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt has undergone a transformative update, gracing players with next-gen graphics that breathe new life into an already legendary game. As a seasoned Witcher, stepping back into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia feels like revisiting an old friend in a dazzling new light.

The visual overhaul is nothing short of breathtaking. The meticulously crafted landscapes, now richer in detail and realism, immerse players in the sprawling world of The Continent like never before. From the sun-kissed meadows to the murky swamps, each environment is a testament to the game's commitment to visual excellence.

Character models have been revamped, granting Geralt and his companions a level of detail that makes facial expressions and subtle nuances more palpable. The cinematic sequences, already a hallmark of the game, now showcase an even higher level of fidelity, enhancing the emotional impact of the narrative.

The lighting and weather effects are among the standout features of this update. Dynamic weather transitions seamlessly, casting dramatic shadows across the landscape as storms brew and clear. Sunsets and sunrises paint the sky with a spectrum of colors, adding a layer of beauty to the already captivating scenery.

Performance-wise, the game takes full advantage of next-gen hardware, delivering smoother framerates and quicker load times. The responsiveness of controls adds an extra layer of fluidity to combat, making battles feel more dynamic and engaging.

While the graphical upgrade is the star of the show, the core elements that made The Witcher 3 a masterpiece remain intact. The rich storytelling, complex characters, and morally ambiguous choices continue to shape a narrative that's as captivating as it is morally challenging.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt's next-gen update is a triumph, elevating an already outstanding game to new heights of visual splendor. Whether you're a returning Witcher or a newcomer to the world of monster hunting, this enhanced edition is a must-play, showcasing the timeless appeal of a modern classic in the RPG genre.
